One of the best RPG I have played!

Great game in most ways but it has his flaws like the fight system which not respond as quickly or accurate as it could be. But finally you get used to it ;o) Well, sometimes that doesn't do what exactly is supposed to as you have to choose the right sword first - depends if you fight a creature or a humanoid - and then you have to choose the style of your fight and here begin the trouble as sometimes you reach the target but finally that wasn't the good option and sometimes you had the good one but you missed every time.
In fact that the biggest and mostly only complaint I have against this game. Every other aspect is great nonetheless: great scenario with quite a good bunch of third parties quest, nice ambiance music, graphic very well done (mostly when we know that is a 2008 game!), the dialogue system nicely put (you have to make a choice between the different option you get as it will have some impact for the rest of the game), the alchemic system not so difficult to understand and which could help you a lot and finally you had lots of information regarding the history/explanation of the different people you will meet during the game, the monsters, the places etc.

So as you can imagine I warmly recommend this game for every gamers who like RPG, I'm sure you won't regret it!

Un des meilleurs RPG auquel j'ai joué!

Un superbe jeu sur plusieurs plans malgré quelques défauts comme le système de combat qui ne répond pas aussi vite ou précisément que l'on souhaite. Mais on finit par s'y habituer :) Mais des fois cela ne fait pas exactement ce que c’est supposer faire du fait que vous devez d’abord choisir le bon type d’arme en premier – selon si vous devez vous battre contre une créature ou un humanoïde – et après vous devez choisir le style de combat et c’est là que les problèmes commencent car des fois vous arrivez à atteindre votre cible alors que ce ne sont pas les bonnes options choisies et des fois vous avez les bonnes options mais vous rater votre cible à chaque fois.
Cela dit, c’est la plus grosse récrimination que j’aurais envers ce jeu. Tous les autres aspects sont excellents : un très bon scénario avec pas mal de quêtes annexes, excellente musique d’ambiance, graphique très bien fait (surtout quand on sait que c’est un jeu de 2008!), le système de dialogue bien mis en place (vous devez faire un choix entre les options que vous avez car cela aura de l’influence sur le reste du jeu), l’alchimie pas trop compliqué à comprendre et qui pourra beaucoup vous aider et enfin vous pouvez avoir beaucoup d’information à propos de l’histoire / explication des différents protagonistes que vous allez rencontrer durant le jeu, les monstres, les régions visitées etc.

Donc comme vous pouvez l’imaginer je recommande chaudement ce jeu pour tous les amateurs de RPG, je suis sûr que vous ne le regretterez pas!

reviewText:
A Fine RPG Whose Strengths Outweigh Its Weaknesses
Date of Review: October 12, 2015

Nearly eight years ago, a Polish game design studio named CD Projekt RED released a new CRPG based off the book series by Andrzej Sapkowski. It was the studio's first released game. This game is The Witcher.

After having The Witcher in my games library for a long time and seeing the strong reception its sequels have gotten, I decided not long ago to finally play it through, start to finish, as part of a greater plan to run through the entire Witcher trilogy. I'm glad I did. The Witcher is not without noticeable flaws, but is a decent game in my opinion.

Very Different from Its Successors

I want to note early in this review that The Witcher is powered by a very heavily modified Aurora Engine - the same engine that powered Bioware and Obsidian's Neverwinter Nights games. CD Projekt has come a long way since 2007 and the more recent REDengine is a far cry from the aging Aurora. If someone comes from the second or third game to see where the series started, they might be in for some big surprises, as the interface and combat are very different from the sequels. It may take some time to get used to!

Combat, Alchemy, and Item Use

Combat in The Witcher has a great deal of depth to it, but its mechanics may not appeal to everyone, so I will explore it in depth.

The Witcher's combat is fundamentally based on maintaining a mouse clicking rhythm in order to chain up attacks on a selected opponent. Each mouse click does not correspond to an individual swing but rather initiates an attack animation that may have multiple swings in it. Clicking at the right moments continues the chain and makes Geralt initiate increasingly elaborate and damaging attacks. Clicking at the wrong time or too rapidly will disrupt and reset the chain. Dodging and parrying are basically automatic. Although you can direct Geralt to spin past enemies or jump over them by double tapping a movement key, these maneuvers are generally more useful for getting into a better fighting position than actually evading an attack.

The real complexity of The Witcher's combat comes from the various systems laid on top of the basic attack chaining, including choosing the correct weapon to fight your foes, choosing the right combat stances, using magic, and using alchemy. Geralt has silver and steel swords with different purposes and three different combat styles to chose from at any time: a strong style for fighting large opponents, a fast style for agile foes, and a group style for eliminating crowds of enemies in arcs all around him. Proper use of magic permits Geralt to stun opponents, set them on fire, or immobilize them with pain. It can even let him execute spectacular and brutal instant kill attacks in combination with his swordplay.

The alchemy system is interesting and serves as one of the main reasons to loot opponents. Monsters almost never carry new weapons, but their organs can be used to make useful potions and bombs. Potions can last for several in-game hours, as do grindstones used to sharpen Geralt's swords, or oils created to temper his weapons versus specific foes. There is strong incentive to prepare heavily for combat long before entering it and to know your enemies' weaknesses in advance of fighting them. At its best, combat in The Witcher combines strategy and tactics with extremely satisfying results.

Environments, Sound, Story, and Consequences

The Witcher is a game with beautiful environments and the modified Aurora engine actually does a good job of rendering both urban and wilderness maps. Overall the game world feels well crafted with praiseworthy attention to detail. I will note that I did see a few graphical oddities, but they ceased once I forced V-sync with my graphics card. In terms of sound, the game has some very well done music tracks that give a lot of life to the game world.

As one probably expects, the best part of The Witcher is the story and how Geralt's actions affect his world. The plot is immersive and your actions do matter. One thing I really liked was that after making a major choice and eventually seeing the consequences, you would get a cutscene with an illustration of what has transpired in the style of a storybook. During the cutscene, Geralt will narrate on the effects of that choice, giving some insight into how this has affected the world. There's a decent number of these throughout the game, usually associated with major quests, and they were one of my favorite parts of the game. I also give special praise to the design of the chapter endings, which were universally strong and usually brought a climatic resolution to the plotlines that were devevloped throughout each chapter. I also felt that Geralt's dry wit was highly amusing, much as it rubbed some of the non-player characters the wrong way.

There is also a decent sense of progression in the game as Geralt levels up, builds his identity, and relearns witcher magic. It does take time, as some of the upgrades the player can purchase on leveling up are relatively small, but it is very satisfying witnessing Geralt tear through hordes of opponents in the endgame after starting so humbly in the prologue.

Flaws

Although this is an overall positive review, The Witcher is not without noticeable flaws. Even though the environment is detailed, the placement of the world geometry on some of the maps, especially in the various swamp areas, can make traveling through them much more time consuming and annoying than it needed to be.

For many, the biggest flaw will simply be the combat system. At its worst, the combat in The Witcher devolves into a dull repetition of waiting for the attack prompts to appear over and over. If one finds the rhythm based clicking and management of sword styles unappealing or was expecting control over the individual swings, blocks, and parries, their enjoyment of The Witcher's combat will be severely limited. Furthermore, there are occasionally oddities in hit detection and movement attributable to the mechanics of the Aurora engine. I did not let these hurt my experience, but I recognized them from having previously played the Neverwinter Nights series.

And much as I praised the story overall earlier, the game does have some pacing problems. In my opinion, this was most noticeable in the early game. The prologue is excellent as the attack on Kaer Morhen serves as a good impetus for Geralt's quests, but chapters one and two can go very slowly at times. Both of them have excellent climaxes at the chapter endings, but the gameplay in the middle can sometimes feel like it is moving at a crawl with too much repetitive traveling through the same villages and swamps. This is compounded by some quest design problems, as I feel that a number of quests were executed somewhat badly, resulting in confusion, tedium, or both. There is also some uneven dialogue and subpar voice acting that simply does not match the quality of other parts of the game.

All that said, I did not find these problems overwhelming and when the game really hit its stride, it was extremely compelling.

Summa Summarum

I really enjoyed The Witcher, but will also readily admit that it has its share of flaws. Provided one is forgiving of the game's rougher portions and is willing to put up with some aged mechanics, I do recommend this game.  It also sets up very nicely for import into Assassins of Kings for those interested in playing the entire trilogy from start to finish. I know I'm looking forward to continuing my game into the sequel and then into The Wild Hunt.

reviewText:
In Witcher you follow around some guy named Geralt, who looks like he just hit his midlife crisis. Lucky for him, he has amnesia and doesn't remember anything. Much to everyone's disappointment though, he doesn't forget how to be extremely boring.

Geralt has many redeeming qualities like being in heat all the time and nothing else. I don't know how he sleeps with enough women to populate a large village, but he does, and it's as sad as it sounds. Watching Geralt  try to seduce women is like watching your recently divorced father beg a Wal Mart greeter for a date.

What's worse than that though? The game doesn't let you forgot your moment of shame because it drops a card in your journal to remind you of that proud moment when started collecting video game women like trophies. They might as well include a fedora and self help book with the game.

After you take a shower to wash away all that sleaze, you can enjoy... Oh no wait, this is when the developers thought slow clicking and micromanaging how dumb your character looks would make for a great combat system. Well don't worry about that, because after all the grinding you get to spend your hard earned points on thrilling, state-of-the-art skills that mostly just increase your main damage or some other vague damage that doesn't really matter. All the different damages and micromanaging seem like a failed attempt to add some depth to battles.

And you definitely won't forget how mature this game is: every other character uses cuss words like they don't understand how language works, but that's ok because no character seems to know how being memorable works. When the writing isn't too busy being vulgar for no reason, it also finds time to show how grown up it is by throwing around morality and politics like the clumsy kid in gym class.

You might be thinking Wow that sounds negative
date:
how can you be recommending this?"
Well here is how this little trick works: Just copy and paste the second word of every sentence and that's what my actual review says!

Just kidding. But seriously
recommended: I enjoyed this game despite the flaws and I was pretty swept up by it."

reviewText:
Oh, The Witcher. One of my favourite RPGs from now on.

I had to admit, I could only play it through for the third time I started it, yet, I feel this is just something that everyone has to try out. At first glance, it may seem a little complex and boring (because of the alchemy stuff for example), but once you get into it, you just can't stop. The choices you have to make, actually make you think about the world in the game. I can say, that I totally got familiar with my character in the game, I was able to make choices that were really mine. The story sucks you in, and after  40-50 hours of gameplay, and finishing the game, you just still want more of it. And that's the time you buy The Witcher 2. :)

Oh, and a good advice for newcomers to the game. Make sure you do a lot of alchemy, you'll need  it mostly in mid-game.

I haven't played the second game, so I don't know how much the game got improved after this.

Of course, The Witcher also has some negative aspects. Actually, it has a bunch of it, at first it may not seem like an AAA game, but believe me, it is. One of the worst aspect is the voice acting. I played it in Hungarian, which, in my opinion was  actually not that bad, but as I tried out the English version, I just couldn't stand it. Another little negative thing is, that sometimes you have to do a lot of running, between quest givers, or merchants to sell all the loot you just can't carry. One thing that troubled me about the story is, that in the beginning there's a lot of references in the game which you know nothing about, but by reading in-game books and talking to people, you can get to know a lot about The Witcher's lore.

Regarding everything, as I already said above, this gem became one of my favourite RPGs of all time. Another good thing is, that you can import your saved games to The Witcher 2, however I don't know how much will it affect the second game, yet.

If you read my review to this point, then I only have one more thing to say.

Go, and play this game!

reviewText:
The Witcher: Enhanced Edition Director's CutDevelopers CD Projekt Red | Release date 2008

One of my favorite RPG games. Solid RPG that features moral choices and great story line. Game keeps you in dark climate of fanatasy medieval. Witcher 1 is based on A. Sapkowski (polish writer) book called Wiedźmin". Book shows story about Gerald the witcher monsters killer for hire. Book is based on Slavic mythology. In game is a lot of slavic mythology elements like monsters (demons) and rites. All of that is put in addictive sidequests. Combat system isn't well but is easy to learn.

7/10"

reviewText:
I will just come right out and say this and go into detail as to why this game is one of the best RPGs of all time.

This is the 9th time I have played and beaten the Witcher on PC. I believe that holds my highest replay rate of any game I have ever played and I have been gaming since 95. As someone who is a huge RPG nut this game hits every spot we RPG people are looking for. I will now go into the reasons why the Witcher 1 is absolutely worth playing and if you want to play Witcher 2 and 3 you should NOT skip this game in the franchise.

The world. The game world has a dark feel to it, based in realism, rascism, and people being what they are so commonly capable of being. Monsters. The games are based of Novels from Polish author Andrzej Sapkowski who created a world deep in political and personal intrigue. This is one of those games you Game of Thrones fans can appreciate as well. Nothing is as it seems and never take a coin without thinking of the consequences.This game makes you think. It lets you play how you want, you can remain neutral (as Witchers are sworn to take no part in the matters of the human world similar to Grey Wardens). Their concern is monster hunting and profit from such activities. You can take sides, with benefits and downfalls. The game leaves choice to the player. That is what makes the world so amazing.

The sound and graphic design still holds strong as a game from 2007. The graphics and a majority of bugs and content were added in the enhanced edition. Which was CD Projekt red's way of saying we are sorry the initial launch was so rough and pretty bad to be honest. That is a moot point now, as the game looks great still to this day and plays quite well. The voice acting is quite good and enjoyable, although there are only a few voice actors for as many characters as there are. So expect to hear the same voice actor more than once. Geralt has one of the best voices of any bad ♥♥♥ in any game ever as far as I amconcerened.

The gameplay. In my opinion the UI and quest system is superior to Witcher 2 because it was
built for a mouse and keyboard where as Witcher 2 was sadly designed around a console UI (sigh) I expect the Witcher 3 to be the same sadly. Anyway the combat system will turn most people away from this game and one reason I enjoy it as much as I do. As a fan of the Dark Forces games from Lucas Arts such as Jedi Outcast and Jedi academy their combat was styled around the stances" play. Where you would need a different fighting style to tackle different enemies effectively. Strong
date:
Medium and Fast. The Witcher uses this system and I do love it. The combat comes down to chaining attacks effectively for devistating combos and executions. A lot of people think its repetative and boring and to be honest I can understand but if you enjoy the fighting style in the first place you will be
right at home with the combat in the Witcher.

That being said
recommended: this game for the sake of having a deeper appreciation and understanding of the\ngames world play the first one. It is an excellent RPG that has aged well even if it is a little\nclunky. Your armor
hoursPlayed: weapons and some major decisions carry over into the Witcher 2 and seemingly into Witcher 3 if we are lucky. So if you are one of those Mass Effect
voteText:
Dragon Age fans who love choice and consequences reoccuring in your games. The Witcher series is among the finest if not
the best.

Give this game a shot. It is fantastic. I hope this review helps you people on the fence to give it a try.
10/10"

reviewText:
Ah, The Witcher. I'll admit - I was one of the naysayers - I played this game a couple years back. Gave it an hour or two of my time. However I just couldn't get over the hurdle of combat. It didn't feel right, fruitlessly clicking to time your attacks. It felt clunky, disjointed. I tossed it into the backlog and thought nothing of it.

I gave it a second chance recently, due to all the Witcher 3 hype, and am thoroughly glad I did. Yes, the terrible combat mechanics are still there, but they are not even nearly as bad as I thought them to be in my first attempt at playing. Behind all this lies a deep and engrossing storyline that makes you care about the characters and the areas in which you frequent.

There are many choices in the game that change the course of the story as you go. Actions have consequences - it usually ends up as the lesser of two evils. The game has an overall 'dirty' feel to it - towns aren't entirely 'happy' and cheerful. You see things like racism, foul language, and general debauchery. You can even go so far as to sleep with many different women, who are more than happy to provide you 'trading cards' showing off their, ahem, assets. Its things like this however, that greatly set it apart from other RPGs, which is certainly welcoming as a lot of other games utilize the 'cookie cutter' approach far too often. Its good to be 'bold' with your games, and I highly respect companies like CD Projekt for doing so.

The game has three difficulty settings - I recommend playing on hardest. It's really not all that hard, aside from a boss fight or two, but it makes you rely on using alchemy and potions, as well as utilizing sword stances and parries/dodging. It really brings out the best in the game and gives it a steady pace as you progress through it.

At its core, the game plays like most other action RPGs, but you do have to time your mouse clicks to chain attack combos, which has notably been this game's biggest shortcoming. Otherwise, you have your typical potions and buffs/food, alchemy ingredients, and a few weapons here and there (you only swap armor literally once). The focus is less on the loot, more on the story. However the 'less is more' approach tends to lend more weight to the new items you acquire, and gives you a better appreciation of them.

You can level up quite often, and the game has a skill tree where you can upgrade talents based on your traditional stats such as strength, dexterity, etc., as well as a few magical spells you use (you have a total of 5 spells, but they, much like the weapons I mentioned above, have more weight to them and are very useful). You can also upgrade your sword techniques from here. There are a multitude of potions you can craft, which result from collecting herbs and ingredients on your journeys. The key to fights are finding hints and literature before approaching most monsters, and preparing accordingly with potions or oils.

Overall, The Witcher is a very well rounded game. Its graphics are older, but still hold up well today. It presents much of the same RPG elements but injects many other angles that make it unique and memorable. I definitely recommend this game if you have the time for it. It took me about 48 hours to beat (my time says 51, but I do not count the 2-3 hours from my original attempt a while ago). I didn't rush through it, did about 85-90% of side quests, and took my time. Enjoy it for the story, and remember that there's no wrong way to play this game. Live with your choices and press on. The story of Geralt of Rivia is an amazing one, and you won't regret it.

reviewText:
I have finished The Witcher Enhanced Edition yesterday, after 71 awesome hours of gameplay. During my playthrough, I really enjoyed the game and when I was not playing it, I was dreaming about playing it :). It is one of the best games and best story RPGs that I have played, it is really intense, has an awesome story, lovely progression system and a great game alltogether that really makes me feel awesome. Normally, I would be sad after finishing such a game. However, it is awesome that I had the possibility to import the save games in the Witcher 2 and the adventure will continue :D.

You play the Game as Geralt of Rivia, one of the best warriors in the game world and also a witcher, belonging to a guild of monster slayers. The game takes you through beautiful medieval castles, cities and villages. The story is very intense and you have many decisions which affect the game and COMPLETELY change the main story. Some little sudden and seemingly insignificant decision somewhere in the game might have an effect in a further quest very close by, or maybe in the next chapter after 10 more hours of gameplay or maybe even towards the culmination of the story. I just loved how my decisions not only mattered but shaped the story in a completely different course to the other choices. This game is awesome. From a graphics point of view, the graphics are beautiful. I enjoyed seeing the big city of Temeria with all it's huts, medieval fortificantions, swamps, villages, beautiful fields and more. The game also runs smoothly, with no bugs. The combat is very awesome, very fun and addictive.  There are also many interesting things about it such as enhancing your weapons, preparing bombs, potions, using oils, magic.

I really also loved how the game  has a discovery feeling to it. You encounter certain monsters in the wonderful world. Then you might hear a story about them or read a book about them to give you more information and tell you about some valuable ingredients for your potions that you can take from them. I really liked how nothing was random in this game, every monster species has its own purpose, own description, own location and time in which it appears, own secret book to find about them, own quest or quests involving them.

After travelling in this game through such a fantastic fantasy filled with great characters, stories, lovely places (the city, fields and water will tell you of another gorgeous world which exists beyond our own), I feel awesome and will probably start the Witcher 2 today. Thank you, developers, 10/10, 100% recommended, one of the most beautiful games you ca play, like reading an awesome book or seeing a great, memorable movie, but here you are it's awesome hero.

reviewText: I finally finished The Witcher after starting it over a year ago. I wanted to savour the mature storyline and it's richly detailed world. The game has 70+ hours if you do most of the sidequesting and you're trying to get all the girls (Yes, you can have sex with many of the women in the game - but all you get is the same blurry animation and a nude or seminude card of them). Hence you often get distracted from your main goal and the main story tends to become secondary to all your conquests.  The only problem with the Witcher is that because it is so long it tends to get repetitive, a lot of fetch quests and back and forth travelling (no fast travel) and specially the same NPC models returning for different characters on the new towns and villages. Even the enhanced edition feels like it could have been more polished with a few extra models (for old ladies and beggars for example - there's only one for each kind), even the women have limited models, you have the peasant woman, the town girl, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the nun and of course the elves and druids but after 40 hours of gameplay you get tired of always finding the same innkeeper and women in each town. Nevertheless you will want to own this game just to watch the epic CGI opening and closing sequences and to try the rather original if not entirely satisfying combat system;  or, if you don't have the time, just try the flash parody game 'the ♥♥♥♥♥er', it basically gets the gist.

reviewText:
This game is one of my favourite games ever and i personally think it even beats the second witcher.
The witcher 1 has one of the best stories i have ever personally experienced, and without spoiling to much you will be shocked by the twists and turns it takes throughout the 30+ hour story. It features theifs, elves, humans, dwarfs, monsters and much more which it ties together nicely with an overarching plot about politics, racism and much more.
As a small tip i would say try to do all the sidemissions, they lend a great bit of depth to the main plot and even the smaller quests will play their role in some way later on.
The combat system can be a bit basic and the pace is a little bit off sometimes but overall this game is amazing and you owe it to yourself to play it!
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The story in The Witcher is deep, the main character is amazing in his complexity (a moral code he created himself in order not to question himself, a neutrality he cannot maintain...), the dialogues are in my opinion even better than those in DA:O, there are changes happening in the world that made me totally immersed in the game.
It made me want to read the books which are comparable to Terry Goodkind's The Sword of Truth and Robin Hobb's The Royal Assassin and I now want to have a computer able to run the second properly (and hopefully the third too).

Story aside, some people say that the combat system is clunky ; it is not that bad, it's just different from what we are used to in other games but the good side is that it makes you need to look for ingredients and use alchemy to create elixirs and these are what makes Geralt what he is : a witcher, no longer truly human.
It takes a few minutes to understand how the combat system works, with the different stances, the two main different weapons (one for humans, one for monsters) and the importance of adapting to each enemy.

I recommend this for anyone willing to play the sequels or who is looking for a new quality book series (note that the stories from the books and from the games don't overlap and that there are many references to the books in the dialogues of the game).

reviewText:
Having just now concluded the story of this game and most of the side quests, the word to describe how I feel is: Amazed.
Woah, what a ride this game takes you in. For those who don't know, this game was based on a polish book series and this first game certainly does it justice. The story is indeed amazing, real kudos to the author Andrzej Sapkowski for this experience and to CD Projekt Red for making it playable. I got drunk, made love to 10+ women, was a successful detective, got drunk again, slayed tens of different beasts, died of an overdose, left the present and came back.
The only con of this game is the combat which sometimes will fail hard on you and might result in frustration, more so in the last 6 hours of the game.
All and all, a must-play for every RPG lover and any gamer who loves a game with an amazing story. For me this worked perfectly, as I am both.

Rewarding experience. 8/10 would get drunk again.

reviewText:
Great RPG based on the universe of books written by Polish writer Andrzej Sapkowski. It tells the story of Geralt, a witcher, a monster slayer.

- Great living world, affected by our choices and decisions
- Very interesting story
- Simple, but satisfying combat system
- Excellent soundtrack
- Brilliant dark fantasy atmosphere

One of my favourite games!
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game really brings a lot of classic RPG elements into the gameplay and story. As you expect the The Witcher is based on a series of book written by the polish author Andrzej Sapkowski, so from the beginning the game already has a really large and well established lore to start with. The game puts you into the boots of Geralt of Rivia, a witcher that is trained since he was very young to become a badass monster slayer, but he is not doing it for free, you need to throw a couple of gold if you want your local atrocity to be dealt with. In terms of gameplay the game can be a little clunky but it's rewarding as well. Geralt is able to equip one of his two swords, more precisely the steel sword and the silver sword. The steel one is used for killing humans and the other one is for monsters. I still can't see how the silver one is not that effective against humans but I let that pass. Geralt will be able to explore a vast open world with interesting characters and I will warn you, that there is a lot of dark comedic tone in pretty much all the dialogue but somehow it manages to give The Witcher the personality it strived for. The UI is gonna be very strange at first but will get used to it and it will never break imersion when you shuffle through your inventory for potions and recipes. The music and sound is pretty good and matches the medieval fantasy air that the game brings, but the voice acting is kinda less to be desired. On the bad note The Witcher suffers from the disease called ♥♥♥♥yourquesttracking"-ilia. Is really easy to get all your quests managed when you can't find where the hell are you supposed to go or how many of "x" monster you have to kill to get "y" item so you can fetch it back to "z" NPC. Despite all those flaws The Witcher has been a really fun experience and I would recommend it only to people that enjoy a dark and mature story.\n\nP.S. I don't like to give any games that I review any grades or marks or any other kind of number so I'll say that if you find yourself atracted to game you should try it first hand
date: before judging it from some popular reviewer POV.\n\nGame On!"

reviewText: The Witcher 1 is a very fun game to play especially if you are going to go down the series. To start, I'm going to say that you should buy this game when it goes on sale for 85% for $1.49 (which it does often). For the price that you pay, you get well worth the cost back with fun.\n\nThe Witcher 1 has a nice compelling story with a good conclusion. You play as a Witcher called Geralt who lost his memory and try to track down Salamandra. There are a phlethora of both main story quests and side quests and the intermingling of those actually make the quest line very fun. It also makes the side quests (grinding ones sometimes) much less boring and some can get done while you do the main quest. As for the main story quest, you can alter it depending on who you side with at times. There will be quite a few times where you have to side with people or make key decisions. Although they don't ruin the story if you chose the other" side
date: they do change some of the narrative in the future.\n\nSo onto some of the cons that make me want to rage sometimes. First of all
recommended: there is no jump option. This isn't a big deal or anything since the space bar is just atactical pause
hoursPlayed: but there are quite a few hidden walls where there clearly shouldnt be or could not be. You litearlly cannot jump off any kind of ledge at all
voteText: no matter how small. Furthermore
helpfulPercent: the combat is a bit clunky in many regards and like with the invisible walls

reviewText:
I decided to play this underrated series, The Witcher. I bought 1 and 2 during The Witcher sale (around April or May, I don't know) for under 5 dollars which is a great deal. So, I ended up being hooked on because what game makes interesting is the storyline itself.

+ Pros+Interesting storyline
+Great replayability
+Unexpected plot twists
+Interesting characters
+Alchemy crafting system

- Cons-Requires timing to create chain combo
-Limited free roam
-Movement controls
-Initiating attack can be frustrating at times

Conclusion: Overall, The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a great series to start with. It's immersing experience for me but linear free roam and combat system needs to do a lot of work. I don't think I can recommend for some people to start the series but only some people who are dedicated to narrative singe player experience.

reviewText: Is The Witcher worth playing? I don't know, how much is your time worth? Do you love excellent RPGs? Does it bother you that in some brief flash within the space time continuum, our absurd existence will have began and ended in a flicker, only to wash away in the cosmic tide where there is no life, moral or meaning? reviewText: Neutral: This first instalment in the Witcher series is something of a flawed gem: a good story well-told that suffers at the hands of it's needless complexity and poor combat system.  It seems to mistake complexity for quality in many aspects, creating an overly complicated series of mechanics that ultimately end up resembling a Rube Goldberg machine.  Nonetheless, an above-average plot and some decent character writing help buoy the Witcher to be a worthwhile CRPG if you can stomach the complexity and insubstantial combat.\n\nRead the full review here[www.highlandarrow.com]

reviewText:
Now let me begin first by saying that i realise this game is old, this review is my opinion on the game and what i think of it.

This game ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off more than flappy bird did by far, all because of its crappy combat mechanics. You can't block or parry or dodge attacks by will, it is all determined by chance, which increases as you level up the correct skills. It is a 3rd person click mini game to put it short, you draw your sword and click on an enemy to execute techniques to damage your foes. It was good  that you couldn't spam click, you had to wait and click at the right time to execute a move correctly, otherwise it will fail. One thing i admire about the combat mechanics is the fact that you have 3 different stances, one is slow but does a lot of damage, one is for swift enemies, and the other stance is used when you fight against more than 1 enemy, i loved that idea. But AGAIN, its broken, at some point i was surrounded by 10 enemies and switched to group stance, my attacks never registered for some reason and i always ended up just casting Area of effect spells.

You had the ability to cast spells in this game, which were very useful. You could cast a certain amount of spells based on your endurance" levels. Finally a game that excludes the word mana. The spells were extremely hard to land sometimes as it is always casted in front of you.

The enemy AI of the game is completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Sometimes they would just take it up the ♥♥♥ while you hit them with your sword
date: you could run in circles of tables and stuff and they will blindy follow you. When they have your back turned to you and are unaware to your presence
recommended: they would suddenly turn around when you get close enough and start attacking you. So there wasn't really advanced intelligence of enemies in this game

reviewText:
This game is absolutely awesome.  I was never bothered about Witcher when it first came out or even when others mentioned it.   When i saw the trailer for The Witcher 3 i was blown away and straight away thought this is going to be right up my street (RPG fan), so i bought 1 & 2.

From the start of Witcher the story is a little hazy and for some reason it doesn't grab you right away.  A bit of advise:  Stick with it!  After about 3 hours in the story begins to unfold and the gameplay really picks up.  As you play more and more the more additive is becomes.  The story is just brilliant and really draws you in.  I was really surprised how i was so into it and how i just wanted to play more and more to unfold more of the story and path i had chosen.  The path you choose is up to you, choose wisely on what you do and who you go with, it all matters in the end.

If you are looking for a good RPG, then this a great game to play and you won't be disappointed.  Just great!

Feel epic when you complete:-)

reviewText:
Now let me begin first by saying that i realise this game is old, this review is my opinion on the game and what i think of it.

This game ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off more than flappy bird did by far, all because of its crappy combat mechanics. You can't block or parry or dodge attacks by will, it is all determined by chance, which increases as you level up the correct skills. It is a 3rd person click mini game to put it short, you draw your sword and click on an enemy to execute techniques to damage your foes. It was good  that you couldn't spam click, you had to wait and click at the right time to execute a move correctly, otherwise it will fail. One thing i admire about the combat mechanics is the fact that you have 3 different stances, one is slow but does a lot of damage, one is for swift enemies, and the other stance is used when you fight against more than 1 enemy, i loved that idea. But AGAIN, its broken, at some point i was surrounded by 10 enemies and switched to group stance, my attacks never registered for some reason and i always ended up just casting Area of effect spells.

You had the ability to cast spells in this game, which were very useful. You could cast a certain amount of spells based on your endurance" levels. Finally a game that excludes the word mana. The spells were extremely hard to land sometimes as it is always casted in front of you.

The enemy AI of the game is completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Sometimes they would just take it up the ♥♥♥ while you hit them with your sword

reviewText:
Great game, still holds up after 7 years.

It can get tedious at times (I'm looking at you Chapter II) but the great story and the consequences of your choices make up for that.
It's also a great time-sink. One playthrough as a Sign focused witcher took me almost 70 hours. The combat near the end was ridiculously easy thanks to maxed out Igni and Aard signs. Will play through the game again as a bloodthirsty swordsman just to experience that side of the game, too. I bet it will feel like a completely different game.
Another great thing is that you can import your saves to the second game and see the results of your actions.

All in all, if you're looking for a good old RPG with lots to offer, you should definitely play this game.

2015 ReviewWhile the incredible story and masterpiece of worldbuilding remain quite intact, a few things a very dated and don't quite survive the years. If you are dedicated enough to pick up the game these days, you'll want a few things:

Full Combat Rebalance Mod (glitchy, but not moreoso than the original game).

A very large amount of free time.

reviewText:
Like:
+ the story,it's very engaging and deep, got me hooked.
+ that you have choices which can affect things later on, making you often question if you should of made that decision.
+ Main characters are memorable.
+ the fist fighting and poker playing.
+ I think the graphics are quite good.

Dislike:
- Combat is terrible, click enemy wait for sword to glow, click again succeed and repeat or fail and start again.
at first didn't like how the combat felt, but after getting used to it past the first boss, it doesn't seem too bad and is worth putting up with as the story is good. And once you start getting combo's into the 3's to 5's it's quite fun to watch Geralt do elaborate multiple swings and backflips.

-Not fond of the easy, trashy women, every woman I come across in the game wants Geralt. None of them seem to have any morals or respect for themselves. And don't have old fashion values of courting, romance or being wooed properly.

-Monster hunting side quests a bit boring and repetitive.
-some quests have a lot of back tracking with no quick way to travel.
-inventory is so small with no way to expand it.
-unimportant NPC's have many replica's such as old peasant women all look the same, the merchants all are fat richly robed etc.
-A bit too linear, can't go back to previous areas.
-A bit disapointed at the end to obviously what Alvin has become in the future.
-even playing on normal mode, didn't need alchemy much, mostly just used swallow, Cat, white rafford's Decoction and the occasional oil coating. Didn't bother with bombs.
-With the signs only used Aard for knockback and Igni for Incineration, didn't find the others that useful or necessary.

Despite the things I didn't like, I definitely reccomend this game, especially for those who like RPG's and a good story. This game to me is a must play. 7/10 Not worthy of an 8 as the combat is rather clunky and not very good.

reviewText:
So, let me tell you a story about how I came to put 38 hours into The Witcher: Enhanced Edition.

Like many of the people probably reading this review I was scouring the internet finding out whether or not it was worth playing this game or skipping straight to The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings, before jumping into the recently released and critically acclaimed The Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt.

A friend of mine (who also left a review here, check it out under 'Thorns') brought me the first 2 in the Steam sale last winter and suggested I played them both.

After much research over whether or not the first game was still worth playing, it seemed unanimous that YES, it was because it is a unique and enjoyable game with fantastic lore, music, and characterization (albeit with janky combat and some strange, questionable decisions made throughout) although it wasnt a necessity if i was going to play it for story alone.

Well.
After taking the plunge I am happy to report that this game is well worth the time and effort I put into playing it, and stands true as one of the most interesting game worlds i've ever had the pleasure of being a part of.

YES. The combat is initially a confusing and unrepsonsive mess. You cant use a controller with this game and so the combat consists of you choosing the necessary sword (steel or silver) and a combat style best suited to the situation (strong, fast or group) and quite literally having to time mouse clicks via on screen prompts.

Yeah, it's an odd choice.

This being said at around hour 4 I had the hang of it and actually came to love and respect it's uniqueness in it's own way.

If you can get passed this early on, along with the relatively old animations, occasional hiccup in writing and lack of multiple chracter models (seriously, there cant be anymore than about 20 in this 35+ hour game) then you will be enthralled by the music, the deep and interesting lore, the humor and the cast of fun and enticing characters.

In the end I would say I possibly enjoyesd this more than I did The Elder Scrolls V:  Skyrim.
I know, that's a bold statement. But I think Skyrim delivered everything I expected and nothing more. The Witcher exceeded my expectations immensely. Don't do what I did and pass on this game because you think it's too old or outdated.

Play it, love it.

P.S. - You can have sex with a HUGE amount of the women in the game, and each time you do you collect an old school Nudey" trading card.

Just because.

On one occasion
date: I beat up a young girl's father because he wouldnt let me see his daughter to fetch a friend's lute back
recommended:
convinced I was going to shag her because that's what my friend did. I then proceeded to shag her brains out. She loved it.


10/10 would throw done with daddy again..."

reviewText: This game is incredible. It has all the Witcher lore and characters that any fan would love. The gameplay and the user interface aren't brilliant, so be prepared to deal with that. Apart from that everything else is great. It has that sort of hardcore old school RPG feel to it where the game gives you minimal guidance and leaves you to do most of the thinking to very, nowadays, extreme levels. I wouldn't recommend it as an introduction to the Witcher universe unless you're into that hardcore old school style of RPGs. I would recommend, instead, either reading one or more of the books or playing the second game. It is much easier to fall in love with this universe if you do that and this specific game becomes a lot better once you do.\n\nOverall it is an incredible game and a must play for any Witcher fan.

The story was good although you can fail quests just by advacing in the story, and also you can screw up at least for me Geralt character if you don't go neutral ending which I didn't went not on purpose but ended joining with the scoia'tel and at least from the books what I see from Geral is that he is a BAMF/lone wolf that doesn't care about what the others are killing themselves for although he interveins if something is screwing up the nature balance or something like that.
In conclusion it's a good game even better if you experience the right ending at least for me I thought that.

reviewText:
Simply amazing,
You play as Geralt, A witcher, a man who was taken as a child and subjected to a number of experiments to become a Witcher. A Witcher is a monster slayer... a person who sets out to purge the evil of the land. Their training as children make the efficent, powerful, and fearsome characters. They are able to use magic, heal at a rapid rate and during the process they become sterile.

This game is full of adventure, sex, action, and a compelling story. Although the voice acting could be a bit better it's quite amazing and on the level of Skyrim. You have choices that ultimately change your story. The world is a linear in a way, but open. It has different areas you can go into, with in those towns, villages, and cities you visit you can freely explore them until you move toward the next area.

For this review i give this a 10/10 It's an absolutely gorgeous fantasy style rpg game that is not only fun, story driven and interesting, there is tons of side quests and challenges that just make it more fun. They have people talking that make it more fun and it's defintely a must have for any gamer.

reviewText: Behind the ennui that is the first chapter, the esoteric combat and somewhat dated visuals lies a rich world drenched with atmosphere, unique characters, great dialogue, great soundtrack, compelling quest lines and lore, sex and a prize winning cow.

reviewText:
I remember playing this game 7 years ago, and yet when I started playing it again, the story was different.
Instead of your usual linear RPGs, or those who have choices but they barely make any impact ingame, in The Witcher, everything you do has an impact on - the story, enemies and others. It feels great! Few games have ever achieved this level of detail.

Everything you do has an outcome, so not only this game has a high rate of re-playability, it will suprise you on your second run how things go different.

Also if you are a big pervert like me, you also will enjoy the sexual theme going in this game(infact in the book Geralt, the main hero, bangs anything that moves and is female apparently).

Well written story/ies, very original and distinct from what we are used to, the only downside is the combat system, but I got used to it.

One of the best RPGs out there indeed! I highly recommend you to try it and I tip my hat to CD Projekt RED.

reviewText:
I waited a long time to play The Witcher. It was made using the Aurora Toolkit, a module editor from one of my favorite games, Neverwinter Nights, the first game I ever bought, and the only one for many years.

The best thing about Neverwinter Nights was, of course, the editor, nay, the great community of players who made such amazing content. It was released in 2002 and people are still playing it, still making new content, much because Neverwinter Nights 2 was so disappointing. I played some incredible modules, some of them in multiplayer, using the DM client, which allowed playing like it was a paper and pen RPG, really. Why they never released another game with this feature?

But enough about Neverwinter Nights, let’s talk about The Witcher. It is everything I expected, and more. I could cope with the limitations of the engine, and the story really surprised me for its deep. Many themes were dealt in this game: politics, sex, alchemy, magic, destiny, the holy grail, mutants… I had no previous knowledge of the Witcher universe, but I fell in love with it. It’s like Game Of Thrones meets Conan meets Van Helsing. Geralt is smart and charming. The game makes you feel like your choices matter, even makes you feel guilt about them later. Except for the way you treat women, and that is a shame.

The political issue caught my attention: The Order of The Flaming Rose represents a fanatical religious and military organization that hates non-humans (that represents native peoples). The non-humans fight for freedom and equal rights. The druids represent environmentalists, helping non-humans when they can. Those in power only want to keep their power. The witchers represent a small, powerful group of people who prefer to stay neutral, but end up being used by both sides of the conflict.

The ending is great, but it could be even better if the things you said to Alvin actually affected the end result, assuming Jacques is really Alvin from the future.

So, in quick list:
+ Great story
+ Interesting setting
+ Well written dialogues
+ Balanced quests, including some puzzles
+ Nice character system (considering the limitations of the engine)
+ Includes an Adventure Editor
- Some glitches and other engine limitations
- Combat sometimes gets boring with so many spawning monsters
- There are some holes in the narrative

reviewText:
The Witcher 1 Enchanced Edition is a great game that is underestimated by many. The biggest issue for people is combat. Well it's not that bad when you're 20h into the game. Of course the combat may be an obstruction for most, but you just need to ignore that single fact. The combat actually becomes enjoyable when you are around level 10-14. thats when the real fun begins.

9.5/10

Story is just amazing. It starts slowly, introduces player into the world, teaches ropes of the game. Later on it picks up the pace seriously fast throughout the game only to put player under maximum pressure in chapter 5. There is a lot of sex and I mean it. Geralt can have unlimited number of intercourses and he wont have a baby (no need for protection eh? lucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ :P).
Regardless of old age of the game it has a lot to offer and will deliver a lot of fun and enjoyment. If you decide to do completionist walkhrough you need around 55 hours to do so. Not only you get countless sex occasions (that includes threesomes, foursomes even going at it with goddess!). All is presented in very tasteful style and player is rewarded with a hand drawn card of a woman, Geralt had intercourse with. All is done in very tasteful manner, not vulgar <insert any hardcore mature video names here>. Ever wanted to beat up father so hard, that he would beg you to stop only so you could get to his daughter 5 minutes later upstairs while he is still recovering from beating downstairs? This game is definetly for you!

The graphic is outdated but that does not matter, in the longer run once you get used to it, you may consider some shader play and reflections actually pretty (i.e. shader play in the sewers, reflections in royal rooms, etc). Textures are so low resolution that its laughable. There is mod to improve overall graphic quality but I didnt use it personally. The game regardless of huge amount of patches that were released, still suffers from occasional stutters in some areas throughout entire game. They occur only in some insignificant places.


To do list in the game:
* get to know as much women as possible, that includes working girls(if u get a deal with brothel lady, one cheap flower is enough for full service with one of girls:P)
* beat up a father till a point he begs you to stop. ofc u get to his daughter 5 mins later upstairs while he is taking the inflicted pain downstairs lol
* get in a threesome with 3 nice vampire ladies
* get drunk a lot, especially during cutscenes with dandelion
* get on in action with village waitress from chapter 1 in the mill, locals will believe ghosts haunt the mill again xD
* get drunk hard, purchase a special drunk bonus skill and fight everyone while totally wasted
* even more sex!
* slay some memorable monsters
* seduce a goddess in the game
* become so op with strenght and dexteriety that opponents cant hit you 95% of times :D
* run around the sarcophagus in crypts while being chased by the striga, do not forget to play benny hill theme in the background! priceless laughs guaranteed :D
* beat up everyone in the inn's
* get laid even more (food for fun lol)
* allow yourself to be immersed into the world of the witcher, this is great world you just need to open yourself for it
* fight the evil and bad guys
* become a gambling legend and whoop king's butt for almost 4000 orens :D
* make decisions that fit your own morality, conscience and values
* even more stuff to do, list would be way too long. oh have i mentioned more sex?
* epic alvin twist at the end of the game

To sum things up the Witcher 1 Enchanced Edition is one of greatest games ever released. Great atmosphere, immersion, story, characters, world, amazing soundtrack. There is way too much to  mention! It has its own flaws but lets face it, nothing is perfect. Technnologically (some animations, some movement, some funny bugs are here, but not many). Perfection is plain boring. (this is why ill never understand people abusing plastic surgeries, perfection doesnt exist and each surgery needs maitenance each 6-10 years period). The combat may be flawed but it's very rewarding once your character develops to certain level. If you're looking for great game or want to experience Witcher series from scratch, go ahead and start with first installment of the series. You will not be dissapointed whether you buy it on normal price or as soon as it's on sale. It will be money well spent. Assuming that you have got the game, do not forget to check Witcher 2 Assasins of the Kings and Witcher 3 Wild Hunt :)

reviewText:
It's been some time since I finished the game but I didn't write any review about it. In fact I've played it 6 years ago when I didn't have the game on steam so it's time to write my view on the game.

GREAT GAME. If you like story driven RPGs you won't go wrong here. The atmosphere of the whole world is pictured really well. Gloomy and corrupted world full of complex characters. It's up to player to figure out true character of persons and make decisions with them. Combat may not be for everyone but I like the way how they made it. You simply click on the enemy and at the end of attack you click again to join another attack. It isn't really hard but some timing is required. You have 3 different styles (strong, fast, group) which you can change according to situation. Also you have some kind of magic (signs) which makes a combat more interesting and some alchemy. Everything is upgraded through a talent tree with higher levels.

The plot is interesting and your decisions actually matters. Graphic is pretty good for a 7 years old game. You can make it even better with some mods.
I finished the game twice now and maybe I will play it again in the future. It took me over 50 hours to finish the game on hard difficulty with every sidequest I could find.

So I can only recommend this game for everyone who likes RPGs with STRONG STORY, nice graphics, interesting combat and other things which good RPG should have.

reviewerDisplayName: yung nish from the east side
reviewText:
A beautiful game, even after 7 years. The Witcher is a dark and rather mature game. You get to make game-changing decisions that let you feel as though you are a part of the game.

The first chapter is rather slow, but it gives you time to experiment around and get a feel for the combat. Some of the game mechanics were not explained properly (such as the alchemy) and it took a bit of experimenting to get some things to work. The combat is not truly combat. You click when an icon appears and let your character do the rest. That, coupled with the fact that signs were too overpowered, led to a dull gameplay experience. However, all that are minor annoyances compared to what the game is truly capable of. The developers don't hold your hand and lead you through the entire game. Instead, they give you a few basic tutorials and leave the rest to experimentation. It also helps that alchemy is not a must (unless you're on higher difficulties).

All in all, the games treats you like an adult, leaving you with choices that feel real. You must choose between several choices based on your moral code, since nothing in this game is truly black and white. You would be hard pressed to decide sometimes and what you choose really just comes down to what you feel is right. The graphics are'nt amazing, and there are quite a few technical issues, but overall, I feel that this game is worth playing.

reviewText:
As a person who knows the story very well, and read all the novels, I feel that my impression of the game is twofold. On the one hand, the game is great, it has amazing dialogues, storyline, quests, lore, characters, etc. - it is obvious that PC Project did a great job. However, I highly advise to read the actual novel prior to playing this game, or many things might be totally unclear to you (the entire story of 7 books is very long though, and it is understandable that not many people have enough time to do it) or at least, try to find the Polish movie of 2000 (which is a crap though).

Unfortunately, the Witcher series are not that popular as Game of Thrones in North America, which becomes a problem because majority of people know nothing of this Universe and what had happened in the world prior to this game - and there were lots of things happening. I ll try to summarize everything in one sentence - a war had happened which united the Northern Kingdoms against an army of Southerners, the war was won - at the same time, there is a huge Elven rebellion happening, and of course, Witchers, the mystique organization which had sworn to protect humans from evil, is slowly disapepearing from the public. Geralt is among the last ones to survive.

Of course, devs did a good job explain everything from the start, but still the game has enormous amount of flashbacks which test your knowledge of the series, and in order to enjoy the game in full extent it is advisable to know what the heck is going on at least.

On the other hand, there is some element of uncertainty. A. Sapkowski, the original author of the series, made it clear several years ago that the story of Witcher did not end in his books yet, and if I understand it correctly - he is working on another book currently. In this way, I am just very confused whether how this game as well as Witcher 2 and 3, would fit into Universe. But this is a question which cannot be answered yet. For now, I give a strong A + to the game.

9 / 10

reviewText:
After having a bit of a struggle, I decided to give this game a thumps up. My opinion doesn't differ alot from most of the positive reviews: The Witcher 1 is a game with a well-designed story which is based on the witcher-novels of Andrzej Sapkowski,  astounishing graphics (at least back in it's release-days in 2008), complexe quests and tough/impactful decisions as well as memorable characters...

Yet it also suffers from certain problems, mainly considering the fighting system and (from todays perspective) some lesser gameplay issues as well as bad" graphics and a very deep lore which needs quite some time to be fully understood. This may scare you off if you're not 100% determined to finish this game.

In my opinion one should watch some gameplay videos or read the first novel before considering to play this game. This will make it easier to understand the lore and might also give you some determination to play it. All in all one could say that it's worth playing for the sale price of one dollar/euro..."

reviewText:
I am recommending this game with a few caveats. It's 2016 as I write this, and I refuse to play The Witcher 3 until I beat the previous two, and we all know that I have to play The Witcher 3... I HAVE TO! I am now 50-something hours into this beast and I'm not gonna lie to you, it is a ♥♥♥♥ing grind sometimes. Collect ten of these, bring this to there, grind money, farm herbs... It reminds me of some of the worst parts of WoW at its low points. There's also The Witcher's graphics, which, in its day, probably would have melted my face off like the ark of the covenant, but now they're pretty rough. The gameplay is equally dated and suffers from some truely bizarre implementation choices (Parapa the Rappa style combat?). It takes grit to get through it sometimes.

But despite all of that, there is a seed of greatness taking root here. Even by modern standards, the original Witcher has an incredible depth to its mechanics (flawed as they are), and a richness of character and storytelling that is woefully lacking in most games (even modern RPGs). There's no black and white moral scale here to define your actions. No need to max out your good or evil points to get this or that ability. Just choices. You make choices and you live with the consequences. That's the price of admission. Sometimes you'll make a choice, and twenty hours later that ♥♥♥♥ will come back to bite you in the ♥♥♥, and it's not because you made the wrong choice, but because there wasn't a right choice. This game's not about finding the optimal path of least resistance. It's about moral ambiguity, and the story of an active participant in history, ♥♥♥♥-ups and all. This game made me step away from my keyboard a few times to think it over before I made my choices. I agonized over them sometimes, but in the end, no matter the outcome, it always felt right.

I will say this however: If you're just trying to get through this to play the next one, you don't have to. The Witcher 1 isn't a blank slate either, so no matter which one you start playing, you'll feel like you only know part of the story. And if you insist, but just can't take an 80-hour game, just play it on easy so you can get through it quick and see what happens. That's where the Witcher does its best work. The story.

reviewText:
When it comes to action rpg/adventure games - which is easily my favorite genre - the two games I've played for the longest in my entire life were Diablo II and The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. I love games like The Witcher.

If you are into rpgs, adventuring, doing quests, killing monsters and extracting their body parts to craft different potions, challeging gameplay, and dialogue options, then get yourself in on the Witcher action!

The aesthetics are very well done, with lots of detail in the environment. During dialogue scenes, you can enjoy dynamic characters that will move and express their emotions (quite the opposite of Morrowin'd static, unmoving faces). Your character, Geralt, can also be a playboy (if you take him down the right dialogue paths), romancing many different characters. During the sex scenes, a card (with absolutely no value except that you can look at it again by checking the person's biography) with the woman in a revealing position will cover the dream-like sequence (which seems to be very similar for every person).

The music is pretty good, and the effects of skills and powers are great - my favorite being the cateye potion, which gives you the very useful ability of nightvision.

The story is pretty good, and the game is content-heavy with lore for anyone wanting more immersion into the Witcher universe. You can switch from a third-person perspective to a more top-down style camera if that suits you better. The game takes place exclusively in the castle city of Vizima, with Geralt wandering to surrounding areas for missions (but always returning to the main hub of Vizima).

The controls are fairly easy to get used to, especially if you are familiar with rpgs in the vein of Dragon Age and Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. You queue your skills/actions, and timing is very important - properly pressing the attack button (mouse click) will allow you to continue your atack combos. There are three different Witcher stances you can use - fast, group, and heavy. These implement a sort of rock-paper-scissors style mechanic, where quick enemies are more susceptible to fast attacks; tanky blockers are bested by heavy strikes; and weak mobs fall to your group attack quickly.

The learning curve is moderate to difficult, there is a lot to do in the Witcher world. I am currently playing on the hardest difficulty, and I recommend you do so if you want the full experience. In this mode, crafting potions to buff Geralt (ex: higher criticals, poison damage, or increased endurance/stamina) is essential - you WILL die repeatedly if you do not utilize the potion mechanic. In the lower difficulties, you can get away with ignoring this aspect of the game. The tutorial questline is very good at helping you learn every aspect of the game, from skinning monsters to crafting potions to leveling up your skills.

Crafting potions is an entire game in itself - whenever you defeat an opponent, you can usually loot their bodies (and taking some crafting ingredients in the process). There are books you can read (usually by purchasing them from vendors or finding them) that will allow you to extract a wider variety of crafting components from your kills. Many of the higher-tier potions require you to use rarer ingredients (which in turn require you to find the specific book that will teach you how to extract it).

Enemies will also drop their weapons, and you can pick these up if you like (although they are usually weaker than Geralt's equipment). Geralt can equip his standard Witcher silver sword (strong against mythical creatures) or his steel sword (strong against normal humans), and two other secondary weapons (I have a large axe that has a bonus against shields, and a small axe that does extra piercing damage).

Inventory management is very good thanks to the auto-arrange feature.

Geralt's interacttion with the environment is amazing. You can talk to most NPCs, some of which will accept gifts from you in exchange for (sometimes) special items. Later, you will find dice and can play a dice version of poker (which is extremely addicting). There is an entire questline where you can challenge different-tiered opponents until you become a professional. You can trade with characters/vendors, and you can even try to romance some if given the opportunity. You can even engage in drinking contests with certain individuals - winning (sometimes) special prizes if they tap out first. There is also a fight club in the taverns.

One of my favorite things about this game is the time-delayed consequences of your actions - usually not becoming evident until much later in the game. Also, there is no concrete karma" system (ex: renegade/paragon
date: or jedi/sith) for your actions - so you are encouraged to play the game and make decisions how you actually would
recommended: rather than relying on a black-and-white karma system.\n\nThere is an abundance of side missions for you to do
hoursPlayed: and this is recommended to maximize your leveling potential. The upgrade tree is very good

reviewText: Picked up The Witcher a long time ago, but due to compatibility issues I never gave it much of a go. As the launch of W3 approached I figured I should do the whole series. I'm a story guy, so reports of lacklustre combat didn't bother me (it's not great, in truth) and the story more than makes up for it. Took me 45 hours start to finish. I would certainly recommend the game for those that want a good RPG. It's starting to show its age graphically, however because the story and characters are so good, you forget you're playing a 10 year old game. Lots of choices to make, taking you down a different path depending on your decisions and an adult themed collection of in-game cards aquirable upon coupling with the various characters. I can honestly say I enjoyed the game world so much that upon finishing, I looked for the books the game is based on, and started installing the sequel.

Story: 9/10
The Witcher's strongest feature. The narrative in the game holds your attention due to its morally gray character motivations as well as its well realized central protagonist. Modern RPGs are plagued with the fetch either an angel halo for the gods or a dead baby for the demons" choice system. The Witcher's choices are very gray at first glance
date: and for much of the game character motives are wonderfully opaque. This leads to real thought
hoursPlayed: for decisions you've made.\nThe other issue RPGs have is the "build your own protagonist" system a la Skyrim. This becomes tantamount to there being NO protagonist but instead a soulless fetch quest runner who gets to witness the other ACTUAL character fulfill their motivations. Geralt is his own man

reviewText: Welp to Start off despite what Steam says I played of this game I played about 20 hours of it offline do to my internet being destroyed. So this game atleast for me took about 45 hours give or take and you can probably do it in less. Would I reccommend the game for its story 100% but there are some issues that the game has regardless of its amazing story. First I'll start off with the positives story, setting, lore and all of that are so fasinating. The dialogue in this game can also be so golden and this game has a cast of very memorable characters. Now the downsides the combat is really basic and not really unique. The sword play is a combo system based on timing your clicks and not really special and trying to use abilities in tandem feels really clunky so combat is nothing that special. Also sometimes in certain sections of the game it just starts performing poorly, I will be running this game 60 fps maxed out and everythings fine then suddenly in certain areas and sections of the game everything goes to ♥♥♥♥. Now despite its faults this is still a fantastic game story wise and is extremely compelling, I would find time escaping me as I would play this game as oh ♥♥♥♥ suddenly its like 2 or 3 am and I need to go to bed. Also I just remembered this the crafting system in the game is really unique but only on the alchemy side when your making potions besides that I never needed to make bombs and never saw a use for them and also I just got so much grease and such from drops that I hardly ever had to make any.\n11/10 story like woah\n7/10 Overall

reviewText:
The Witcher is a story-driven action RPG. I'll admit that it took me a few tries to get into this game; this was part due to its different combat system. The Witcher’s combat isn't about blindly clicking the mouse, but instead requires timing to effectively chain a number of progressively stronger attacks together (sort of a really cut down fighter’s style of combos) as well as picking the right fighting style for the situation.
The equippable item system in Witcher is rather basic. If you’re looking for a Diabloesce game with an exorbitant amount of different weapons and armour, you won’t find it here. Fundamentally, you’ll use 2 unique swords and a set of armour. These items have a couple of upgrades as the game progresses, but for the most part, that’s all you’ll use.
The real item aspect of the Witcher is with its “power ups”. You’ll spend most of your time looting corpses and objects in search of crafting components to create potions, bombs and weapon boosts.
I thought the levelling system in the game could have been a little more interesting. Every time you level up, you get certain kinds of skill points to allocate to a skill tree. These points mostly just influence your character’s numbers (extra damage, extra resistances, extra chances to dodge) and don’t necessarily feel noticeable. You do get to chain more attacks as you level those skills, but perhaps some completely new abilities as you level to show your advancement may help?
The visuals were quite good, especially given the game came out in 2008. I especially liked the look of the combat as well as the visual effect on the weapons when “power up” items were applied to them. My biggest con for this game however was the repetitive character models. You will run into the same NPCs and enemies models a LOT.
Lastly, the story. The Witcher story was quite enjoyable with a rather hefty length to it. The game offers you a lot of opportunities to make decisions, but ultimately the game’s outcome will be the same. We’re offer 3 endings, based on a few key decisions, with different set dressings along the way based on other decisions. In saying that though, I did get invested in the story and had wished some of my decisions had had different outcomes in the story.
Overall, a very enjoyable game and I’m looking forward to playing the sequel, Witcher 2. Should you so choose, your save file from Witcher 1 can be imported into Witcher 2, so that your decisions  and equipment following you, allowing it to really feel like it’s a continuation of your character.
It you enjoy your stored driven RPG and have the time and patients to invest into a long story, I’d recommend giving The Witcher a try.

reviewText:
The Witcher is a story-driven action RPG. I'll admit that it took me a few tries to get into this game; this was part due to its different combat system. The Witcher’s combat isn't about blindly clicking the mouse, but instead requires timing to effectively chain a number of progressively stronger attacks together (sort of a really cut down fighter’s style of combos) as well as picking the right fighting style for the situation.
The equippable item system in Witcher is rather basic. If you’re looking for a Diabloesce game with an exorbitant amount of different weapons and armour, you won’t find it here. Fundamentally, you’ll use 2 unique swords and a set of armour. These items have a couple of upgrades as the game progresses, but for the most part, that’s all you’ll use.
The real item aspect of the Witcher is with its “power ups”. You’ll spend most of your time looting corpses and objects in search of crafting components to create potions, bombs and weapon boosts.
I thought the levelling system in the game could have been a little more interesting. Every time you level up, you get certain kinds of skill points to allocate to a skill tree. These points mostly just influence your character’s numbers (extra damage, extra resistances, extra chances to dodge) and don’t necessarily feel noticeable. You do get to chain more attacks as you level those skills, but perhaps some completely new abilities as you level to show your advancement may help?
The visuals were quite good, especially given the game came out in 2008. I especially liked the look of the combat as well as the visual effect on the weapons when “power up” items were applied to them. My biggest con for this game however was the repetitive character models. You will run into the same NPCs and enemies models a LOT.
Lastly, the story. The Witcher story was quite enjoyable with a rather hefty length to it. The game offers you a lot of opportunities to make decisions, but ultimately the game’s outcome will be the same. We’re offer 3 endings, based on a few key decisions, with different set dressings along the way based on other decisions. In saying that though, I did get invested in the story and had wished some of my decisions had had different outcomes in the story.
Overall, a very enjoyable game and I’m looking forward to playing the sequel, Witcher 2. Should you so choose, your save file from Witcher 1 can be imported into Witcher 2, so that your decisions  and equipment following you, allowing it to really feel like it’s a continuation of your character.
It you enjoy your stored driven RPG and have the time and patients to invest into a long story, I’d recommend giving The Witcher a try.
