reviewText:
As a person who knows the story very well, and read all the novels, I feel that my impression of the game is twofold. On the one hand, the game is great, it has amazing dialogues, storyline, quests, lore, characters, etc. - it is obvious that PC Project did a great job. However, I highly advise to read the actual novel prior to playing this game, or many things might be totally unclear to you (the entire story of 7 books is very long though, and it is understandable that not many people have enough time to do it) or at least, try to find the Polish movie of 2000 (which is a crap though).

Unfortunately, the Witcher series are not that popular as Game of Thrones in North America, which becomes a problem because majority of people know nothing of this Universe and what had happened in the world prior to this game - and there were lots of things happening. I ll try to summarize everything in one sentence - a war had happened which united the Northern Kingdoms against an army of Southerners, the war was won - at the same time, there is a huge Elven rebellion happening, and of course, Witchers, the mystique organization which had sworn to protect humans from evil, is slowly disapepearing from the public. Geralt is among the last ones to survive.

Of course, devs did a good job explain everything from the start, but still the game has enormous amount of flashbacks which test your knowledge of the series, and in order to enjoy the game in full extent it is advisable to know what the heck is going on at least.

On the other hand, there is some element of uncertainty. A. Sapkowski, the original author of the series, made it clear several years ago that the story of Witcher did not end in his books yet, and if I understand it correctly - he is working on another book currently. In this way, I am just very confused whether how this game as well as Witcher 2 and 3, would fit into Universe. But this is a question which cannot be answered yet. For now, I give a strong A + to the game.

9 / 10

reviewText:
I am recommending this game with a few caveats. It's 2016 as I write this, and I refuse to play The Witcher 3 until I beat the previous two, and we all know that I have to play The Witcher 3... I HAVE TO! I am now 50-something hours into this beast and I'm not gonna lie to you, it is a ♥♥♥♥ing grind sometimes. Collect ten of these, bring this to there, grind money, farm herbs... It reminds me of some of the worst parts of WoW at its low points. There's also The Witcher's graphics, which, in its day, probably would have melted my face off like the ark of the covenant, but now they're pretty rough. The gameplay is equally dated and suffers from some truely bizarre implementation choices (Parapa the Rappa style combat?). It takes grit to get through it sometimes.

But despite all of that, there is a seed of greatness taking root here. Even by modern standards, the original Witcher has an incredible depth to its mechanics (flawed as they are), and a richness of character and storytelling that is woefully lacking in most games (even modern RPGs). There's no black and white moral scale here to define your actions. No need to max out your good or evil points to get this or that ability. Just choices. You make choices and you live with the consequences. That's the price of admission. Sometimes you'll make a choice, and twenty hours later that ♥♥♥♥ will come back to bite you in the ♥♥♥, and it's not because you made the wrong choice, but because there wasn't a right choice. This game's not about finding the optimal path of least resistance. It's about moral ambiguity, and the story of an active participant in history, ♥♥♥♥-ups and all. This game made me step away from my keyboard a few times to think it over before I made my choices. I agonized over them sometimes, but in the end, no matter the outcome, it always felt right.

I will say this however: If you're just trying to get through this to play the next one, you don't have to. The Witcher 1 isn't a blank slate either, so no matter which one you start playing, you'll feel like you only know part of the story. And if you insist, but just can't take an 80-hour game, just play it on easy so you can get through it quick and see what happens. That's where the Witcher does its best work. The story.

reviewText:
When it comes to action rpg/adventure games - which is easily my favorite genre - the two games I've played for the longest in my entire life were Diablo II and The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. I love games like The Witcher.

If you are into rpgs, adventuring, doing quests, killing monsters and extracting their body parts to craft different potions, challeging gameplay, and dialogue options, then get yourself in on the Witcher action!

The aesthetics are very well done, with lots of detail in the environment. During dialogue scenes, you can enjoy dynamic characters that will move and express their emotions (quite the opposite of Morrowin'd static, unmoving faces). Your character, Geralt, can also be a playboy (if you take him down the right dialogue paths), romancing many different characters. During the sex scenes, a card (with absolutely no value except that you can look at it again by checking the person's biography) with the woman in a revealing position will cover the dream-like sequence (which seems to be very similar for every person).

The music is pretty good, and the effects of skills and powers are great - my favorite being the cateye potion, which gives you the very useful ability of nightvision.

The story is pretty good, and the game is content-heavy with lore for anyone wanting more immersion into the Witcher universe. You can switch from a third-person perspective to a more top-down style camera if that suits you better. The game takes place exclusively in the castle city of Vizima, with Geralt wandering to surrounding areas for missions (but always returning to the main hub of Vizima).

The controls are fairly easy to get used to, especially if you are familiar with rpgs in the vein of Dragon Age and Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. You queue your skills/actions, and timing is very important - properly pressing the attack button (mouse click) will allow you to continue your atack combos. There are three different Witcher stances you can use - fast, group, and heavy. These implement a sort of rock-paper-scissors style mechanic, where quick enemies are more susceptible to fast attacks; tanky blockers are bested by heavy strikes; and weak mobs fall to your group attack quickly.

The learning curve is moderate to difficult, there is a lot to do in the Witcher world. I am currently playing on the hardest difficulty, and I recommend you do so if you want the full experience. In this mode, crafting potions to buff Geralt (ex: higher criticals, poison damage, or increased endurance/stamina) is essential - you WILL die repeatedly if you do not utilize the potion mechanic. In the lower difficulties, you can get away with ignoring this aspect of the game. The tutorial questline is very good at helping you learn every aspect of the game, from skinning monsters to crafting potions to leveling up your skills.

Crafting potions is an entire game in itself - whenever you defeat an opponent, you can usually loot their bodies (and taking some crafting ingredients in the process). There are books you can read (usually by purchasing them from vendors or finding them) that will allow you to extract a wider variety of crafting components from your kills. Many of the higher-tier potions require you to use rarer ingredients (which in turn require you to find the specific book that will teach you how to extract it).

Enemies will also drop their weapons, and you can pick these up if you like (although they are usually weaker than Geralt's equipment). Geralt can equip his standard Witcher silver sword (strong against mythical creatures) or his steel sword (strong against normal humans), and two other secondary weapons (I have a large axe that has a bonus against shields, and a small axe that does extra piercing damage).

Inventory management is very good thanks to the auto-arrange feature.

Geralt's interacttion with the environment is amazing. You can talk to most NPCs, some of which will accept gifts from you in exchange for (sometimes) special items. Later, you will find dice and can play a dice version of poker (which is extremely addicting). There is an entire questline where you can challenge different-tiered opponents until you become a professional. You can trade with characters/vendors, and you can even try to romance some if given the opportunity. You can even engage in drinking contests with certain individuals - winning (sometimes) special prizes if they tap out first. There is also a fight club in the taverns.

One of my favorite things about this game is the time-delayed consequences of your actions - usually not becoming evident until much later in the game. Also, there is no concrete karma" system (ex: renegade/paragon
date: or jedi/sith) for your actions - so you are encouraged to play the game and make decisions how you actually would
recommended: rather than relying on a black-and-white karma system.\n\nThere is an abundance of side missions for you to do
hoursPlayed: and this is recommended to maximize your leveling potential. The upgrade tree is very good
voteText: as you can invest points into either silver or steel sword - and specific forms within those; overall agility

reviewText:
The Witcher is an amazing Role-Playing game and the first entry to the popular franchise involving Geralt of Rivia, a monster slayer, more specifically, a witcher.

In The Witcher, the main gameplay focuses on combat and dialogue. Talking with the characters is a huge part in completing the numerous main and side quests. What you say matters, as each possible line might cause something different, it can mean a mass slaughtering or a problem solved in a peaceful way. Certain characters will help you or not depending on what desicions you made in the past.

It is known that combat is a weak part of the game, but it is not as bad as people make it out to be. Sure, it is not the same as the later Witchers' but it isn't that awful. When you put the cursor over an enemy, it will turn into a sword, that's when you can attack. Clicking mid-action stops the attack. Clicking when the sword is flaming starts a chain of attacks. Depending on what type of enemy you are fighting, you will use a different sword. The steel sword is used against humans, elves, dwarfs, dogs, while the silver one is used against monsters. Three fighting styles are available, depending on if the enemy is a strong or light type, or you are fighting a group of enemies.

Witchers have the ability to use signs - they provide specials powers such as telecinetic blasts, shields, making enemies your allies and more. As the game progresses you will find them all. Geralt can brew potions - large part of the game, especially if you are playing on a higher difficulity, make oil - to enhance his swords and deal more damage, and craft bombs.

Story is also amazing, but considering the game is made after a book, it's not surprising. People say that the second and third game's stories are more important, though, so what do I know.

Along with the game, you get adventures, I guess they could be called free DLC. They are small main quests, not tied to the story. An adventure editor also comes with them.

Overall, this is a must play for RPG fans out there and considering it goes as low as an euro during sales, it's a great deal as the game can provide over 30 hours of fun.

reviewText:
The Witcher was released almost nine years ago and regularly goes on sale for a couple of dollars or less. The question for today's player isn't so much if the game is worth your money but rather if it's worth your time. The answer, in true Witcher fashion, isn't entirely black and white.

The game for me was, overall, enjoyable.  The combat system is unique, and regardless of it's mixed reviews, I found it to be a serviceable and even somewhat cool RPG combat system. The finishers tend to get a bit repetitive but add a nice, and gruesome, touch. Although the main story isn't incredibly epic, the decisions that you make along the way feel like they are, and have a significant impact on certain characters fates.  I particularly enjoyed the economic system in the early to mid-game, when you actually feel like you need to put in work to earn those Orens, because everyone has their hand in your coin pouch, and everything you want to accomplish has a price.  Unfortunately this fades towards the end of the game as there simply isn't anything left to buy and no one left to bribe. Graphically the game doesn't look bad, it’s got its hiccups sure, but nothing that interferes with playability.

Geralt, despite being one of the ugliest human beings I've ever seen in this particular game, somehow manages to slay more women than monsters--quite an accomplishment considering aptitude for his profession.  The dude simply can't miss, and it's undeniably entertaining to see just how many naughty cards you can collect.  It also adds an interesting layer of complexity to Geralt's ongoing romance with a certain red-haired sorceress.  No matter how serious their relationship tries to become, the White Wolf simply can't stop banging other women.  Relationships are hard. Players unfamiliar with the series may find Geralt's character at first take to be bland, dull, or flat out boring.  However, once you begin to understand his complexities, his sarcastic and cynical nature, and his convictions, you'll surely come to appreciate this incredibly rich and interesting character as so many others have.

The world map by today's standards is pretty small but the game easily has 50 hours of content.  This translates into A TON of backtracking.  By the end of Chapter II I was more familiar with the streets of Vizima than my own neighborhood, which is great because the mini-map is zoomed in way too far and makes navigation a little frustrating.  I often found myself needing to open the world map just to find a house that was actually ten feet away.  NPCs carry on with their daily lives, which at first seems pretty cool, until you're searching for one for twenty minutes because he's not getting drunk at the inn for once and he's slipped off his magical RPG quest-tracking bracelet.  Because Geralt's a Witcher, monster contracts play a role in the game, unfortunately most of them are simply kill X number of Y monster and turn in their eyes/teeth/skins/whatever.  One of them even has Geralt collecting flowers...??! That's like hiring Agent 47 to assassinate a weed in your garden.

The recycling of NPC textures is somewhat distracting but doesn't ruin the experience.  Expect though, to see the same fat guy, skinny guy, and half-naked hooker models reused over and over throughout your adventure. The game also suffers painfully from a gear shortage.  I found myself using the same armor and two swords throughout most of my adventure. The difficulty on normal is average, as it should be, but does have some frustrating moments.  Too many enemy groups have to ability to stun-lock Geralt, causing him to stagger like a drunken derelict as you helplessly pound on your peripherals for way longer than any doctor recommends.

Mini-games are present; dice poker has you playing poker by rolling dice instead of drawing cards and is ok at first but you'll quickly get tired of it.  There are also fist fights which pit Geralt against an array of fighters of supposedly increasing difficulty, however, once you figure out the somewhat wonky fighting mechanics you'll be able to beat the crap out of even the strongest opponents with virtually no effort. Overall, the mini-games felt like they could have been left out and, much like me at a party, no one would have even noticed they weren’t there.

Now, we circle back to our original question; is The Witcher worth your time in 2016?  As a fan of The Witcher 3 I certainly found it to be worth mine.  Despite it's age and other concerns, the game is still pretty darn good.  If you're completely new to the series it would seem like the obvious place to start but I would actually recommend starting with the Witcher 3 and working back to this one. Many may not agree, but the game is 50 hours long and sometimes feels like a slog. If you're not already invested in these stories and characters, and the lore of this world, playing this game first, as a contemporary player, could potentially turn you off to the entire franchise and that would be a shame.  If you're a fan of the Witcher 3, like me, and want to experience more content from this world, then there's no reason not to give this game a spin.

Final score: 7/10 RECOMMENDED.

Thank you for reading and good hunting

reviewText:
After tying up every lose ends in the first of the witcher series and nearly logging in 50 hours into this game, I can say that I`m mentally exhausted. I didn`t expect that a game released 7 years ago would achieve such a feat. CD Projekt did a wonderful job creating a deep, rich and satisfying story that reminded me that sometimes having an excellent story is as important as having fantastic gameplay mechanics. Albeit the magnificent tale, the witcher falls short of delivering in its combat system, sometimes being painfully buggy during the heat of battle. Power-ups frequently doesn`t work and some spells are way more overpowered than others. In the end however, the absorbing nature of the game keeps pulling me back for more. I hope the witcher 2 would solve the above issues and it`ll be splendid.

Pros:
- Undeniably good story
- Lots of quests to take on, sometimes overwhelmed by what to do next and often lead astray
- Good alchemy and skill tree system
- So many chats to chat
- Not so terrible graphics for a 2007 game

Cons:
- Combat mechanics are buggy, some skills are OP, early game is tough for hard mode
- Tutorial are thin and for the first few hours, prepare to be confused
- Small variety of weapons and armors

Hope you enjoyed reading it as much as I enjoyed writing this.

This game deserves a 9/10.

reviewText:
The Witcher is one of my favorite series, with that said the game hasn't aged well. Voice acting is horrible, animations are awful and the combat system is boring. You will spend most of your time running from 1 location to the other doing fetch quests or just aimlessly wandering around until you find a solution to a quest.
The issues I had with the combat is that it resembles a clicker game. After chapter 2 you will find yourself dying over and over in certain missions because they decided that you can go 1 v 10 against a room full of enemies. I wouldn't mind this if it weren't for a total stunlock when the enemies surround you, at which point death is certain.
For newcomers I would recommend downloading these mods to make the experience somewhat better:
- The witcher texturen mod - improves textures for environments and objects
- The witcher hi res character models - improves textures for characters
- Item Stacking and Equipment Slots Mod - you will need this if you don't plan on organising your inventory every 5 minutes
- Faster Movement Mod - this mod increases your movement speed by 25% but can be changed to even more. The game makes you run around, alot. The issue here is that the maps are pretty big and if you plan on doing sidequests you will be running all over the place and the default movement speed is lousy. If you don't want to uninstall after 1 hour pick this up.

If you came only for the story you will be satisfied, but only if you don't mind all the shortcomings. An added bonus is that you can import your choices into The Witcher 2.

reviewText:
The Witcher is a fantastic rpg released back in 2007. It is a sequel to a series of fantasy novels centering around it's protagonist, Geralt of Rivia. In this game, after his apparent death in the novels. He awakes with amnesia and no recollection of his death nor the people in his life. After that he is launched on a quest of revenge as he remembers who he is.

One of the finest aspects of the Witcher is how it's quests are designed. You are never shown the consequences of your actions immediately. Instead, in later chapters of the game you see the results of your choices. This was done to prevent players simply reloading and not accepting the consequences of their actions. As a result your actions really do feel like they have weight, and it's rare to see this executed properly in a game.

There are of course negative aspects of the Witcher. Most people cite it's combat as the biggest drawback of the game. I'm inclined to agree, as I initially stopped playing just before finishing the prologue. My advice is to push on past the prologue as you start to really get into the game during it's first chapter. Eventually you will fall inlove with this game and it's timing based combat.

reviewText:
In this first chapter of the trilogy based on the novels by Andrzej Sapkowski, you play as Geralt of Rivia, the witcher (monster hunter with supernatural abilities).

The game came out in 2007 and was later re-released in 2008 in an Enhanced Edition. From a technical standpoint, it's nothing jaw-dropping but it holds up more than well to this day. The story of the game is easily it's strongest point, with a long and compelling story, varied and colorful cast and tons of side missions.

The combat can be played in two ways: with an over-the-top camera with mouse controls or an over-the-shoulder mouse'n'keyboard controls. While it is unintuitive at the beginning, through time you'll get better and better and feel really good about yourself. There is a vast array of weapons, mutagens and potions to improve your abilities. The only problem is that the difficulty is kind of unfair even at the easiest setting.

Overall, this is a great beginning for a fantasy trilogy that will go down as one of the best ones.

Story: 10
Graphics: 8
Gameplay: 9
Challenge: 8
Sound: 8
Replayability: 6

ENJOYMENT: 8.5
FRUSTRATION: 6

I strongly recommend installing The Rise of the White Wolf"

reviewText:
The Witcher, the story originally written as a book by Polish writer Andrzej Sapkowski in 1992, feel old? No. This game expands the main storyline very, very well. Good job Poland, you have created something that no one will forget. One of the best RPGs ever made.
STORY:
The story, as I said before, expands the storyline from the books, and adds something more to it, the game starts with the witcher, Geralt, that looses his memory, is taken to Kael Morhen, the ancient witcher castle, which is now half destroyed and almost empty. The prologue and then the first chapters of the game may seem a little boring and slow, but after it game takes on regarding what decisions you make.
GAMEPLAY:
For new players, gameplay in prologue is the main thing why the most players stop playing after 10 minutes of the game. The combat system is based on the right timing clicking, so that confuses most people. Geralt can carry up to 3 swords and 1 optional dagger, another small weapon or torch. Also witcher spells" called signs are introduced

reviewText:
I was introduced to the Witcher series by a friend, and I am glad to say that purchasing this game was one of the best decisions I have made. The Witcher is quite possibly the pinnacle of Action/RPG games.

The game boasts an old-timey combat system based on stringing together specifically timed attacks into combos that works very well for this game. The types of attack combinations performed are based on specific combat styles that players must switch between based on the situations they find themselves in. Geralt, the main character, can progressively strengthen his combat capabilities by leveling up and spending talent points to lengthen his combos, increase his damage output, increase his alchemical abilities, and much more. The character development aspect of this game is very well done in that it allows players to upgrade Geralt more or less to their own specific play style based on how they wish to spend their talent points. The storyline of this game is really quite remarkable, and its nonlinearity allows players to explore the open world that they are in to their hearts' desire. The quality of the storyline is only compounded by the game's morality system, for which it has recieved much praise. Morality in the Witcher is not a cleanly-cut black-and-white morality system, and the heavy presence of moral gray-areas allow players to judge morality for themselves rather than on the game's own terms and face the consequences of the decisions they make.

All in all, the Witcher is a fantastic Action/RPG game, and everyone who is a fan of these types of games will not be dissapointed by it. It is absolutely worth buying even at full price, and is a marvellous and refreshing gaming experience for fans of the Action/RPG gaming genre.

reviewText:
The Witcher - is one of the few modern (well, almost modern) 3rd person RPGs that really do their job properly. This game is not about levelling your character or killing tons of creatures with one swing of your sword. It's about playing o role - a ROLE playing game.

You play as a witcher, a mutant that kills beasts. It's based on famous books series by Andrzej Sapkowski. Since you are a mutant, not every person likes you. More of that, you always have to chose how to behave, whos side to take.

It's a first game by polish studio CD Project RED, so it's not brilliant, but you immediately forget about all it's cons when you start playing because a rare game can get you suck a real roleplay experience, such dark fantasy world, where everything is corruted, dark and still people survive and see bright things.

reviewText:
I'll start by stating that The Witcher is a great game.A great game that has its good and bad.So let me review what I think is most important of any game ,the story,The gameplay and graphics.

The witcher has a great story.The story starts really slow and dull until you reach the third chapter.By reaching the third chapter,things get really interesting.The problem is,you get dragged through 3 long boring chapters,with unnecessary main missions and some little odd ones.But in the end,the story stands out with its unique choices.

The gamplay is the game's weakness.I say this with full confident due to alot of flows in the combat system,AI,boss   fights,difficulty, glitches and so more.The combat system is good idea the was executed badly due to random stunning you get even if you were away from enemies or they had no chance of hitting you,random bleeding,randomly beating an enemy with one hit even it is impossible,or even being forced to use a normal sword to what is clearly not a human enemy.The AI is bad,you may say it is justifiable for a game that came out in 2007 but i think they could have done better or at least updated it.The friends who company you die easily and completely useless.The enemy AI is odd and sometimes standing far away stops them from attacking you or simply running around them in circles.What really annoy me in some of the bosses is how scripted the fighting is.You could check The spider queen fight.It is unbelievable how scripted it was.The difficulty spike from easy to normal is ridiculous.I highly recommend playing it easy if you cant take dying from an OP enemy or a boss.Finally,the gliches.Three are alot of them.Sometimes you cant use any sign,even if you reloaded the game.Sometimes,by walking around a cretin area,you can avoid a main story fight!!some keys refuses to respond like your mouses right click or the saving button.Using a sigh has no effect on enemies who are close to you and this glitch can cause you troubles.I could take along times mentioning these glitches.


The Witcher has a good graphics.The game obviously aged well.Even playing it without mods didn't make it old .Though you cant play it with SlI enabled without problems for some reason.

In conclousion,The witcher is great game with alot of problems.I recommend it only in easy difficulty and for a really really patient gamer.

reviewText:
The Witcher Enhanced Edition is a game that you have to spend some time getting into. My first impression was that the game had suppen frame-drops and clunky controls and did not like it at all in the beginning. However, it only took me about 2-3 hours to fall in love with this game.

What I liked most about this game was the story. It was one of the reasons I got so addicted to the game. The clunky controls did not bother me, because the story was so interesting and unique. I also really liked the Level system. It had alot of variation, for example upgrading your magic skills, health, making your combat moves look smoother and even make Geralt do backflips!

One of the things most people hate the most is the combat. You click on the enemy and look at Geralt do some swings and wait until the sword (mouse pointer) have flames on it and then click again for a 2nd combo. I personally had no problem with this type of combat and actually enjoyed it a lot. But I understand why people dislike it, but it really depends on your style and what you like.

The biggest complains I have with this game is the clunky controls and sudden game crashes (which can be really annoying if you don't save the game often). But I've heard that the game auto-saves if you press f5, which I didn't know until after I finished the game and started on The Witcher 2.

Overall, I think this a very good RPG game from an amazing franshise that I recommend for those who like dark, sexy and actionpacked RPGs, and  I therefore give this game a strong 8/10.

reviewText:
A fantastic game, worthy of all praise!

Packs a gripping story that ticks all the right boxes for an Action-RPG. Your choices have real consequence - and choices are generally complex and not of a binary 'good v bad' nature. In The Witcher you need to think on your feet, about your identity, your friends and the fate of Temeria. The story is similarly complex, filled with mystery, love and treachery.

A fantastic entry in the series. I can't way to carry over my progress into Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings.

reviewText: Having finally beaten the Witcher tonight, I feel I must make my oppinions known. The Witcher is sadly overlooked by most mainstream gamers. RPG focus is stolen by games such as Skyrim, Fallout, and Dragon age. All of those are great games, but the Witcher is something special.  The witcher gives you many moral choices that are difficult to decide. They actually make a huge difference in the outcome of the game as well. The game gives you somewhat of a blank slate, and forces you to choose what you believe in, who you  trust, and what is right or wrong.  The Witcher has tons of nudity, so don't play this near young ones. A good playthrough will take 40 hours or so, but will allow you the ability to import your save file into the Witcher 2. It is also worth mentioning that the modding community has made many wonderful mods for this game. I was playing with some HD texture mods, and some interface re-works. These make the game a joy to play even this many years after its creation. If you are an RPG fan, you owe it to yourself to sit down and recount the tales from Geralt of Rivia. The Witcher.

reviewText:
A fantastic game, worthy of all praise!

Packs a gripping story that ticks all the right boxes for an Action-RPG. Your choices have real consequence - and choices are generally complex and not of a binary 'good v bad' nature. In The Witcher you need to think on your feet, about your identity, your friends and the fate of Temeria. The story is similarly complex, filled with mystery, love and treachery.

A fantastic entry in the series. I can't way to carry over my progress into Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings.

reviewText:
This is a good narrative rpg, but a god awful video game. The combat is terrible, the character progression is terrible, the inventory management is terrible, the game's auto save system is completely sentient and makes its own damn rules, Act III comes with a hearty helping of cpu usage issues with a nice side of micro-stutter, oh and bad voice acting combined with robotic facial animations makes Geralt being hit on and getting laid constantly extremely awkward and uncomfortable. BUT, even with all that, play this game. The stories are well written and have numerous outcomes based entirely on the way you do things. Choices are rarely laid out in front of you and always have a significant impact later in the game.

Recommendation: this game is everything that Bioware RPGs wishes they were, but the low budget and (probable)inexperience of CDProjektRed in 2007 hides the good behind multiple layers of clunk and awkward.

Side Note: Assassin of Kings succeeds in virtually every area that this game fails, so it's an obvious choice over this game, but they allow you to import a save with all your choices, so I'd say The Witcher is worth suffering through to get the best experience out of the sequel, even if you hate its guts.

reviewText:
Finally! After putting it off twice now, I've finally beat this long, incredible game. I know some people will say it wasn't too long but I tried to get as much out of it as I could. Anyway, on to the review, in this game you play as Geralt of Rivia. A witcher, which is basically a human that was trained from birth to hunt monsters and remove curses. Also, as part of the process, the witcher finally earns his name sake by completeing the trial of the grasses which is a long process involving taking mutagens which (if the human survives) transforms him into a mutant which gives him faster reflexes, better vision, and all that good stuff but at the cost of infertility.
At the beginning you discover Geralt has lost his memory and is wounded but winds up on the steps of Khear Moren (sp?), basically the school and home for the Witchers. There he is nursed back to health by his fellow witchers and Triss Merigold, a sorcess and love interest. Just as Geralt is getting back on his feet, a group of thugs assisted by a couple powerful mages attack the castle. After a short battle, wherein you choose to help fight the monster that the mage brought with them or if you choose to go to the laboratory with Triss to stop them from stealing the Witchers secrets, you decide to split up to different corners of the world to find your groups lost secrets and to seek revenge on the group that attacked and so begins the game.
The game is kind of hard to explain on paper, but I'll try my best. First off, combat isn't like in most games... when fighting anything you have to click on the target and Geralt will start attacking in a predetermined manner whereas during the attack your sword icon will light up between yellow and orange then go back to gray, during this time you have to click on the target again during the yellow/orange phase to follow through with a four step combo, the longer you prolong the combo the more damage that is done ending in a finisher stage which deals the most damage. Also, depending on your target, there is a lot of prep that goes into the fight before actually fighting. You have to consider the target, is it human or monster? If its human you must use your steel weapon or sword. If its monster, you must use your witchers silver sword, something you get in the second chapter of the game (there are 4 chapters and an epilogue). Then once you determine between human or monster, you must figure out if the target is a large target or small target because large targets require a strong attack stance and small targets require a small attack stance... usually. You can quickly switch between the three stances (the third being a group stance which is pretty good during almost all fights and covers both large and small targets) by pausing the game and selecting the stance, then resuming. Most of the time its all trial and error, if you attack a small framed guy and he seems to be dodging or parrying your attacks, switch to the strong and that'll drop him. Sometimes, if you get good enough and your skills improve, you can use most any attack stance on any size target with greater result (small/singular target + strong stance with improved skills = 2 hit kill). Then there is the oils and stones and such... some stones can imbue your swords with different effects for short periods of time, just apply before battle because he actually has to apply it. Same goes for oils, but the oils do different things, like making a target bleed more, causing more pain (causes the target to attack slower/move slower), and then theres the oils for different kinds of monsters. Like necrophage oil, causes more damage to ghosts. Insectoid oil, causes more damage to insect like monsters. And theres an oil that causes the blades to do more damage to dragons and such, the list goes on and that alone is complex.
You also have magic that you learn by visiting stones scattered about the world. They give you powers like Aard, which is like force push from SW or just a strong burst of wind. Theres 5 total I believe but I only ever used Aard because when you level it up you can knock down multiple targets or even if you want to just quickly move through an area and theres one monster/human blocking the path you can sometimes stun the target which leaves them open for an instant melee kill. I also forgot to mention above that, just like the instant kills, fighting in general is very quick and visceral. Lots of blood flies around, wounds will appear, sometimes heads will roll but its a very satisfying part of the game. Just as with the magic and melee, as you progress through the game and level up, you gain points in the form of tokens which varies as you get higer level. These tokens are bronze, silver and gold and the skills you can buy follow the same form of scale being bronze is basic and gold is the best.
As you progress through the game you will encounter tons of characters, often ones you can interact with. Some will give you missions, others will just say a few set things and continue about their business. As mentioned earlier, there is decision making opportunities that present themselves several times in the game and will always effect the game later down the road. So pick your decisions wisely and don't listen to the inner dialogue or other characters when they push you to pick a side... its totally possible (and apparently the prefered choice) to play the neutral part.
The game can get tedious though... as one could imagine from my intro, this is the third time I've played it and actually the first time of successfully completing it. There are a few dull parts in the game, which I liken to the Song of Ice and Fire series from Martin, if you're familiar with them... when its boring its really dull but when it gets good its so damn good! Try to break up the dull parts by doing monster contracts which you can find at the local taverns, right outside on the billboard. Each chapter usually has like 6 different contracts posted and they'll always fetch decent money. But as for the story, probably one of the best games I've played and I really look forward to the next chapter in the series as the ending is left pretty open no matter what ending you get (there are 3 different kinds). I highly recommend this game just go in with an open mind and try to remember to think things through if you're stuck or try different strategies, because thats what this game is all about.

reviewText:
The good:
A gritty take on High Fantasy Land which shows us the brutality of an actually medieval world, fleshed out characters with a clear hint an author was behind them and the story. The usage of folklore to create an archaic kind of fantasy magic and monsters is something I only remember from Darklands (an ancient RPG in medieval Germany where all folklore and hexes were equally true). Nice interconnection of event, nice ambiguity in the choices. Graphics are dated but still able to convey the story and atmosphere very well.

The bad:
I was finishing this to get my Witcher fix for Witcher 3 and the controls are jarring and some elements of the combat like stun chains (which can happen to you without anything to do about it) can be plain frustrating. The inventory is kind of a mess. Sometimes you run around the same areas the xth time and I'd really liked a fast travel because this world has none of the emergent stories a real open world RPG has. By today's standards the world tiles are really small and you still need tons of time to traverse them.

The ambigious:
To some the preset of the character Geralt (the main protagonist of the novels) might feel a bit limiting but it helps to create a deeper story as the character of Geralt is defined to a large degree. Themes are mature with excessive romance to the point of self parody but also a pretty dark world where none is 100% good.

Conclusion:
This is primarily a story driven game and I only played it for that. In that sense they could have thrown out plenty of the decisions (which do not have very deep impact on the story anyway) and it would still be interesting to see the relations of fleshed out characters and a well established world.

I would recommend the story, but cannot blame anyone taking shortcuts on the gameplay.

reviewText:
I don't know, I have conflicted feelings on this game. First, I kinda sorta loved the main character Gerald since he has my style sense of humour. Second, there is a consistent story going on and it reveals to be both well tought and told. The graphics are good enough to satisfy my greed on good graphics. (Well, they are a bit better than that ^^') and the unique way that Gerald makes potions according to the recipies he follows, gather the necessary ingredients in order to brew the potions is really satisfactory.

YET

Combat sucks. Guys, I am not joking. It basically relies on how good you click on your mouse. Annoying. Yet since it is a story fueled game, I don't think it is that necessary to have a complicated combat option in the game.

It would have been nice of course but hey, this is the very first game of the series and as I understand the firm was not a professional one back then. You are excused staff, be better next time you hear? (They must have since I hear the following games ARE amazing in every aspect.)

Well, I enjoyed the game so far and I think I will keep enjoying it on my one and only off day.

I hope you find my commentary helpful.

Chicka kisses.

reviewText:
One question, one answer.

Should you play this game before the other two or just skip it?

Yes, play it, or well, it’s up to you. It will set basis for you knowledge in the universe of The Witcher, and even though it’s a long game (for me 77 hours my first play trough), I felt it was totally worth it, and very rewarding. The game plays different than in The Witcher 2, instead on focusing on skill play, it focuses on tactics like alchemy and oil coating, etc. It may not sound good, but it is pretty fun. Plus the tactical knowledge carries over to the following games, letting you play I higher difficulties than before.
The length of the game was in my opinion perfect, it didn’t felt repetitive, or like being obligated to do chores. Heck, I got bored of Alien Isolation halfway through the entire game which only lasted about 15 hours. I just don’t play games for long, still, this is my second most played game of all time, I would never had tough!!!
For the price you get all this content, it is just a crime not to get, less than $2 for in sale sure.
The only thing you have to get pass to is the gameplay, if you come from The Witcher 2 like me, don’t quit in the introduction because of the combat. Stick with it for a little and you’ll get used to is very soon, as I already say, the gameplay is a little different, but it’s still fun.

Thank you CD Projekt for this Masterpiece, I’m a fan of the series now.

reviewText: Not the prettiest game, not the greatest combat system (igni), terrible lip syncing and some pretty poor character models, very weird story telling system (at first), and lots and lots of walking simulator. But somehow, it's one of the most compelling and overall best games I've ever played.\n\nIf you're having a hard time getting into it, just play through the first act and see how you feel. It took me a while to get invested, but at one point in class I was just like, Dang
date: I really wish I was playing the Witcher right now
recommended:
went home, and played for 50 hours over the course of a week or so.

I'm honestly not sure what makes this game so great. None of the individual aspects really stand out, with the exception of maybe the story. However, the story telling method just thrusts you into the game, characters discuss events that you haven't experienced like you're supposed to know what's going on, and there are a lot of unanswered questions by the end.

But somehow, it all ties together to make one inredible game. Probably the best RPG I've ever played.

reviewText:
This is a good narrative rpg, but a god awful video game. The combat is terrible, the character progression is terrible, the inventory management is terrible, the game's auto save system is completely sentient and makes its own damn rules, Act III comes with a hearty helping of cpu usage issues with a nice side of micro-stutter, oh and bad voice acting combined with robotic facial animations makes Geralt being hit on and getting laid constantly extremely awkward and uncomfortable. BUT, even with all that, play this game. The stories are well written and have numerous outcomes based entirely on the way you do things. Choices are rarely laid out in front of you and always have a significant impact later in the game.

Recommendation: this game is everything that Bioware RPGs wishes they were, but the low budget and (probable)inexperience of CDProjektRed in 2007 hides the good behind multiple layers of clunk and awkward.

Side Note: Assassin of Kings succeeds in virtually every area that this game fails, so it's an obvious choice over this game, but they allow you to import a save with all your choices, so I'd say The Witcher is worth suffering through to get the best experience out of the sequel, even if you hate its guts.

reviewText:
Finally! After putting it off twice now, I've finally beat this long, incredible game. I know some people will say it wasn't too long but I tried to get as much out of it as I could. Anyway, on to the review, in this game you play as Geralt of Rivia. A witcher, which is basically a human that was trained from birth to hunt monsters and remove curses. Also, as part of the process, the witcher finally earns his name sake by completeing the trial of the grasses which is a long process involving taking mutagens which (if the human survives) transforms him into a mutant which gives him faster reflexes, better vision, and all that good stuff but at the cost of infertility.
At the beginning you discover Geralt has lost his memory and is wounded but winds up on the steps of Khear Moren (sp?), basically the school and home for the Witchers. There he is nursed back to health by his fellow witchers and Triss Merigold, a sorcess and love interest. Just as Geralt is getting back on his feet, a group of thugs assisted by a couple powerful mages attack the castle. After a short battle, wherein you choose to help fight the monster that the mage brought with them or if you choose to go to the laboratory with Triss to stop them from stealing the Witchers secrets, you decide to split up to different corners of the world to find your groups lost secrets and to seek revenge on the group that attacked and so begins the game.
The game is kind of hard to explain on paper, but I'll try my best. First off, combat isn't like in most games... when fighting anything you have to click on the target and Geralt will start attacking in a predetermined manner whereas during the attack your sword icon will light up between yellow and orange then go back to gray, during this time you have to click on the target again during the yellow/orange phase to follow through with a four step combo, the longer you prolong the combo the more damage that is done ending in a finisher stage which deals the most damage. Also, depending on your target, there is a lot of prep that goes into the fight before actually fighting. You have to consider the target, is it human or monster? If its human you must use your steel weapon or sword. If its monster, you must use your witchers silver sword, something you get in the second chapter of the game (there are 4 chapters and an epilogue). Then once you determine between human or monster, you must figure out if the target is a large target or small target because large targets require a strong attack stance and small targets require a small attack stance... usually. You can quickly switch between the three stances (the third being a group stance which is pretty good during almost all fights and covers both large and small targets) by pausing the game and selecting the stance, then resuming. Most of the time its all trial and error, if you attack a small framed guy and he seems to be dodging or parrying your attacks, switch to the strong and that'll drop him. Sometimes, if you get good enough and your skills improve, you can use most any attack stance on any size target with greater result (small/singular target + strong stance with improved skills = 2 hit kill). Then there is the oils and stones and such... some stones can imbue your swords with different effects for short periods of time, just apply before battle because he actually has to apply it. Same goes for oils, but the oils do different things, like making a target bleed more, causing more pain (causes the target to attack slower/move slower), and then theres the oils for different kinds of monsters. Like necrophage oil, causes more damage to ghosts. Insectoid oil, causes more damage to insect like monsters. And theres an oil that causes the blades to do more damage to dragons and such, the list goes on and that alone is complex.
You also have magic that you learn by visiting stones scattered about the world. They give you powers like Aard, which is like force push from SW or just a strong burst of wind. Theres 5 total I believe but I only ever used Aard because when you level it up you can knock down multiple targets or even if you want to just quickly move through an area and theres one monster/human blocking the path you can sometimes stun the target which leaves them open for an instant melee kill. I also forgot to mention above that, just like the instant kills, fighting in general is very quick and visceral. Lots of blood flies around, wounds will appear, sometimes heads will roll but its a very satisfying part of the game. Just as with the magic and melee, as you progress through the game and level up, you gain points in the form of tokens which varies as you get higer level. These tokens are bronze, silver and gold and the skills you can buy follow the same form of scale being bronze is basic and gold is the best.
As you progress through the game you will encounter tons of characters, often ones you can interact with. Some will give you missions, others will just say a few set things and continue about their business. As mentioned earlier, there is decision making opportunities that present themselves several times in the game and will always effect the game later down the road. So pick your decisions wisely and don't listen to the inner dialogue or other characters when they push you to pick a side... its totally possible (and apparently the prefered choice) to play the neutral part.
The game can get tedious though... as one could imagine from my intro, this is the third time I've played it and actually the first time of successfully completing it. There are a few dull parts in the game, which I liken to the Song of Ice and Fire series from Martin, if you're familiar with them... when its boring its really dull but when it gets good its so damn good! Try to break up the dull parts by doing monster contracts which you can find at the local taverns, right outside on the billboard. Each chapter usually has like 6 different contracts posted and they'll always fetch decent money. But as for the story, probably one of the best games I've played and I really look forward to the next chapter in the series as the ending is left pretty open no matter what ending you get (there are 3 different kinds). I highly recommend this game just go in with an open mind and try to remember to think things through if you're stuck or try different strategies, because thats what this game is all about.

reviewText:
The good:
A gritty take on High Fantasy Land which shows us the brutality of an actually medieval world, fleshed out characters with a clear hint an author was behind them and the story. The usage of folklore to create an archaic kind of fantasy magic and monsters is something I only remember from Darklands (an ancient RPG in medieval Germany where all folklore and hexes were equally true). Nice interconnection of event, nice ambiguity in the choices. Graphics are dated but still able to convey the story and atmosphere very well.

The bad:
I was finishing this to get my Witcher fix for Witcher 3 and the controls are jarring and some elements of the combat like stun chains (which can happen to you without anything to do about it) can be plain frustrating. The inventory is kind of a mess. Sometimes you run around the same areas the xth time and I'd really liked a fast travel because this world has none of the emergent stories a real open world RPG has. By today's standards the world tiles are really small and you still need tons of time to traverse them.

The ambigious:
To some the preset of the character Geralt (the main protagonist of the novels) might feel a bit limiting but it helps to create a deeper story as the character of Geralt is defined to a large degree. Themes are mature with excessive romance to the point of self parody but also a pretty dark world where none is 100% good.

Conclusion:
This is primarily a story driven game and I only played it for that. In that sense they could have thrown out plenty of the decisions (which do not have very deep impact on the story anyway) and it would still be interesting to see the relations of fleshed out characters and a well established world.

I would recommend the story, but cannot blame anyone taking shortcuts on the gameplay.

reviewText:
I don't know, I have conflicted feelings on this game. First, I kinda sorta loved the main character Gerald since he has my style sense of humour. Second, there is a consistent story going on and it reveals to be both well tought and told. The graphics are good enough to satisfy my greed on good graphics. (Well, they are a bit better than that ^^') and the unique way that Gerald makes potions according to the recipies he follows, gather the necessary ingredients in order to brew the potions is really satisfactory.

YET

Combat sucks. Guys, I am not joking. It basically relies on how good you click on your mouse. Annoying. Yet since it is a story fueled game, I don't think it is that necessary to have a complicated combat option in the game.

It would have been nice of course but hey, this is the very first game of the series and as I understand the firm was not a professional one back then. You are excused staff, be better next time you hear? (They must have since I hear the following games ARE amazing in every aspect.)

Well, I enjoyed the game so far and I think I will keep enjoying it on my one and only off day.

I hope you find my commentary helpful.

Chicka kisses.
^.^

reviewText:
A fantastic game, worthy of all praise!

Packs a gripping story that ticks all the right boxes for an Action-RPG. Your choices have real consequence - and choices are generally complex and not of a binary 'good v bad' nature. In The Witcher you need to think on your feet, about your identity, your friends and the fate of Temeria. The story is similarly complex, filled with mystery, love and treachery.

A fantastic entry in the series. I can't way to carry over my progress into Witcher 2: Assassin of Kings.

reviewText:
The Witcher Enhanced Edition is a game that you have to spend some time getting into. My first impression was that the game had suppen frame-drops and clunky controls and did not like it at all in the beginning. However, it only took me about 2-3 hours to fall in love with this game.

What I liked most about this game was the story. It was one of the reasons I got so addicted to the game. The clunky controls did not bother me, because the story was so interesting and unique. I also really liked the Level system. It had alot of variation, for example upgrading your magic skills, health, making your combat moves look smoother and even make Geralt do backflips!

One of the things most people hate the most is the combat. You click on the enemy and look at Geralt do some swings and wait until the sword (mouse pointer) have flames on it and then click again for a 2nd combo. I personally had no problem with this type of combat and actually enjoyed it a lot. But I understand why people dislike it, but it really depends on your style and what you like.

The biggest complains I have with this game is the clunky controls and sudden game crashes (which can be really annoying if you don't save the game often). But I've heard that the game auto-saves if you press f5, which I didn't know until after I finished the game and started on The Witcher 2.

Overall, I think this a very good RPG game from an amazing franshise that I recommend for those who like dark, sexy and actionpacked RPGs, and  I therefore give this game a strong 8/10.

reviewText:
I'm a recent Witcher fan. After watching Angry Joe's video over the Witcher 2, I've been curious over this entire franchise for a while. Last Christmas, my parents got me several of the Witcher novels and my then girlfriend bought me one of the comics in trade. Since then I've loved the franchise, if just for the books alone.

This game however, while not as great as the books I've read thus far, is still great and show off the potential the developers have. I haven't played the other Witcher games yet but I'm excited to. While the combat, character models and English voice acting is wonky, the story, world and unique alchemy and daytime system really make this game work. Once you get into this game, you'll begin to trully roleplay as Geralt. You will fully understand why Geralt in the books is written the way he is and you as the player will sympathize with, or in my case agree with, his choices and world view.

For those wanting a unique and extremely different fantasy experience, look no further than the agressively, yet lovably, Polish Witcher.

WARNING: Play this before you play the second one

The second game is a lot better, especially the fighting system. In the first it's not that exciting. But it is complex, you have sword types, oil coatings, potions, bombs and magic. You'll need to use those elements in Normal to Hard dificulties.

The story is complex, with diferent outcomes to diferent decisions, it involves a lot of mature content. And the glossary gives you a lot of lore, information about characters and enemies.

The first game is a nice introduction to the series. The second is a better overral game and we can only expect the thir is going to be epic in scale.

Buy it when on sale. It's a little old game, but it's good.

reviewText: Holds up very well and forever refuses to pay off shallow investments.  It's a complex game with a combat apparatus unfairly rejected by many but the savvy rpg veteran will be handsomely rewarded when meeting the game on it's terms.  Don't be so quick to dismiss the first Witcher game in hopes of fast-tracking your enjoyment of newer ones, especially if time is no constraint.  There are many reasons why you may find it to actually be the best in the series!

reviewText: The Witcher combines spectacular action and an intriguing storyline. You are a Witcher, a warrior who has been trained to fight since childhood, subjected to mutations and trials that have transformed you. You earn a living killing monsters, and are a member of a brotherhood founded long ago to protect people from werewolves, the undead, and a host of other beasts. The game's visual style and physics systems shoot for a high-powered blend of brutal action, complex RPG options and character configuration, and sweeping storytelling.

reviewText:
I would like to say The Witcher is the first serious RPG I had played ( played Lord of The Rings Online because of friends ) , and I am really entertained by the vast lore.

I suggest you play this game for the plot, as the battle system seems quite awkward. It's just a matter of clicking at the right moments instead of button mashing, and perhaps brewing HP regen potion are essential.
Also, it is strongly reccomended to often save your games, because mine kept crashing for unknown reasons. :/

Plot wise, it introduces you to the theme of The Witcher, and the quantity of adventures in this game are large,  which I like ! I had fun watching the medallion vibrates for suspected monsters that disguise as humans.

TLDR, it's worth to buy, especially when it's 85% off ( which is my case )  :3 .

reviewText:
Note: No doubt you've noticed my hours but I played this with the FCR & Rise of the White Wolf mods installed, which Steam apparently doesn't recognise. Total playtime at the time of writing this is about 40 hours, give or take.

Provided that you can stick out the massive grind at the start, you'll get hooked quite easily on this. Design, in most respects, holds itself quite well even after all these years and I do recommend playing this if you're planning to get into the Witcher series or have played the other games.

- The story is quite good though fairly limited in location and the amount of sex avaliable will leave you wondering why Geralt hasn't had a heart attack from all that action.
- The developer's decision to use the world of Andrzej Sapkowski's beloved books was a brilliant idea and they've done a superb job of recreating the characters, atmosphere and setting.
- The combat and voice acting are the weaker parts of the game with the latter being often irritating to listen to.
- Nevertheless, this is still an extraordinary achievement for it's time and surprisingly addictive.

The Witcher: Enhanced Edition certainly isn't perfect but the debut for CD Projekt Red remains one of the most immersive RPGs to date and a worthy entry in the series and your library.

reviewText: This game is hauntingly atmospheric with a soundtrack and visuals that tend to be too beautiful to have any business belonging to such a dark storyline. I still can't believe that CD Projekt Red pulled all of this off with a heavily modified Aurora engine, which goes all the way back to 2002's Neverwinter Nights. Though the combat can feel strange and jittery at some points, the overall gameplay is very fun and the storyline is extremely well-crafted. An impressive selection of choices and consequences make this worth a few replays as well to take Geralt on a different path. To me, this game along with its sequel both play more like action/adventure titles with RPG elements rather than pure RPGs, but they do it extremely well. Recommended.

reviewText: Отличная игра! Боевая система оказалась на удивление оригинальной. Да и вообще вся анимация боев заслуживает исключительно лестных отзывов. Стоит заметить, что в повседневной деятельности Геральт активно использует два меча (стальной – против людей, серебряный – против чудовищ) и три боевых стиля, открывающие в сочетании с пятью магическими знаками огромный простор тактических возможностей. Все ведьмачьи атрибуты, стили и магические знаки разделены на пять витков развития, каждый из которых связан с сопряженными способностями. Три вида талантов (бронзовые, серебряные и золотые) не позволят игроку прокачать что-то одно и навсегда забыть об остальном – хочешь не хочешь, а основы выучить придется. reviewText: This game is hauntingly atmospheric with a soundtrack and visuals that tend to be too beautiful to have any business belonging to such a dark storyline. I still can't believe that CD Projekt Red pulled all of this off with a heavily modified Aurora engine, which goes all the way back to 2002's Neverwinter Nights. Though the combat can feel strange and jittery at some points, the overall gameplay is very fun and the storyline is extremely well-crafted. An impressive selection of choices and consequences make this worth a few replays as well to take Geralt on a different path. To me, this game along with its sequel both play more like action/adventure titles with RPG elements rather than pure RPGs, but they do it extremely well. Recommended.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Witcher is a captivating series based on a series of Polish books. It took some time for the series to gain momentum, but this games sequel was a resounding success and the third and final game is set to be the greatest game of all time.

If you can get past the prologue and the combat system you'll begin to really love this game.
I was committed to completing this game and I had a lot of trouble getting started, I nearly gave up on this game at that point. The game has very bad mechanic but it will grow on you with continued use, and these mechanics have divided audiences between both hating the game and loving it. Once you've adapted to these mechanics, you can emerse yourself in the story and you really will love this respectably long game - it will hype you for the sequel and the sequels sequel prior to its release.

The decisions made in the game will affect the plot throughout the entire trilogy, so make sure you choose the moral choices you'd actually choose in the situation, otherwise you could play the entire trilogy to a particular moral style.

It's one of the longer games I've played and I normally don't really like role playing games, and I would play this again without question.

reviewText: This has one of the slowest starts I've ever seen in an RPG game, first of all the game begins with terrible combat, an uninteresting story, and sketchy graphics. Everytime you move there's another cutscene or jump to boring dialog. This wraps up in an hour or two however and then the game really opens up. Eventually you get used to the combat and it starts improving as you unlock new skills and weapons, the main storyline still feels pretty irrelevant but there's a huge amount of side content to keep you busy. It does start out as one of the worst games I've played for a while and almost prompted me to uninstall it, however after sticking through it, I now think it's one of the best games to come out in recent years.

reviewText:
My only experience of any witcher games was The Witcher 2 on xbox 360 a while ago and I never really got into it enough to finish.
So, when I saw the witcher games on sale recently I grabbed them, why not? they where really cheap.

I do not regret it one bit.

I decided to start from the first, because the best place to begin any epic tale is from the beginning.

Expecting a mediocre experience and clunky gameplay (I'd heard the second had improved drastically on combat) I went ahead and started a game.

Oh man, what a game, I'm only 5 hours into it as i write this review and i'm already sucked right into the story. This game does it's story better than most recent games I have played. The characters are extremely likeable and the voice acting is pretty good for the most part.

The game itself looks very nice visually, true it isn't the best graphics but it looks extremely well done given it's age.

The combat is a bit limited, however, this doesn't make it any less fun. While you are limited to the three fighting styles there are ways to string together combos and use magic too. The game cleverly forces you to use strategy in your fights which also mixes things up a bit. If you're expecting to hack and slash your way through I suggest you play on easy. If you try that on normal or hard you'll find yourself face down in the dirt.

Finding things is extremely easy as you can mark each quest or item you're trying to find on your map. A mini map in the top corner constantly points you in the right direction too.

I'm pleasantly surprised so far....... and i expect to be pleasantly surprised some more as I play through this story.

I definately recommend this game to everyone, the history and lore behind the game alone is so expansive, it's as if this whole other world actually exists.

Pick it up, give it a try, become intregued and emotionally involved in Geralts story. You wont regret it.

reviewText: I've never listened about the Witcher saga until 2015 when I saw TW3 was about to be released. I felt curiosity for it and after looking for info I liked it: ahuge RPG and with a very rich story. Although I had in mind the idea of buying it I didn't do it at the end 'cause a couple of months before there were steam sales on The Witcher 1 and 2 :D 90% ones so I immediately grabbed my wallet and paid the few bucks they costed.\nI loved this first one for ALL of it. The story, the characters you come across with, the music, the combat system (not dynamic or stressful at all, just clicking at the right moment, cast some Signs and swallowing a couple of potions. The toxicity factor also was extremely interesting and realistic (?) ). The plot twists, the all-the-same-NPCs, their realistic quotes, the books and the info you could get from them to learn more about the Witcher's world, the side quests, the witcher contracts that made me feel like a real witcher though were boring and poorly paid, ALL OF IT was completely worth and enjoyable and I do not regret playing it. Just buy it and be astonished.

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nThis has to be one of the best games I have ever played. I played it just last year, and in spite of the outdated graphical quality, it pretty much blew my mind. It took me roughly forty hours to finish the game (and I left out maybe a third of the side-quests) and it was a forty hours well-spent. Not only is it a fully compelling story, the characters are well-developed and fleshed-out throughout. The gameplay is remiscent of Dragon Age-meets-rhythm-game, but it works incredibly well. And what honestly is the most impressive to me is the soundtracking. I haven't played a game before or since this one that is soundtracked as well. Overall, I'd say 10/10 for anyone who enjoys RPGs, or any kind of fantasy game.

reviewText:
I'll keep this short and sweet because I think the majority of people that played The Witcher did so in order to get some backstory for preperation for The Witcher 2 & 3, thats just how I feel about it because I suppose thats the purpose of my playthrough because what it comes down to is the game alone isn't very delightful on its own but its not terrible either. I suggest playing it before going at The Witcher 2 so you have an idea of whats going on, plus it will make The Witcher two more enjoyable.

The Witcher is a great RPG with anywhere from 50-80 hours of gameplay depending on how you want to take it along with choices to make that effect the story down the road and the game doesn't hold your hand. Minus chapters 2 and 3 (due to their watered down quests that seem to go on forever and the boring environments) out of 5 chapters along with a Prologue and a Epilogue the game is pretty fun and entertaining.

Combat in the game turns off a lot of people right off the bat, I say give it a chance because once you get used to it you'll feel more intune to the way it works and you possibly may even enjoy it. For those who want to take on the hard difficulty, prepare to possibly rage due to a few boss fights and a few other silly encounters that are just plain unfair, unfourtunatly.

The voice acting in the game is decent but often times laughable and the animations minus some of the combat animations are just plain silly. Character models are reused frequently as well throughout the game which was just plain lazy. All in all I'd say pick this one up even if its for a quick runthrough if you are planning on playing The Witcher 2 and 3.

reviewText: So I never got to finish this game and I fear I won't. First off it doesn't have cloud save. I played for 8 hours only to have a faulty hdd resulting in reinstalling windows. I lost my saves and had to restart the game. Now today it happened again, except this time windows got corrupted and rendered my hdd useless without a reformat. So my review is only based on the 8 hours I managed to squeeze out of the game. The graphics are okay (game is rather old) The combat system is so weird. It took a couple of hours before I understood exactly how to use it. As you level up, you unlock more combo  moves and it becomes pretty fun. The story is hands down my favorite out of any game I have ever played (I also own consoles) It sucks that I won't get to finish the game as I don't really see myself spending another 8 hours doing the exact same ♥♥♥♥ I have done twice before. Highly recommend this. Now it's time to move to Witcher 2. I will review that once I finish it :)

reviewText: This is a damn excellent game. The stat system is not mind-boggling, the action is tight and awesome looking, and the graphics are good. What really makes this stand out is the story. You will make many choices in this game, and very rarely will there be any 'right' or 'wrong' choice - they're all in shades of gray, just like in real life. The consequences of your actions aren't always immediate and may have a big impact, so it makes these decisions really hard and involving. Just the story alone is worth shelling out $20 for. This game is worth $50, at least. Definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
The Witcher is a RPG game set in a dark fantasy universe. The atmosphere resembles the dark middle ages, where poverty, war and disease has struck down on the denizens of this world.

You are Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher who is both respected and despised for his line of work. Your profession is to dispose of creatures of the dark, demons and foul creatures by means of spell, sword and alchemy.
However, in the beginning of the game you are struck by amnesia and thus your past is unknown to you. This is a central plot in the game, as you will carve your own destiney in the god-forsaken universe of the Witcher. Choosing between right and wrong is difficult, if not impossible, as every decision you make will depend on your own moral code. There are no heroes, no real villains, as everyone is fighting for themselves and characters are thus grey" - they all contain classically noble character traits and "evil" traits. Consequently
date: the demons you are sent to kill can appear more humane than the village priest who would rather have you kill seemingly innocent people.\n\nThe game is highly recommendable
recommended: despite its now outdated graphics. The quality of the game experience is enjoyable
hoursPlayed: and several replays is almost inevitable if you want to know what would have happened if you just had sided with the other faction.. or none at all."

reviewText:
A unique role-playing game that is a rarity these days. Developed by a Polish company and is based on the book with the same title written by a Polish author called Andrzej Sapkowski. You play as Geralt, a mutant hunter who is specialised in fighting and slaying monsters. At the beginning of Geralt's story he does not remember much - he's found unconscious and is taken to the witchers' hideout. The establishment, then, is attacked by a group of bandits known as the Salamander - although defending the castle is a success, the witchers are unable to stop the bandits from stealing their precious mutagens. Geralt and his fellow witchers, therefore, set out to find where the gang is hiding and of course to take back what is rightfully theirs.

Some notable elements that characterises Witcher and makes it different from other RPGs:

--- Controlling Geralt is very easy. The game offers you several camera perspectives, in fact, even the input device can be changed: focus can be on the mouse solely or you can use the combination of the keyboard and mouse - whichever is your preference.

--- During combat timing is very important. The game being hack-and-slash requires you to hit enemies several times. This, Geralt does automatically, but following the hit of his blade you can have a follow-up click with your mouse - if your timing is perfect Geralt does make a follow-up cut which is stronger and deadlier. In addition to this the game employs 3 combat styles. Larger enemies require the strong style: Geralt carefully times each hit and while they are slower they result in a heavier slash. Faster enemies simply avoid your attacks but changing to the fast style enables you to hit them. And if your are surrounded you need to use the group style.

--- Beside the styles and the timing you should be careful with the material your weapon is made of. While steel-made swords are perfect against human beings and some of the monsters you encounter there are many supernatural beings in the Witcher's world you can only wound with a silver-made sword.

And here come those that made me like the game a lot:

--- Choices: Yes, yes, this is common. You decide to help or you simply let people die. Right? No! Witcher does not indicate what will happen once a decision is made. Unlike Mass Effect, here there are no indicators and nobody tells you whether it is good or bad what you'll attempt to do. In certain cases both decisions you can make will result in the death of someone - you need to decide which is better" or you simply need to pick A) so that in your next playthrough you can go with option B.

--- Alchemy: A very important part of the game! There are severals types of plants / herbs out there you need to collect. You can then use these at fireplaces to create potions that either make you stronger or grant you an extra ability (e.g. seeing in dark places). Interestingly
date: all of these poison Geralt to a certain degree - your toxicity level increases and eventually you need to rest or drink another potion that neutralises the adverse effect of these drinks. The more scrolls you find the more potions are available - you can also experiment if you have the time.\n\nIt should be noted that Geralt is mainly a warrior. You have some spells called signs but they are nothing special. So
recommended: in your next playthrough you cannot have a significantly different build - you can experiment
hoursPlayed: for sure
voteText: but the value lies in Witcher's world. And this world is huge. I like how the game starts filling up your Glossary - a menu similar to the codex in the Dragon Ages series containing all kinds of entries explaining the world to the gamer. Also
helpfulPercent: while fistfighting is rather easy and boring the drinking and dice-poker mini games are excellent and make the game quite funny!\n\nI finished the game in 50+ hours and pretty much completed everything I could. I read the game's wikia pages parallelly and found that I'd missed some missions and if I remember correctly the game has at least 2 endings. So there you go: over 100 hours and this is only for 8 bucks! In addition to this
