votesFunny: Witcher is a unique RPG. If you are fan of the genre and finished multiple playthroughs in Dragon Age then do head for the store page as this game must be in your basket!"

reviewText: I never planned to play this game, I watched a full playthrough and planned to start with W2. However this game was on sale for $2, so I bought both this and Witcher 2. Now I'm really glad I didn't skip this game because it's amazing.\n\nNow despite what everyone says, I personally don't think the combat's that bad. At first its really awkward and surprisingly easy but as you progress it does get more difficult and it does get more complex, especially once you start unlocking witcher signs. Basically, you click on an enemy to attack, and then the cursor on-screen turns into a flaming sword, you click. It's like a rhythm, and each style of fight (strong, fast, and group) requires a different rhythm" that you will eventually memorize. Overall controls are a bit odd

reviewText:
I recommend this for RPG fans.  This game has gathered some attention for some of the adult-themes in it, and while running around carousing is mildly amusing at first, it is the gameplay and the story that win out in the end.  After spending around 800 hours between Oblivion and Fallout 3, exploring every nook and cranny of those games, I just couldn't get into New Vegas and haven't bothered with Skyrim because they just seem like more of the same.  While I would have thought that to be a good thing, I think personally my RPG cravings were just ready to be immersed in something new.  Enter The Witcher:

While you don't get to choose a character or class in this game, the main character has his own qualities and abilities that make it unique.  The story in this game is compelling and there is a lot of entertaining detective work to do and choices you have to make to keep the game advancing. The characters have more depth than most games, quite possibly due to this being based on a novel—a medium where if the character development is lacking,...it just plain sucks.  For example, Geralt of Rivia, the main character, has a personality that is mostly  polite, cordial, and heroic at times, but depending on who he's talking to there is a sarcastic, snarky side, as well as a naughty side.  Rarely are characters in games given this much dimension.

By today's standards, the combat system is seems antiquated, but after you get used to it, it's fine.  It does the job and makes getting contracts to slay monsters for gold a fun and worthwhile profession.  The item pickups are not plentiful, and if you want a new weapon every 10 minutes, this isn't your game.  Honestly though, I found this aspect of it kind of refreshing, the upgrades seem well deserved and its kind of nice to not have to learn to use a new toy or ability every few minutes or keep looking at weapon specs all day trying to figure out which is better,...this way you can just keep playing. The alchemy on the other hand is one of the deeper aspects of the game, and it becomes a fun hobby as the game progresses.

My biggest gripes about this game, which are few, are how I was robbed of some of the mission completions.  For example, I escort an NPC to safety,...end of mission cutscene ensues, ...story to be continued later, but then the NPC randomly gets killed instead of being safely immune from danger,...and then there is no continuation on that plot because the NPC has perished.  Maybe I'm just too picky. This game reinforces the tried and true RPG mantra: save frequently, and make multiple saves.

A True masterpiece. A word of advice though

reviewText: This game is tricky to review. The story is fairly enjoyable, but the pacing and execution leaves much to be desired. Game mechanics-wise, the Witcher is a game riddled with bugs. I only regret not recording some of them, as they were incredibly amusing. The graphics are fairly good for their time, and improved upon more in the enhanced edition of the game. The art direction is pretty solid, and the music presentation is above average. If you can find the courage to take this game on despite its glaring flaws, it's worth a play. If not, I'd recommend a summary or a Let's Play series somewhere on YouTube to watch instead. That said, I'm still going to finish this game and prepare myself for the Witcher 2, which I've heard is infinitely better. 6/10

reviewText:
This is RPG nirvana. lots of varied, multi tiered tasks to accomplish along with a good amount of spicy cards to collect by bedding the natives.

The inventory management is awesome, and the alchemy is fun and exciting.

The combat takes some getting used to and if you play it on the hardest difficulty like i am, you are going to have to  get DAMN proficient at both timing as well as alchemy in order to defeat your foes.

The graphics arent amazing, but considering my old toaster, im actually relieved because i can play it at a fairly high level of detail albiet at a low resolution.

You should by this if you can appreciate fantastic storytelling and well voiced dialog with solid action systems and inventory management.

PS, you can play this in third person behind the back, or from a distance ala Dungeon Siege distance.

The story in this game is compelling and there is a lot of entertaining detective work to do and choices you have to make to keep the game advancing. The characters have more depth than most games, quite possibly due to this being based on a novel—a medium where if the character development is lacking,...it just plain sucks.  For example, Geralt of Rivia, the main character, has a personality that is mostly  polite, cordial, and heroic at times, but depending on who he's talking to there is a sarcastic, snarky side, as well as a naughty side.  Rarely are characters in games given this much dimension.

By today's standards, the combat system is seems antiquated, but after you get used to it, it's fine.  It does the job and makes getting contracts to slay monsters for gold a fun and worthwhile profession.  The item pickups are not plentiful, and if you want a new weapon every 10 minutes, this isn't your game.  Honestly though, I found this aspect of it kind of refreshing, the upgrades seem well deserved and its kind of nice to not have to learn to use a new toy or ability every few minutes or keep looking at weapon specs all day trying to figure out which is better,...this way you can just keep playing. The alchemy on the other hand is one of the deeper aspects of the game, and it becomes a fun hobby as the game progresses.

My biggest gripes about this game, which are few, are how I was robbed of some of the mission completions.  For example, I escort an NPC to safety,...end of mission cutscene ensues, ...story to be continued later, but then the NPC randomly gets killed instead of being safely immune from danger,...and then there is no continuation on that plot because the NPC has perished.  Maybe I'm just too picky. This game reinforces the tried and true RPG mantra: save frequently, and make multiple saves.

reviewText: It clearly apparent that a lot of what happens in The Witcher 1 is not very present in The Witcher 2, though, I'm sure more will come into play during the final chapter. That being said, this game starts out incredibly slow, and was much more difficult in the beginning than in the end. Aside from the imbalanced difficulty curve, I found myself barely fighting monsters apart from grinding. There's too much running errands, talking to people and running back and forth required in the story, and not nearly enough being a witcher. Although I felt the gameplay was a little stale, the biggest redeamer is the story. I really liked it! My advice, play this one on easy and try to breeze through it not only to get a feel for the story, but to create a more personal experience in the second two games as well. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is an extremely immersive game if you let it be. I didn't like it the first time I tried it because I didn't know what I was getting into. The second time however I feel in love. I will note a few things though:

The game as a whole is dull until Chapter 2

The game focuses on dialog and character development as much if not more than combat. If that turns you off I wouldn't recommend this game.

The combat is more repetitive than most games, but tolerable.

The game fails to give tutorials on how some mechanics/controls works. For instance: You hold down shift to see your mouse cursor to click on your signs. There I just saved you 5 minutes of google searching.

The dialog is really bad in the first chapter, but significantly raises in quality after that.

Closing Thoughts: If you like RPG's that are character driven this is the game for you. It may not have the open world of Witcher 3, but it is a very enjoyable experience.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's a lengthy adventure with a lot of choices to make. Although, the story is straight-forward, it has different elements that make it awesome. The combat mechanics are a bit of a letdown, but you have 3 different fighting styles and 5 powers too, so you can use a combination of that to improve your fighting experience. The alchemy and the universe - lore - are really amazing. You have a lot of detailed information about monsters, characters, missions and the world of Temeria, where the adventure of the Witcher is set. Although the graphics are outdated, and some npc's models recycled, the atmosphere is flawless, you can feel like you are Geralt. It has a good replay value, as there are 3 possible endings, which are determined by your choices, some of those, are made way before you see the consecuences, making you feel like an a**hole because of what you have done.

TL,DR:

+: 30+hrs of fun, nice graphics, immersive world and story, nice replay value
- : combat mechanics and some npc's recycled models. character animations are, sometimes, bad

reviewText:
A slow start might turn you off at first, but when you reach the second chapter you will be hooked. You'll encounter many well written and unique characters and the choices you make aren't black and white, you'll pretty much always have to choose the lesser evil.

Since the game is based on the Aurora engine (although with a completely rewritten render path) the graphics are dated but nonetheless nice to look at (especially with modded high-res textures and NVIDIA's AO or SweetFX).

I encountered a few crashes which I could solve by disabling autosave. So in case the game crashes to the desktop, try this first.

Overall, a great game and worth playing through.

reviewText:
Brilliant game, okay so some of the voice acting is a little ropey, but that doesn't mean the gameplay, or the storyline is bad, in fact it's probably one of the best single player RPG's I have played in a long time.  Surprisingly long quests, main story just keeps you coming back to complete it, potions are not bought, so no simple go to a store and buy everything you can find routine; you have to craft your potions, and prepare for anything that might happen.

Combat is interesting, different styles, and different swords, depending on what enemy you may face (extremely satisfying to take out 5-7 enemies in group combat, once you have got to a certain level and enhanced certain abilities), and defensive spells you can perform, from simply stunning/pushing the enemy away (and you can perform finishing moves, on stunned or knocked down enemies), induce fear and panic, turn an enemy into an ally, or simply setting enemies on fire, or casting a shield on yourself.

An overlooked game, that deserves to be in your list.

reviewText:
Short version: Great game with good story. Some unique elements that are mildly annoying, but add to realism/immersion. Morally grey decisions that cause game-lasting changes to various elements. 8.5/10

Great action RPG with some unique elements that separate it from the rest of it's genre. On the hard difficulty with the Extreme Immersion mod installed (which removes much of the HUD and other elements that make things feel more game-y), it presented a good challenge that never got too frustrating.

The combat system is a bit weird, but not bad once you get used to it. Instead of 1 click per attack, you click once and Geralt launched into a combo. Then you click again at the end of the combo to begin the next flurry. Proper timing leads to much better (and cooler looking) attacks.

Items/potions that restore chunks of health instantly are rare (I know of one). Instead, everything just makes your natural health regen faster. A bit annoying at times, but it does add a bit more realism to the game.

You can't gather alchemy ingredients if you don't know they exist. Again, a bit annoying, but adds realism. If you didn't know that a dog's liver was good for making potions, why would you ever take it out, right?

Finally, this is one of those RPGs that forces you to make various moral decisions (many of which will affect the later chapters in the game significantly, so choose wisely). However, unlike many games which hvae clear good" and "bad" choices
date: Witcher almost always makes you choose between two equally bad options. For example (spoilers incoming)
recommended: at one point you decide whether to support a village whose leaders are murderers
hoursPlayed: rapists

votesHelpful: but you must decide which to kill and which to save. That decision will affect various things for the remainder of the game (my advice: save the witch)."

reviewText: An amazing RPG that has just the right balance of old and new RPG mechanics. The only true flaw with the game is its numerous difficulty spikes, but in the grand scheme of things, this is forgiveable, as the rest of the game makes up for it. The combat blends together a tactical and action-focused approach, giving you a rush while retaining a D&D feel. The story is, in my opinion, highly original, with a monster slayer trying to cope with a changing world in which man can be a greater danger than beast. With this changing world, he too must change, learning to fight humans as well as monsters. In this ever-changing world, nothing is ever black and white.

reviewText: The Witcher is an amazing RPG that features some of the best storytelling and decision making I have ever seen. Everything decision, whether through actions or dialogue, carry weight and actively change the world around you. The game takes around 35-45 hours to complete, depending on how many side quests you do. There is a large amount of content in the game and warrants several playthroughs to see how different decisions change the course of the game. There are only two minor complaints that I have in this wonderful game. The first is the combat, while engaging, tended to be either a bit buggy or laggy, one of the two. The second complaint is a very minor complaint and partially is my fault for I have a short attention span. Some of the areas require a long walk to get from eachother, and you have to go back and forth quite a few times. I started to get bored of the long walks. Overall, the game is a very indepth RPG that defiently warrants several playthroughs. I highly recommend The Witcher to anyone who is a fan of RPGs.

reviewText:
Like Dragonage: Origins? Wish it were more focused on your character, with perhaps a little more premade story?

Enter The Witcher, a game adaptation of the short stories by Andrzej Sapkowski. You play as Geralt, a seemingly ordinary wandering warrior like you might have seen in any other adventure-RPG. But what you don't know about Geralt is...well, everything. Why? Suffice it to say this: not even Geralt knows, and it's up to you to help him find out. This is a game worth experiencing every detail as a surprise, and I won't spoil it for you.

I rate this game a 10/10 overall, 9/10 in the midst of more recent and up-to-date games. I rate its combat system an 8/10 only for glitch/anomaly reasons, otherwise it would've been 9/10. The game earns a 7/10 for solidity, it has a few annoying got to reload" glitches. Story: 10/10!"

reviewText: A dark, gothic, action RPG that is neck-deep in story. The action is flashy, however combat controls are obtuse; and when those clunky controls are paired with nearly brain-dead AI the action is underwhelming. The CRPG elements (item hoarding, inventory management, skill upgrades, etc) are very classic in nature - which is a hate-it or love-it affair. Likewise the presentation is something players will either hate or love - being a Central European RPG the story begins in medias res, there is a ton of dialogue, and the supporting characters are mostly ordinary folk with fairly rich back stories (as opposed to typical JRPGs which start at the beginning" of a story
recommended: and include flashy but hollow characters). The only issues holding this game back are the bugs and how poorly it performs (given its fairly dated graphics)."

reviewText: The Witcher is based on bookk series of author Andrzej Sapkowski. The game provides you the story of Geralt of Rivia, the beast slayer, deep into the medieval dark fantasy, discover the Salamander plan, conflict between species. Every moments and quest plots are really polished and reasonable decisions. With strong and complex RPG elements and point-and-click combat style (Combat styles, parry, dodge, signs, and alchemy), it reminded your old school feeling and very enjoyable. As enhanced edition, most of scripts and plots are rearranged to be more outstanding. In addition, the soundtracks are really great and well-fit.\nThe clipping issue during combat which cause Garalt's animation to be delayed and some glitch of inventory and quest tracker annoy me a little. However, they're just minor issues that I had encountered along the game, compared to overall execution. I have no doubt to say it's one of my RPG masterpiece all the time :)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I played through this game on easy and just listened in to the story for the most part. Even on easy the game was pretty challenging in parts, but not really due to the difficulty, but due to the very clunky combat system. I felt like I was fighting Geralt's glitchy moves more than I was the monsters at times. However, the game as a whole is pretty good. It's a decently long game and there's a bunch of quests. There's a bit too much backtracking for my tastes, particularly in Chapters 2 and 4 and the quests at times can feel arbitrary (go to person A, find person B, find out person B is dead and then have to talk to A. Go find person C so they can give you xp and orens). I can really only recommend this game if you really don't wanna feel left out for some of the characters in The Witcher 2 and you want to transfer your save file over to the 2nd game a la Mass Effect style. If the game's combat really turns you off that much, I'd honestly just find a wiki summary of the story and read that, though you'd be missing out on the pretty good character interaction.\n\nTL;DR: The game is clunky and feels very dated, but the main story is really enthralling and worth the trip if you care about the lore enough.

reviewText: The Witcher is a rough diamond.  Some of the translation to English results in odd conversations, some sections (mainly the swamp) are a bit of a grind, the combat can be repetitive and I had the occasional crash.  There are also some upgrades, signs and potions that are much more useful than others.\n\nAt times, too, it wasn't particularly clear about why you were doing what you were doing, or which speech option would get you which result.  But that's part of what makes The Witcher rewarding to play - it doesn't always hold your hand or telegraph every step in the plot.  The story is engrossing and, translation aside, the characters are great (even though most of the 'romances' are just Geralt saying let's bang
date: ok?") and you will quickly realise that you can't please everyone.  There are definitely a few tough choices to make.\n\nThe game takes a while to warm up so don't be put off by the slow start.  Also
recommended: if you're finding it difficult and dying a lot then - like me
hoursPlayed: initially - you're doing it wrong.  There are always potions
voteText: blade coatings
helpfulPercent: signs or upgrades that make beating particular enemies (and the game) much easier.  When in doubt: Swallow.\n\nWhile The Witcher lacks some of the polish (not Polish) of its AAA RPG cousins

reviewText: The Witcher is a rich RPG with a deep storyline and an old school styled combat mechanic in the style of KOTOR. I heared great things about this game for years I regret not playing it sooner. Geralt is a mysterious figure who's past is un certain, he's a member of a group of mutants called Witchers. Witchers are former humans who take mutagens to enhance their senses and fighting abilities. A Witcher is essentially a monster hunter who takes contracts to gain money. In the age that the game is set there are only a handful of Witchers left in the world and they are threatend by a force tha wants to destroy their way of life. This game forces you to make tough decisions and pulls ou into a murky world of politics every decision you make could have consequnces for Geralt down the road.

reviewText: It clearly apparent that a lot of what happens in The Witcher 1 is not very present in The Witcher 2, though, I'm sure more will come into play during the final chapter. That being said, this game starts out incredibly slow, and was much more difficult in the beginning than in the end. Aside from the imbalanced difficulty curve, I found myself barely fighting monsters apart from grinding. There's too much running errands, talking to people and running back and forth required in the story, and not nearly enough being a witcher. Although I felt the gameplay was a little stale, the biggest redeamer is the story. I really liked it! My advice, play this one on easy and try to breeze through it not only to get a feel for the story, but to create a more personal experience in the second two games as well. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Just finished the game so will give a brief description of my thoughts;
Pros; Graphics are very good considering how old it is.
Story, is very engaging, a little long winded at times but ultimately rewarding.
great character development and a real sense that your decisions really matter.
Huge amount of lore to find, this really adds a sense of immersion in the world.

Cons; Quests amount to a lot of running around and back and forth, basically fetch quests.
Combat is not bad once you get used to it but lacks weight and thus i would list it as a weak point.
Armour and weapons upgrades felt a little under developed, mabye that was just me though.
Overall i really enjoyed the game, particularily for the story but all the running around can get a bit tedious, especially in the early chapters. however, it is an excellent story that is worth sticking with to the end.

reviewText:
It is probably helpful for the reader if I compare The Witcher to Skyrim:

While Skyrim 'feels' like a computer game, a role playing game, and maybe could be described as having a slight theatrical vibe, playing The Witcher feels like reading a good book. It is very character- and story-focused. Geralt of Rivia is a very down-to-earth and likeable character and the game doesn't try to glorify or overly dramatize things. Those subtleties make the game feel even more believable and realistic than the medieval setting already does.
I was worried that because of this, the game might be overly gruesome, but it's not. It has a certain charme.

I actually like that the game world is relatively limited and that you revisit places a lot, which change every now and then. It gives the whole setting more depth. I also can more easily relate to the various quests, see them as part of a whole. At times the game makes it difficult to stop, because, as I said, it's like reading a good book where you're always at some interesting point.

The combat isn't overly detailed, which makes it more fun to play around with the various combat stances and alchemical helpers and just watch and enjoy the action. I also like the very limited selection of weapons and armor. It would just be unnecessary complication. I personally don't like stuff that much, and the alchemy is still tolerable to me, because when you play on medium difficulty, you don't have to dive deep into that. A few potions here and there and it'll be fine.

I like very much how the game doesn't put too much time pressure on you. Many of the temporarily active helpers are long-lasting (e.g. a blade sharpening that lasts a full day of in-game time), and the in-game time progresses slowly enough that you don't end up hurrying around before the 'wrong time of day' sets in.

It's easy for me to overlook the various small flaws of the game. They're not too immersion-breaking, and the UI has some minor complications that aren't too bothersome. (Among the things that bother me most is that in some free range areas there are artificial fences, requiring you to walk all the way around. But it's just a minor inconvenience.)

The decisions you make in various situations don't feel like dummies that pretend to have an effect, but there are (some) consequences, so you actually feel like playing a role.
I sometimes would have wished for more flexibility in dialogues when decision-making is involved, but again: Not a big deal.

The Witcher is just so different from that 'typical game experience'. A very good translation of a book series to a computer game. Again... It's almost as if you're 'playing a novel', but totally not like an interactive novel, and also not like those modern games that linearly push you from scene to scene, but a proper, mature computer game with focus on story and character interaction. You're wandering around in a story.

In fact, what makes this game great reminds me a bit of the Half-Life series, but with less action and less linearity. At least the first game was based on the work of a real horror story author.


Specific things that bothered me significantly:
- No access to storage in chapter 5 - you have to work with what you have and can't restock from your storage. Even worse, at the beginning of the chapter you are allowed access, but shortly after, you are barred from it.
- Voice dialogues contain many instances of wrong emphasis due to the VA not knowing the context of the line.
- Geralt keeps sheathing his weapon after a few seconds against my intention to not do that.
- Drawing the sword (except in strong stance) makes Geralt move faster, so basically for fast travel always draw your sword. I wish there was a better way to travel quickly than this obvious workaround.
- Fist fight is very weird. There are skills for various moves, but not enough tutorial to explain how they work, so my fist fighting ended up very simplistic. Situation-dependent combos rarely ever worked properly.

- Geralt of Review

reviewText:
I finished my first playthrough of The Witcher (Yes, first playthrough gave me 99 hours of gameplay, but could have been done in under 40), and I downloaded and started The Witcher 2 just 5 minutes later. This has become my new favorite adventure story that I can't stop telling my friends about, and I thinking about learning Polish just to read the books.

This is a very expansive universe with in-depth gaming mechanics that will take you a while to understand and master (look up the wiki for the game, it will help so much, but be sure to tread carefully as it is full of spoilers: http://witcher.wikia.com/wiki/Witcher_Wiki) It is not a perfected game, as there are limitations to combat and exploring, and dated graphics. Most of these inequities however, you will find ot be endearing rather than frustrating and while play the sequel, you will probably develop nostalgia. On that note, the sequel expands upon almost everything from the first, although it borrows heavily from the mechanics of the first. I'd highly reccomend beating the first before moving on. This way you can jump into #2 seamlessly and feel right at home. Additionally, the first game has tons of morally decisions to make, and tons of loot to find, some of which you can import into the second game!

This game has a very interesting medieval setting, and the coolest things about the story are the contemporary themes! You have 'terrorist' elves taking hostages in a bank holdup, there are 'special forces' units in service to the crown, everywhere you go people are making rascist remarks and commiting hate crimes, you see 'the church' showing its true evil, and overheard jokes about 'drinking and riding'.

This seem to me to be very much a game meant for dudes, for you are medieval badass that slays bandits, monsters, and women alike. It is not a sexist game, there are many women kicking ♥♥♥ here too, but it can come off that way as have the choice to conquer nearly everyone of them. The 'romance' in here isn't great, some of the 'romance cards' are kinda cute, others downright disturbing, but all in all the sequel does a much better job with romance scenes.

Breakdown

Pros:
-Original Medieval Fantasy story/setting
-Great soundtrack
-Mulit-dimensioned combat mechanics
-Lots of exploration
-Good loot
-Lots of characters
-Choices affect the story
-High replay ability
-Hours of gameplay, but not required!
-Mod compatible
-Importing save to the sequel
-Very detailed wiki site and fan base

Cons:
-Minimal control over swordplay
-Poor combat movement
-Invisible exploration barriers (like KOTOR)
-Graphics do not look like the official screen shots
-Awkward and unexpected story ending (don't worry there's a sequel now)

reviewText: I played through this game on easy and just listened in to the story for the most part. Even on easy the game was pretty challenging in parts, but not really due to the difficulty, but due to the very clunky combat system. I felt like I was fighting Geralt's glitchy moves more than I was the monsters at times. However, the game as a whole is pretty good. It's a decently long game and there's a bunch of quests. There's a bit too much backtracking for my tastes, particularly in Chapters 2 and 4 and the quests at times can feel arbitrary (go to person A, find person B, find out person B is dead and then have to talk to A. Go find person C so they can give you xp and orens). I can really only recommend this game if you really don't wanna feel left out for some of the characters in The Witcher 2 and you want to transfer your save file over to the 2nd game a la Mass Effect style. If the game's combat really turns you off that much, I'd honestly just find a wiki summary of the story and read that, though you'd be missing out on the pretty good character interaction.\n\nTL;DR: The game is clunky and feels very dated, but the main story is really enthralling and worth the trip if you care about the lore enough.

reviewText:
The Witcher. We all know why you're here. To play this game before witcher 2 then 3. You may be hesitating whether to buy this game because the graphics look old, and the dialogues are horrible. And you're right, they are, but once you get past those, the game is pretty fun. There are some sex scenes (which I don't mind), but they're opitional and are just pictures of nude women. The story is average, if not above average. A group of super mercenaries, witchers, gets their mutant secrets stolen by a group of bandits, so Geralt must find them and grab it back.

One complaint is that the quests makes you walk back and forth around the map. Receive a quest on the left side of the map, complete it the right side, then talk to someone at the top, go back to the left, then receive reward at the right. The majority of the quests just make you run around until you get sick of the maps.

But the major flaw in this game is the glitchy combat system. There will be times when you need to tap to attack, but Geralt acts like an idiot and just stands still. There have been times when I would want to punch my monitor out of how frustrating it was.

Overall: 7/10
Although the combat and dialogue sucks, the story is indeed worth playing. There is a good sense of lore where you play a medeival fantasy setting. I would recommend this game if you plan on buying the sequels just so you can get a better understanding with the characters.

Some tips if you play this game: spend time to make potions. The only other way to heal is sleeping or waiting for your health to regenerate by eating food. Also, if you deciede to play the extra adventure games, Price of Neutrality" is the only one worth playing imo."

reviewText:
With the impending launch of TW3, I made the decision to replay TW and TW2. I didn't finish TW my first time around as I loat interest around chapter 3. I had similar geelings the second time around but I was determined to finish it this time.

Good point for the game:

1. Story is interesting. If you aren't big on stories,  skip this game.
2. Level system allows for some customization. I fully upgraded igni and aard for instance.
3. Hard is challenging without using alchemy constantly.
4. Choices matter for the storyline.

Drawbacks:

1. Combat is static. 3 styles and then signs. Once you know which style and swords to use you can cut up just about any enemy.
2. Collecting alchemy ingredients is tedious as is running out of inventory for them.
3. Side quests are very repetitive.  Kill x of y. Must read some book first. Boring!
4. You can't change geralt's hairstyle!!!!
5. Not for younger gamers as there is quite a bit of sexual content. Almost unnecessarily at times. I mean, the nurses? Really?
6. Storyline in this game is unnecessary to enjoy TW2. Characters met at the beginning are not revisited after the prologue. Looking forward to seeing them in TW3.
7. Some failed quests always remain active in your log. Hot potato for one.
8. Holy lag starting in Chapter 3. FPS averaged around 30 in the Trade Quarter and sometimes lower at night in the swamp.

Though I have more drawbacks than good points, it can still be worth playing if you like the gameplay mechanics, which grew on me I'll admit. For $1.99 on steam sale, why not buy it?

reviewText: While I do recommend this game to others, I must say this game was a struggle for me. I enjoy games with deep stories that actually demand your attention, but this game lost me. I had to force myself to play it and beat it. It was a tough pill for me to swallow. As many people complain about, the combat system is just down right ridiculous and annoying. The game itself is looonggg. There were so many times I thought that I finally was getting close to the last fight, just to be thrust something else to do that was going to take another half hour to an hour to do. But as much as I struggled to finish it, I'm glad I did. The story, so long as you pay attention, is totally worth it. The choices they give you and consequences make sense. But part of me is glad this is over. I can finally move on to the other Witchers.

reviewText:
This game is worth playing.  The combat system is very wonky but once you get the hang of it, it isn't so bad at all, and the story is very good.  Also the choices you make in this game carry over to 2nd game.

Act I, III and IV move along quite well.  Act II, V and Epilogue seem to drag on.

The alchemy system is a bit confusing but the game tells you what you can make so it isn't too bad.  Level up Igni a lot, it is very powerful, maybe a bit too powerful.

To answer the question:  Is it worth playing this game or should I just skip to the 2nd game?  The short answer: Yes, play this game!  The long answer: if you are a roleplaying enthusit you will enjoy the many nuances the game has to offer, also Geralt's sense of humor is amazing!  The game is a long one, I clocked over 50 hours on it.

reviewText: As this is the first entry of Geralt's gaming appearances, and CDProjektRed's first published product, it can at times feel a little janky. Bioware's Aurora2007 engine contributes to that jankiness a bit as well. For anyone that's played Neverwinter Nights (the original, not the f2p mmo), it kind of feels similar to that. The combat system is odd and tends to be a little bit difficult to get used to, but it serves as only a tool to let you indulge in the weird and wonderful world of The Witcher. Like all the other entries of the series, it's filled with great characters and a story that is echelons above most RPGs.\n\nAll in all, this is a rough gem that exceeds its value by far. Especially when you can get it on sale sometimes for just over a quid.

reviewText: Overall, I'd give it an 80 by today's standards. The combat was decent; I liked how it rewarded timing, like in Legend of Dragoon. The story was ok; nothing amazing, but solid. The RPG elements were great for an Eastern European RPG released in 2005. I thought the amount of sex was a bit much, but once I started seeing it more like a Fantasy 007, it made a bit of sense. Also, the graphics are stunning for any game from 2005 not named Far Cry. Definitely worth playing to catch up on Witcher 2 and 3.

reviewText:
After playing The Witcher 2 and 3, I was pleasantly surprised by this game.  I heard before that it was a bad game, but I wanted to see for myself.  I suspect most players get put off by the confusing game mechanics, the combat system especially.  Once you play enough, you will get the hang of the game's systems.  I was slicing up Salamandra with ease by Chapter 2.

If you get bored of the slow detective-like story, don't worry because it picks up by Chapter 3.  You can beat the game easy by not doing any side quests, which is what I did.  The game has a dark and dingy atmosphere which can feel boring, but it's supposed to tie in with the atmosphere of the series.

Some of the voice acting is pretty bad, and most of the characters faces look deformed.  Alvin and Dandelion are the worst.  The animations are pretty terrible aswell, like walking and Geralt's fighting.

If you like the story of The Witcher 2 and 3, and have a lot of patience, I recommend giving The Witcher 1 a shot.  The scene with The Lady of The Lake and Eredin's spectre at the end are some of my favorite scenes in all The Witcher series.

reviewText: I would definately recommend this game to anyone who is slightly interested in it. The combat system is rather enjoyable once you get accustom to it, I just have finished the second chapter and have yet to feel as if the combat system is repetitive or boring since it provides three different styles for fighting that have different and relevant animations. The alchemy and potion system is unique and adds a different level of difficulty to the game. Even the main character Geralt is amazing with his witty sarcasm and epic expressionless voice. However, one of my favorite things about this game is the ability to make your own decisions and change how you play the game and how the other characters react around you. Overall, this is an incredible fun game with a great story and great characters and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
With rich lore and a compelling narrative, The Witcher delivers a well-exectuted story that has your choices play a significant role in several outcomes. As you explore the world of The Witcher, you will be slaying monsters, fighting the Salamandra scum and choosing whether to help the people (and werewolves) of Vizima.


While the controls get a little getting used to. they get the job done with simple timed-clicks and spell executions. Although, selecting what weapon you use via hotkeys can be confusing and clunky in general. Clicking the weapon you want is by far the easier solution.


Alchemy is a large element of the game as it can give tempoary buffs to Geralt during combat or by granting the ability to let you see in the dark. You can also brew oils to increase your weapons' effectiveness and you can also craft bombs. But, these buffs come at a cost. Toxicity. When your toxicity bar becomes at least half full, Geralt starts to become intoxicated. The more the bar is filled (the more potions you drink), the more intoxicated Geralt will become resulting in him being slower, potions having a negative affect or he may just die instantly. However, toxicity can be cured by: meditating or by drinking White Honey.


Questing in this game consists of having a few main quest branches, a few side quest branches and miscellaneous monster contracts.The structure of the quests can be confusing as let's say, the main
objective is to (no spoilers here, just made up) talk to Triss about the enchanted rose. You do that and this piece of text appears under this quest: Now that Triss knows about the rose
date:
I should come back after I go and see the Druids." That puts this particular quest on hold for now. Then you get a new objective for a different quest that says: "Find the druids and get more information about the rose." You do that and then this quest goes on hold while you go back to Triss....I think you get my point. It's downright confusing!


There are activities in the game such as: fist fights & poker. The fist fights are boring once you learn the right tactics (rigging I mean) but if you want to make quick money
hoursPlayed:
the poker is well done in this game. The music gets you into the gambling spirit!


Overall
voteText: I have enjoyed this game a lot. While the gameplay can feel dated sometimes
helpfulPercent: plus the occasional crashes
votesHelpful: the voice acting is great and the story is compelling. I think it's definitely worth a buy if you're a newcomer to the Witcher series! :)\n\n7.5/10"

reviewText:
On the PC, single player RPGs are becoming increasingly rare. Titles from larger companies seem to be relegated largely to remakes or ports of console games. Some smaller companies have stepped up to fill the gap, and while it would be easy for those companies to make subpar games given their small size and the lack of competition, there are some games, such as The Witcher: Enhanced Edition, which prove that great things can come from small companies.

The main character, Geralt, is a Witcher. Witchers are mutated humans with the ability to dispatch monsters. In return for their increased combat prowess, Witchers are unable to have children. Geralt is part of a small group of Witchers who find themselves besieged by a group of sorcerers. Everyone, including Geralt, is forced to investigate and track down this group. In doing so, Geralt comes face to face with his humanity, his friends and his ideas of morality.

Enough cannot be said about this story. Based off a Polish novel, it is full of detail and character. The story and dialogue is so well written that, at times, it singlehandedly pulls the player into the game. The world of The Witcher is not a bright, green happy-go-lucky wonderland either. Filled with greed, racism, and poverty, the setting portrayed here is as close as any game has ever come in mixing real world problems with fantasy creatures such as elves, druids and dwarves.

To add further depth to the story elements, the decisions the player makes throughout the game have profound effects on the story and relationships with other characters. Simple conversation choices can change how other people, or even entire races, feels about Geralt. To add further weight to those decisions, numerous flashbacks liberally scattered throughout the story explore Geralt’s reflections on events and choices players made in the past. This is a refreshing contrast to other RPGs where your decisions (especially in conversations) have little or no impact on the story at all. Multiple playthroughs to discover different plots and endings certainly add to the replay value. Since decisions at the very beginning can have a domino effect on options later in the game, a complete replay or two may be necessary to experience all the differences.

Of course, being a Witcher, Geralt must solve many situations with weapons and magic. Attacking others is as simple as choosing a weapon and clicking on the enemy. As Geralt attacks, the mouse icon flashes indicating an opportunity to get in an extra attack. By chaining together multiple attacks, massive damage can be done while minimizing incoming damage. Various weapons and magic attacks, each with strategic uses in different situations, keep combat interesting and engaging. Furthermore, potions can be made to provide numerous bonuses in tougher bouts. Things can be pretty hectic in some of the larger battles, but players can pause at any time to consider options and choose the next move. Unfortunately, aiming and camera control can be a bit challenging at times. Pausing allows the player to take their time for the most part, but when one of these issues happens in the middle of a combo, it can be frustrating and lead to the occasional death.

Experience points are earned through fighting and completing missions. Upon leveling, Geralt can meditate and learn new skills. Aside from buffing melee combat and magic, gathering and creation skills may also be improved. Herbs and other materials may be found all over the world and made into potions, bombs and other items to aid during combat. And while potions may improve combat abilities temporarily, they also increase toxicity, so they may not be abused.

Visually, most things look good. Up close, some character models, especially Geralt, look great. Coupled with some great movement, Geralt oozes attitude. On the other hand, there are so many different NPCs that the same character graphics are recycled numerous times, potentially confusing some players. Backgrounds, towns and surroundings are generally well done and detailed; however, significant fog effects and limited drawing distances show up often in several outdoor areas. Sound is done very well, with exceptional voice work

The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is a re-release of the original, bundled with substantial additions. A physical map, bonus DVDs, soundtracks, hintbooks and a couple of extra adventure modules are included. Furthermore, for owners of the original game, many of these bonuses may be downloaded for free from the main site. During the playthrough, several minor bugs and game crashes were experienced. However, the inconveniences were minor, and a quick scan of the forums indicates that these isssues pop up on a minority of computer setups. Also, The Witcher was infamous for its load times that made the game unplayable to some. This issue has been addressed, as scene transitions load quickly.

Overall, The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is an amazing game. The combat system, while quite solid, may not grab everyone. The plot, characters and ability to affect the story will. What The Witcher: Enhanced Edition lacks in technical prowess and polish, it makes up for in heart. Every RPGamer who has ever complained of superficial plot devices and the lack of true decision making abilities in video game RPGs should absolutely give this game a run through. Anyone who plays this game will remember it for many years to come, and that is one of the highest forms of praise RPGamer can bestow on a game.

reviewText: If you played Witcher 2/3 and wondering if this game is worth checking out, I say yes if you were big into the stories of those games. I played 2 and 3 first and was very surprised first of all by how ambitious the story of this older game is, but also by how much continuity there is between all three games. If you played 2/3, you probably followed along the story just fine, but you missed more than you think if you haven't played this game. And again, the story of this game is just as ambitious as its successors, even if the game itself is pretty rough around the edges.\n\nAs far as the gameplay, the combat bears little resemblance to its sequels, while the quest format felt surprisingly similar to Witcher 3. I think Witcher 3 is the game they wished they could have made in 2007, if CDPR had the tech and resources back then. But I must be clear about one thing: clunky" isn't even a good descriptor for this game's combat system. The combat in this game straight up sucks. It's as idiotic as it is frustrating. However in my view it is worth putting up with if you were a fan of Witcher 2/3's stories or just a fan of story-driven games in general."

reviewText:
I was initially put off by this game. I bought it on sale about a year ago and told it would be worth my money. So I get it running and start playing the prologue. I found the controls clunky and hard to control, the combat system seemed needlessly convoluted and I died multiple times at the first boss, because I was so confused. I didn't have the patience for the game at the time. But here I am writing a positive review. I let it sit in my library for months and started to feel guilty that I spent money on a game I didn't want to play. So I decided to pick it up again and was determined to play it further and finish it whether I liked it or not, I felt that I owed the game a fair play, a game that so many obviously love and I couldn't help but feel that maybe I was missing out on something. I was right.

I restarted the game and took the time to play and learn, I still find the combat a bit clunky, but I've learned to manage and succeed playing the game. I've found that The Witcher has a rich story to tell. The music is beautiful and character interactions provide a lot of depth to the world. For each new character you meet, each new beast you fight, and every note or book you find, new story elements are uncovered and added to your journal. It's clear the developers put a lot of time and heart into this game.

One of the most intriguing elements of the game that nobody fails to mention is the Alchemy system. You gather various herbs, chemicals, and liquors which are used in alchemical recipes to create useful potions. You should pay attention to what you can use for a recipe because multiple subtitute reagents can be used as many materials contain the same derivative substance.

The Witcher is far from perfect, but it has just enough depth to keep me hooked, it's an adventure I'm excited to continue and see to the end.

reviewText:
After playing The Witcher 2 and 3, I was pleasantly surprised by this game.  I heard before that it was a bad game, but I wanted to see for myself.  I suspect most players get put off by the confusing game mechanics, the combat system especially.  Once you play enough, you will get the hang of the game's systems.  I was slicing up Salamandra with ease by Chapter 2.

If you get bored of the slow detective-like story, don't worry because it picks up by Chapter 3.  You can beat the game easy by not doing any side quests, which is what I did.  The game has a dark and dingy atmosphere which can feel boring, but it's supposed to tie in with the atmosphere of the series.

Some of the voice acting is pretty bad, and most of the characters faces look deformed.  Alvin and Dandelion are the worst.  The animations are pretty terrible aswell, like walking and Geralt's fighting.

If you like the story of The Witcher 2 and 3, and have a lot of patience, I recommend giving The Witcher 1 a shot.  The scene with The Lady of The Lake and Eredin's spectre at the end are some of my favorite scenes in all The Witcher series.

reviewText: One of my favorite games of all time- I've played through it three separate times and never fail to find new reasons to love it.  The graphics still hold up, and the combat is fine as long as you know what you're getting into- a Diablo-style click on the bad guy to hit him, then hit him again if he's still alive, and if you REALLY mean business hit him a third, fourth, and (you masochist) fifth time.  If you're used to RPG's give it a go on hard- it's adds much more depth using the potions and blade oils, as well as magic signs (I'm an Aard fanatic).  I've heard the pre-Enchanced Edition was somewhat rough, with longer loading times and only about 4 non-Geralt character skins, so if you played it when it first came out it could be worth reloading and seeing what you've missed.

reviewText:
It's pretty rough around the edges (which is understandable given its age and place in CD Projekt Red's catalogue) but quite enjoyable. It is unlike any other RPG I've played in a while. I love the special agent/PI character that is Geralt, it's quite unique for the genre. As is the combat style. Fights (including boss fights) can be surprisingly easy or incredibly difficult based on how much you've paid attention and done your homework. For players of other series, the game has level design and exploration along the lines of Dragon Age, with a combat style that (oddly) reminds me of the Jedi Knight games.

The game has many faults, though. Character assets are reused over and over with only a couple dozen unique characters in the game (surprisingly, though, this didn't irritate me as much as it might sound). Voice acting cutscenes are of a mediocre quality; not terrible but they've been surpassed elsewhere (like the subsequent entries in the series). Combat can be incredibly frustrating sometimes. For example, being stunned repeatedly by four wraiths to the point you cannot move or attack is maddening. It also felt that there were too many elements to the game, some of which can be (and ultimately have to be) ignored in favour of others. For example, I didn't get anywhere near maxing out my character (despite doing every quest) and never touched bombs. I also didn't feel all the signs were as useful as they could be; some easily overshadow others. Combat is generally quite easy (with a few exceptions).

I very much enjoyed the claustrophobic, urban setting of the first half of the game. When it changed setting in the second half I was, at first, relieved for a change of scenery but the following areas (while containing enjoyable quests) are overly large and it feels like all you're ever doing is walking from point to point (with, surprisingly - compared to earlier areas - few enemies to worry about). The game also has a somewhat awkward, somewhat rewarding epilogue sequence, a huge twist (if you're paying attention) and a cliffhanger ending.

Overall, I'd recommend it if you really want to play the entire trilogy. But if you're not that fussed, I'd probably suggest just reading up on what happens in the first game (and about its characters) and moving on to The Witcher 2 (where things improve and change drastically).

reviewText:
Fantastic game. Took about 50 hours to beat the game 100%, so not too long for a RPG. Regardless, excellent story, great graphics for when it came out and for the most part, great voice acting. (Excluding Dandelion...) Fascinating world, and lot's of fun to be had.

Plus there are boobies. And monsters that let their wang hang all the way. (You know, if you're into that sort of thing.)

Really dark and mature, and slightly depressing. Game does not shy away from adult content/humor. Plus there is so much sex. No really. This game is like Game of Thrones but for video games. Geralt is such a player that it's not funny. At one point you can choose to have an affair that takes up an entire chapter of the game. It's great fun.

Fun decision making with real consequences and some cool optional quests. Also very memorable characters... easy to know what you need to do, and the game isn't overly difficult. (That is if you don't mind spending hours and hours grinding your levels)

Plus, it has a great cliff hanger leading straight into the sequel...

Highly recommended. Especially since Steam sells the definitive Director's Cut for so cheap.

Don't think, just buy it. It's the best RPG you'll play on PC until you play the superior sequel.

My rating: A+
Happy hunting.

reviewText:
You are Witcher Gerry.

You're peely-wally, scarred and can't remember jack-♥♥♥♥ but you have a gravelly voice and uber powers so it's okay. That's right folks, you get to play this brilliant RPG as a monster-slaying mutant. There's freaky powers such as force-push (but called something else to avoid a lawsuit) and the ever useful lets-set-everything-on-fire-with-my-mind power.

If that weren't enought fun, you travel the lands wielding two swords (because one would just be average). A normal sword for slicing up men/women/children/dogs/hobos/justaboutanyoneyoucanthinkof and then there's your silver sword for all the monsters that want to eat you. The fighting system is a helluva lot of fun and very simple to use - it works on the basis of timing mouse clicks. Get it right and witness some awesome ballet of the lethal form, get it wrong and watch as a giant man-eating plant starts munching on your pale corpse.

Story's excellent too and it's nice to see a RPG that isn't afraid to be for adults. When Gerry's not slaying monsters, gambling with dice, or boxing fat people, he's chasing every bit of skirt he can find.

BUT NEVER FEAR! Our witcher is sterile and immune to all diseases, so no worries about pregnancies or STIs.

It's not all blood and boobs, there are the game hangups that can frustrate you whilst you wait for it to sort itself. There's also only about 8 voice actors (I swear one of which narrates the tv show How it's made") and just as few NPC models - hint
date: every merchant is the big fat guy with the hat.\n\nStill
recommended: a great game that'll have to raiding tombs and knickers (but never at the same time!\n\nGame on!"

reviewText:
There's a reason why this game has such great scores everywhere, why people speak well of it, and why I played it for hours and hours, every day.
First of all, I have bad news: even though this game is great, don't spend your money if you don't have maturity to play it. I mean, I played it once when I was 14-15, but I could just realise how good this game is by playing it again when I became an adult.

The game is full of decisions. Each decision affects the rest of the game. And by the ending of it, you will see that you made some bad decisions - and that allows replayability, which is great. I hardly get interested in the story, but this one is special

The combat may not respond well sometimes, but considering that the game is a bit old, the flaws are acceptable, and they won't really annoy you.
Something I really liked is that you can choose the way you fight: Sword fighting is excelent and strong, using alchemy is highly effective, and magic is awesome. You can fully max one of those, or mix them - both ways are effective too.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's a lengthy adventure with a lot of choices to make. Although, the story is straight-forward, it has different elements that make it awesome. The combat mechanics are a bit of a letdown, but you have 3 different fighting styles and 5 powers too, so you can use a combination of that to improve your fighting experience. The alchemy and the universe - lore - are really amazing. You have a lot of detailed information about monsters, characters, missions and the world of Temeria, where the adventure of the Witcher is set. Although the graphics are outdated, and some npc's models recycled, the atmosphere is flawless, you can feel like you are Geralt. It has a good replay value, as there are 3 possible endings, which are determined by your choices, some of those, are made way before you see the consecuences, making you feel like an a**hole because of what you have done.

TL,DR:

+: 30+hrs of fun, nice graphics, immersive world and story, nice replay value
- : combat mechanics and some npc's recycled models. character animations are, sometimes, bad
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is an extremely immersive game if you let it be. I didn't like it the first time I tried it because I didn't know what I was getting into. The second time however I feel in love. I will note a few things though:

The game as a whole is dull until Chapter 2

The game focuses on dialog and character development as much if not more than combat. If that turns you off I wouldn't recommend this game.

The combat is more repetitive than most games, but tolerable.

The game fails to give tutorials on how some mechanics/controls works. For instance: You hold down shift to see your mouse cursor to click on your signs. There I just saved you 5 minutes of google searching.

The dialog is really bad in the first chapter, but significantly raises in quality after that.

Closing Thoughts: If you like RPG's that are character driven this is the game for you. It may not have the open world of Witcher 3, but it is a very enjoyable experience.

reviewText: The Witcher is a rough diamond.  Some of the translation to English results in odd conversations, some sections (mainly the swamp) are a bit of a grind, the combat can be repetitive and I had the occasional crash.  There are also some upgrades, signs and potions that are much more useful than others.\n\nAt times, too, it wasn't particularly clear about why you were doing what you were doing, or which speech option would get you which result.  But that's part of what makes The Witcher rewarding to play - it doesn't always hold your hand or telegraph every step in the plot.  The story is engrossing and, translation aside, the characters are great (even though most of the 'romances' are just Geralt saying let's bang
date: ok?") and you will quickly realise that you can't please everyone.  There are definitely a few tough choices to make.\n\nThe game takes a while to warm up so don't be put off by the slow start.  Also
recommended: if you're finding it difficult and dying a lot then - like me
hoursPlayed: initially - you're doing it wrong.  There are always potions
voteText: blade coatings
helpfulPercent: signs or upgrades that make beating particular enemies (and the game) much easier.  When in doubt: Swallow.\n\nWhile The Witcher lacks some of the polish (not Polish) of its AAA RPG cousins

reviewText:
A unique role-playing game that is a rarity these days. Developed by a Polish company and is based on the book with the same title written by a Polish author called Andrzej Sapkowski. You play as Geralt, a mutant hunter who is specialised in fighting and slaying monsters. At the beginning of Geralt's story he does not remember much - he's found unconscious and is taken to the witchers' hideout. The establishment, then, is attacked by a group of bandits known as the Salamander - although defending the castle is a success, the witchers are unable to stop the bandits from stealing their precious mutagens. Geralt and his fellow witchers, therefore, set out to find where the gang is hiding and of course to take back what is rightfully theirs.

Some notable elements that characterises Witcher and makes it different from other RPGs:

--- Controlling Geralt is very easy. The game offers you several camera perspectives, in fact, even the input device can be changed: focus can be on the mouse solely or you can use the combination of the keyboard and mouse - whichever is your preference.

--- During combat timing is very important. The game being hack-and-slash requires you to hit enemies several times. This, Geralt does automatically, but following the hit of his blade you can have a follow-up click with your mouse - if your timing is perfect Geralt does make a follow-up cut which is stronger and deadlier. In addition to this the game employs 3 combat styles. Larger enemies require the strong style: Geralt carefully times each hit and while they are slower they result in a heavier slash. Faster enemies simply avoid your attacks but changing to the fast style enables you to hit them. And if your are surrounded you need to use the group style.

--- Beside the styles and the timing you should be careful with the material your weapon is made of. While steel-made swords are perfect against human beings and some of the monsters you encounter there are many supernatural beings in the Witcher's world you can only wound with a silver-made sword.

And here come those that made me like the game a lot:

--- Choices: Yes, yes, this is common. You decide to help or you simply let people die. Right? No! Witcher does not indicate what will happen once a decision is made. Unlike Mass Effect, here there are no indicators and nobody tells you whether it is good or bad what you'll attempt to do. In certain cases both decisions you can make will result in the death of someone - you need to decide which is better" or you simply need to pick A) so that in your next playthrough you can go with option B.

--- Alchemy: A very important part of the game! There are severals types of plants / herbs out there you need to collect. You can then use these at fireplaces to create potions that either make you stronger or grant you an extra ability (e.g. seeing in dark places). Interestingly
date: all of these poison Geralt to a certain degree - your toxicity level increases and eventually you need to rest or drink another potion that neutralises the adverse effect of these drinks. The more scrolls you find the more potions are available - you can also experiment if you have the time.\n\nIt should be noted that Geralt is mainly a warrior. You have some spells called signs but they are nothing special. So
recommended: in your next playthrough you cannot have a significantly different build - you can experiment
hoursPlayed: for sure
voteText: but the value lies in Witcher's world. And this world is huge. I like how the game starts filling up your Glossary - a menu similar to the codex in the Dragon Ages series containing all kinds of entries explaining the world to the gamer. Also
helpfulPercent: while fistfighting is rather easy and boring the drinking and dice-poker mini games are excellent and make the game quite funny!\n\nI finished the game in 50+ hours and pretty much completed everything I could. I read the game's wikia pages parallelly and found that I'd missed some missions and if I remember correctly the game has at least 2 endings. So there you go: over 100 hours and this is only for 8 bucks! In addition to this
votesHelpful: it comes in the form of a so-called Enhanced Edition that offers a lot of extras such as making-of videos and other campaigns. Plus
votesTotal: the game looks quite good for being released in 2007!\n\nOverall
votesFunny: Witcher is a unique RPG. If you are fan of the genre and finished multiple playthroughs in Dragon Age then do head for the store page as this game must be in your basket!"

reviewText:
I'll make this short and compact:

Pros:
-good story
-good characters
-not too much stupid miniquests that have nothing to do with the plot
-awesome skill trees
-runs perfectly and has a lot of options
-not too hard to understand
-good gameplay
-good franchise
- sex. lots of sex.

Cons:
- being the first game of the franchise, it has A LOT and I mean I LOT of issues
- main issue: the combat system. It feels strange, it is strange, it is VERY random and has rarely anything to do with actual skill gameplay. Ok I lied. It is COMPLETELY random and the weapons only differ in their damage (effects). That's it.
-a lot of on foot backtracking and annoying enemy encounters that can't be avoided because they sprint after you faster than Usain Bolt
- some quests are stupidely hard ( example: escort that 1 chick from a village to another, she dies from 2 enemy dog attacks and it's IMPOSSIBLE to keep her protected the entire time because at least 1 dog always attacks her, therefore losing the mission and forcing you to restart, bringing me to my next point)
-the save system is non existant basically, as the game only ( if ever) saves every half an houri and believe me, if you forget to save yourself 5 times in 2 minutes, backtracking half an hour in this game will basically make you so mad and annoyed that you stop playing the game, like I did after multiple times where I just can't focus saving every 2 minutes because I have other important stuff to mind about in the game already.
-hunky npc interaction, basically there is rarely any clue if your recent dialog helped you gain any useful information for a quest, except if you start a new one
- I have yet to find out ( if I ever start playing again) if the skilltrees are actually effecting my game in any ways, because as I said above, I feel like I skill up but gain nothing from it.
- inventory management is purely a pain in the ♥♥♥ because you never get any hints if the stuff u have in an inventory will help u later in a quest, therefore you keep them and if you drop an item and DO need it later on, you can backtrack half an hour, which kills the entire fun in this game.



Conclussion: I would personally skip this game if I had a chance, but since I bought it for only 2 euros, I can't complain since this game convinced me to play the other Witcher games, which I have heard have improved a lot from the first one. I do not directly regret the Witcher 1 purchase, but would recommend skipping this one and buying the second one directly.

reviewText:
The Witcher: Enhanced Edition is an extremely immersive game if you let it be. I didn't like it the first time I tried it because I didn't know what I was getting into. The second time however I feel in love. I will note a few things though:

The game as a whole is dull until Chapter 2

The game focuses on dialog and character development as much if not more than combat. If that turns you off I wouldn't recommend this game.

The combat is more repetitive than most games, but tolerable.

The game fails to give tutorials on how some mechanics/controls works. For instance: You hold down shift to see your mouse cursor to click on your signs. There I just saved you 5 minutes of google searching.

The dialog is really bad in the first chapter, but significantly raises in quality after that.

Closing Thoughts: If you like RPG's that are character driven this is the game for you. It may not have the open world of Witcher 3, but it is a very enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
It's a lengthy adventure with a lot of choices to make. Although, the story is straight-forward, it has different elements that make it awesome. The combat mechanics are a bit of a letdown, but you have 3 different fighting styles and 5 powers too, so you can use a combination of that to improve your fighting experience. The alchemy and the universe - lore - are really amazing. You have a lot of detailed information about monsters, characters, missions and the world of Temeria, where the adventure of the Witcher is set. Although the graphics are outdated, and some npc's models recycled, the atmosphere is flawless, you can feel like you are Geralt. It has a good replay value, as there are 3 possible endings, which are determined by your choices, some of those, are made way before you see the consecuences, making you feel like an a**hole because of what you have done.

TL,DR:

+: 30+hrs of fun, nice graphics, immersive world and story, nice replay value
- : combat mechanics and some npc's recycled models. character animations are, sometimes, bad

reviewText:
There's a reason why this game has such great scores everywhere, why people speak well of it, and why I played it for hours and hours, every day.
First of all, I have bad news: even though this game is great, don't spend your money if you don't have maturity to play it. I mean, I played it once when I was 14-15, but I could just realise how good this game is by playing it again when I became an adult.

The game is full of decisions. Each decision affects the rest of the game. And by the ending of it, you will see that you made some bad decisions - and that allows replayability, which is great. I hardly get interested in the story, but this one is special

The combat may not respond well sometimes, but considering that the game is a bit old, the flaws are acceptable, and they won't really annoy you.
Something I really liked is that you can choose the way you fight: Sword fighting is excelent and strong, using alchemy is highly effective, and magic is awesome. You can fully max one of those, or mix them - both ways are effective too.

reviewText:
It is probably helpful for the reader if I compare The Witcher to Skyrim:

While Skyrim 'feels' like a computer game, a role playing game, and maybe could be described as having a slight theatrical vibe, playing The Witcher feels like reading a good book. It is very character- and story-focused. Geralt of Rivia is a very down-to-earth and likeable character and the game doesn't try to glorify or overly dramatize things. Those subtleties make the game feel even more believable and realistic than the medieval setting already does.
I was worried that because of this, the game might be overly gruesome, but it's not. It has a certain charme.

I actually like that the game world is relatively limited and that you revisit places a lot, which change every now and then. It gives the whole setting more depth. I also can more easily relate to the various quests, see them as part of a whole. At times the game makes it difficult to stop, because, as I said, it's like reading a good book where you're always at some interesting point.

The combat isn't overly detailed, which makes it more fun to play around with the various combat stances and alchemical helpers and just watch and enjoy the action. I also like the very limited selection of weapons and armor. It would just be unnecessary complication. I personally don't like stuff that much, and the alchemy is still tolerable to me, because when you play on medium difficulty, you don't have to dive deep into that. A few potions here and there and it'll be fine.

I like very much how the game doesn't put too much time pressure on you. Many of the temporarily active helpers are long-lasting (e.g. a blade sharpening that lasts a full day of in-game time), and the in-game time progresses slowly enough that you don't end up hurrying around before the 'wrong time of day' sets in.

It's easy for me to overlook the various small flaws of the game. They're not too immersion-breaking, and the UI has some minor complications that aren't too bothersome. (Among the things that bother me most is that in some free range areas there are artificial fences, requiring you to walk all the way around. But it's just a minor inconvenience.)

The decisions you make in various situations don't feel like dummies that pretend to have an effect, but there are (some) consequences, so you actually feel like playing a role.
I sometimes would have wished for more flexibility in dialogues when decision-making is involved, but again: Not a big deal.

The Witcher is just so different from that 'typical game experience'. A very good translation of a book series to a computer game. Again... It's almost as if you're 'playing a novel', but totally not like an interactive novel, and also not like those modern games that linearly push you from scene to scene, but a proper, mature computer game with focus on story and character interaction. You're wandering around in a story.

In fact, what makes this game great reminds me a bit of the Half-Life series, but with less action and less linearity. At least the first game was based on the work of a real horror story author.


Specific things that bothered me significantly:
- No access to storage in chapter 5 - you have to work with what you have and can't restock from your storage. Even worse, at the beginning of the chapter you are allowed access, but shortly after, you are barred from it.
- Voice dialogues contain many instances of wrong emphasis due to the VA not knowing the context of the line.
- Geralt keeps sheathing his weapon after a few seconds against my intention to not do that.
- Drawing the sword (except in strong stance) makes Geralt move faster, so basically for fast travel always draw your sword. I wish there was a better way to travel quickly than this obvious workaround.
- Fist fight is very weird. There are skills for various moves, but not enough tutorial to explain how they work, so my fist fighting ended up very simplistic. Situation-dependent combos rarely ever worked properly.

- Geralt of Review

reviewText:
I wanted to play all the witcher games in order so started here, I had initially tried to get in to the game a while ago and just didn't enjoy it, I decided to give it another shot. It has a pretty slow beginning and there is a lot to learn in terms of all the mechanics of the game. Combat can be clunky but I thought it was okay.

For me what made this game so great was how immersive it was, not in the sense of awesome graphics, but just how deep and complex the world is, I loved reading all of the background material and the story has lots of twists and turns which for me is what helped keep me hooked and drive me forward. There are some interesting moral choices and I love that none of your choices are the right choice" everything is morally grey and its up to you.

It has its flaws but its worth it for a glimpse into the dark and mysterious world of the Witcher with plenty of unforgettable characters along the way."

reviewText:
The Witcher delivers a mature role-playing experience with a deep and rich lore filled with decisions and consequences. The story and writing is absolutely top of the line, and no wonder considering it's based on the Witcher novels.

This is not you average hack and slash game that you will smash buttons throughout the game, instead you need to plan and time your moves. The game offers a unique combat experience that will seem complicated and hard at first but with time will have you master its techniques. But being a professional monster slayer your combat techniques won't be everything. You need to research about the different monsters that you will face and find their weaknesses to be able to defeat them and you must utilize alchemy to brew potions that will aid you.

The graphics is great considering it's a game from 2008 and offers one of the best soundtracks ever composed for a video game. The voice acting is great as well.

The only downside is its long loading times and inventory system.
