reviewText:
This game is full of rich content, and is thriving with life. Most of the time.

Lets start with the good. It feels like an old timey RPG, with very simplistic, but addictive gameplay models. While the combat may not be supremely engaging, it can be very difficult at times, making preparation before a battle vital to surviving. All you need to do is master the almost, but not quite quicktime attack combat. The animations become more complex, and faster while requiring more timing and clicking with each improvement, making you feel like your moves are getting better and you feel all the more better.

Some potions are easy to make, some are not. Some are very helpful, some not so much. But each one can save your life in a dire situation. You can make a variety of bombs, potions, and oils/weapon enhancements. Some potions even make your character more powerful in general, giving him different abilities and ways to unlock special skills.

Time to talk about the negatives.

The negatives of this game are few, but can really screw with you. My system is very up-to-date and has been updated to keep with the times. However, I have experienced several blue screens through my playtime. I found this extremely odd and angering since no other game has done such a thing to me in the past. Glitches are slightly prevelant, but shouldn't cause too much trouble, and sometimes, the combat can be, at some times, meh. Sometimes, grinding is a factor you might have to use, going through a dangerous swamp to find a single herb for a swallow.

In conclusion, this is a great game, while rough around the edges, is very well made, and has fairly good graphics considering it was made in 2008. I strongly recommend this game, and remember, don't play the other witchers without starting from the beginning. Otherwise, nothing will make much sense in the long run.

reviewText:
Having played this game multiple times through, I can 100% recommend this game to anyone interested in the Witcher story.

It should be noted that anyone looking to purchase and play this game must understand that it differs immensely from its successors in many ways. The voice acting, character animations, and combat can be a little rough for some, but ultimately the game itself presents an excellent story and really pulls you in to assume the role of a witcher. You'll memorize what combat styles and Signs are useful for each monsters, learn the appearance and usage of herbs throughout the world, and you'll read and learn the lore of the Witcher.

The game presents choices throughout the game, some of which affect the story later. It is up to you decide whether Geralt will take sides or maintain his neutrality as a witcher.

Ultimately, if you intend to play the Witcher 2 or Witcher 3, I recommend you play the full trilogy for the full experience.

reviewText:
tl;dr 8/10

Good game, Very good story, Confusing mechanics but you will learn to love it.

Pro
+ awesome story
+ awesome quests
+ awesome world
+ awesome sex with hot babe

Con
- game mechanics
- combat gameplay
- lot of walking around

Full review  First game in The Witcher series from CD project red.
You will play as Garelt, an amnesia-return-from-the-dead-witcher. who try to regain his memory while on his quest to get the bad guy.

As a witcher you are a monster slayer, a human who train since a child with drug use until become a superhuman to slay monster (and laid girls). Too bad Geralt get amnesia and forget all his fighting skill, magic and knowledge.

The witcher is RPG game with lot of things to do and learn,

Story is so good it’s a pure sex, literally.
Every quest have story in it.
You will have to make a choice, take side, spare or kill which will impact the story later on.

There is also many interesting things to do. Play dice poker, Fist fight, Hunt monster, Help random people and collect romance cards AKA getting laid.

You want to have threesome with nurse? Orgy with vempires? Passionate love with sorcerer? This game have it all!!

Graphic is quite good, for old game. The atmosphere and graphic fit the wolrd of witcher nicely.
Music are very good too especially boss fight.

Gameplay is fun. Combat? Not so much.
When you attack Garelt will perform one set of sword move. When the move end cursor will change and you have to click attack again to make combo. If you click attack before or too late the move will stop. It's not that bad actually after you get used to and quite fun later in the game when you are strong but overall combat feel clunky, unresponsive and can be frustrated.

Gameplay is fun and addictive but you will found yourself walking around the map doing quest. Go there, do that kinda thing. No fast travel in this game too. While I find myself enjoy the world and love exploring it. Walking around across the map many times can be boring.

Game mechanics take awhile to get used to. Especially alchemy and crafting.
There is a steel sword for fight human and silver sword to fight monster. There is 3 different fighting style for different enemies. There is potions, blade oils, bombs with different effect which you can make and use if you get ingredients. You will have to buy books or find information about each monster and herb to be able to collect it. And many other little thing.
It will feel annoying at first but it will be a lot of fun after you get used to it. Too bad that I start to feel fun in the last chapters of the game.

The witcher may have boring start with it gameplay and story especially if you have play other witcher games before. Give it a try for a few hour first before you decide to uninstaling it.

Conclusion  The Witcher overall is a very fun RPG. Rich in story and charecter. Combat might not be the best and game mechanics might be confusing but worth to play and I'm sure you won't regret it.
If you interesting in the witcher series from CDPR DO NOT skip this one.

ps: sorry for my english.

reviewText:
The Witcher is a RPG game set in a dark fantasy universe. The atmosphere resembles the dark middle ages, where poverty, war and disease has struck down on the denizens of this world.

You are Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher who is both respected and despised for his line of work. Your profession is to dispose of creatures of the dark, demons and foul creatures by means of spell, sword and alchemy.
However, in the beginning of the game you are struck by amnesia and thus your past is unknown to you. This is a central plot in the game, as you will carve your own destiney in the god-forsaken universe of the Witcher. Choosing between right and wrong is difficult, if not impossible, as every decision you make will depend on your own moral code. There are no heroes, no real villains, as everyone is fighting for themselves and characters are thus grey" - they all contain classically noble character traits and "evil" traits. Consequently
date: the demons you are sent to kill can appear more humane than the village priest who would rather have you kill seemingly innocent people.\n\nThe game is highly recommendable
recommended: despite its now outdated graphics. The quality of the game experience is enjoyable
hoursPlayed: and several replays is almost inevitable if you want to know what would have happened if you just had sided with the other faction.. or none at all."

reviewText:
Since coming out in 2007 The Witcher has aged nicely, thanks to some extra care from the devs. The combat system is a bit clunky, and the graphics are certainly not modern, but it nonetheless remains very playable. Compared to other games of that era like Oblivion or Mass Effect it's a bit below them, but a still solid game. If those are 5's this would be a 4.

It's a super interesting world and story that has a really nice hook at the beginning. Sadly, the game's pacing suffers for the first half after that. Thankfully it picks up steam in the second half before ending in a full-speed-ahead-rollercoaster-esque finale, complete with some unexpected (but welcome and thoroughly explained) plot twists. I was very happy with the way things ended and everything leading up to it.

My biggest complaint other than the pacing problems early on is really difficulty. After the game first gives you some non-linear freedom it is incredibly difficult. Frustratingly so. But somewhere around a third of the way in you unlock enough abilities that it becomes exceedingly easy, and it stays that way through the end. I wish there had been more of a gradual incline rather than this steep cliff drop off. Hopefully the sequels correct this.

And my favorite thing about this game is just how adult it is. They really don't hold back and that's something I've been waiting for in games for a very long time. This is really the first game that aligns more with a movie's R rating, and that makes it unique. Some others have caught up recently, but for the time I'd say this was pretty revolutionary.

Overall I'm glad to have sunk time into this, and I'll be installing The Witcher 2 soon.

reviewText:
Short version: Great game with good story. Some unique elements that are mildly annoying, but add to realism/immersion. Morally grey decisions that cause game-lasting changes to various elements. 8.5/10

Great action RPG with some unique elements that separate it from the rest of it's genre. On the hard difficulty with the Extreme Immersion mod installed (which removes much of the HUD and other elements that make things feel more game-y), it presented a good challenge that never got too frustrating.

The combat system is a bit weird, but not bad once you get used to it. Instead of 1 click per attack, you click once and Geralt launched into a combo. Then you click again at the end of the combo to begin the next flurry. Proper timing leads to much better (and cooler looking) attacks.

Items/potions that restore chunks of health instantly are rare (I know of one). Instead, everything just makes your natural health regen faster. A bit annoying at times, but it does add a bit more realism to the game.

You can't gather alchemy ingredients if you don't know they exist. Again, a bit annoying, but adds realism. If you didn't know that a dog's liver was good for making potions, why would you ever take it out, right?

Finally, this is one of those RPGs that forces you to make various moral decisions (many of which will affect the later chapters in the game significantly, so choose wisely). However, unlike many games which hvae clear good" and "bad" choices
date: Witcher almost always makes you choose between two equally bad options. For example (spoilers incoming)
recommended: at one point you decide whether to support a village whose leaders are murderers
hoursPlayed: rapists
voteText: and child traffickers or to support the witch they are trying to lynch
helpfulPercent: who aided many of those same leaders herself. Both are clearly in the wrong
votesHelpful: but you must decide which to kill and which to save. That decision will affect various things for the remainder of the game (my advice: save the witch)."

reviewText:
With the impending launch of TW3, I made the decision to replay TW and TW2. I didn't finish TW my first time around as I loat interest around chapter 3. I had similar geelings the second time around but I was determined to finish it this time.

Good point for the game:

1. Story is interesting. If you aren't big on stories,  skip this game.
2. Level system allows for some customization. I fully upgraded igni and aard for instance.
3. Hard is challenging without using alchemy constantly.
4. Choices matter for the storyline.

Drawbacks:

1. Combat is static. 3 styles and then signs. Once you know which style and swords to use you can cut up just about any enemy.
2. Collecting alchemy ingredients is tedious as is running out of inventory for them.
3. Side quests are very repetitive.  Kill x of y. Must read some book first. Boring!
4. You can't change geralt's hairstyle!!!!
5. Not for younger gamers as there is quite a bit of sexual content. Almost unnecessarily at times. I mean, the nurses? Really?
6. Storyline in this game is unnecessary to enjoy TW2. Characters met at the beginning are not revisited after the prologue. Looking forward to seeing them in TW3.
7. Some failed quests always remain active in your log. Hot potato for one.
8. Holy lag starting in Chapter 3. FPS averaged around 30 in the Trade Quarter and sometimes lower at night in the swamp.

Though I have more drawbacks than good points, it can still be worth playing if you like the gameplay mechanics, which grew on me I'll admit. For $1.99 on steam sale, why not buy it?

reviewText:
Just completed the game (didn't do all the side quests), and it definitely goes on my top 5 favorite RPG's.  The story and lore of the world created in these games by itself is so immense I felt that captivated by it's story. So captivated in fact that I even started reading the books! The book series story chronologically takes place before the game series begins, and they do a fantastic job making the world created in the books come to life visually! What's even better is that you don't have to read the books to get into the game but it often gives a player whose read them a tip of the hat with settle references to the book series non-readers would miss. I highly recommend reading the book series to really get into this world of The Witcher, but enough about that! Let's get into the pro's and cons! Skip to the recaps at the bottom of each one if you don't feel like reading it all

Pros:
Even though this game is almost a decade old it still holds a lot of core RPG and really compared to today's RPG still feels fresh.
It has a story that changes based on your decisions, which leads to my next pro
This series allows you to port your saves over from game to game. The decisions you make in Witcher 1 effect Witcher 2's story, and Witcher 2 carries over to Witcher 3. Not only does the decisions carry over, but the rare items I work so hard to aquire carry over too! I have began playing Witcher 2 and I was relieved to see my armor, swords, runes, potions, etc. Were all still with me! Especially since most of the awesome rare items are only available towards the end of Witcher 1, but totally worth getting so you can have them in Witcher 2.
Different points of view. Using the F1, F2, F3 you can change from bird's eye view to over the shoulder view! GIving the player the choice to play by their preference.
You get to see boooooobs, and lots of them. Geralt (your character) gets some strange!
The story is fantastic. Playing as a Witcher, a master of sword, magic, and alchemy set on hunting down a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sums it up BUT there is SO much content and unexpected twists.

Recap of pros: Well written story, carry over decisions and items throughout the series(Mass Effect got nothing on Witcher), gettin' some strange. (Seriously, Geralt get's laid in like the first 30 mins of the game)

CONS:
When doing quest the NPC you need to talk to isn't always at the quest marker. So I'll be tracking it on my map, get there, and the NPC is no where to be found. That's because this game has a constant time cycle and simulates day and night. I simply have to wait (or rest to speed it up) till the certain time period for the NPC to show up again. I get it, it adds realism to the game but dammit I hate having to wait for shop keepers to show up I want to buy my items now dammit.
The NPCs are massivley cloned. ALOT of NPC's, other than the important ones, look just like each other. There are a handful of character designs used for townsfolk, gang members, soldiers etc. So it kind of ruins the immerse effect sometimes. I cut Projekt Red a break though, I mean, when this game was developed it's probably the best they could do with the tech we had.  Same with the voice acting too. The special NPC's are their own voice actors throughout the series, but the forementioned NPCs I feel like was 2 or 3 voice actors. All the bandits sound the same.
Compared to todays Open world RPG this game's world is small. Super small. I'm sure at the time this game was released it was very cutting edge but now adays it's going to feel like a small sandbox to the average RPG player. Still a great world though.
and finally, the combat system. It takes some getting used to. After I figured it out it was very simple but just clicking on an enemy Diablo style won't work. It's click, wait for the icon, click again. Though after powering up combo's it is fun to watch Geralt slash open an enemy.

Cons recap: Cloned NPC's, short on voice acting, unexplained missing quest NPCs (until undefined time of day), combat system is wierd compared to today's RPGs.

Overall I give this one 8/10 Toast for Twenty's and am definitely looking forward to playing the rest of the sereis, including the books.

reviewText:
A difficult game to review...

The mechanics are a little old and clunky, so I really didn't care for it at first.  As I played more I started to get into the story, which is rather good. About 4/5 of the way through the game it got boring for reasons I won't spoil.  It did end up finishing strong, however.

There are better games out there to spend your time on, but this one did end up telling an enjoyable story.  If you're not one for flavor text, it's probably best to avoid this one.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm a fan of the Witcher series, ever since this game right here.
It's old, the lack of fast travel, the over complicated alchemy, the very small inventory, the simplistic animations, the incredibly overpowered bosses... all this will try your patience.
But if you want to know how this The Witcher III: Wild Hunt madness began, it was right here.
Very well written with an intrincated story, with some plot twists and an enduring investigation leading up to a final epic confrontation. It will build up to the events of Witcher II, but also to Witcher III. In fact, there's a key moment close to the end where your decisions will make a difference in the third game.
Don't play the other two games without having a go with this one. You'll appreciate the evolution of the plot, but also the evolution of CD Projekt RED in making videogames. And you'll love the technological steps taken in the trilogy.
Also... it's cheap... no excuses there...

reviewText: The combat is janky, the voice acting stilted and the engine was poorly optimized for computers back in 2007 and is STILL poorly optimized today, but The Witcher remains one of the most magnificent computer role-playing games to emerge in the last decade. It's a slow burn especially by today's standards, and I needed to try this game twice before getting into it completely. Once I did, the adventures of potion-mixing, bomb-tossing, double sword-wielding Geralt the Riv totally snared my imagination, and this game remains one of the few modern titles to remind me of my all time favorite RPG/adventure series of yesteryear, Quest for Glory.\n\nReally can't give it a higher recommendation than that.

reviewText:
The Witcher is an RPG that differs from others in several ways. It is old and a bit crude at times, fighting often feels awkward. However, it offers a deep and very interesting story, full of surprises and turns. There's also tons of side quests and every decision you make has consequences on how the story progresses. Also, the game has a whole lot of content. And even though it takes quite some time to actually play through it, it never really gets boring.

In my eyes, this game has more to offer than some modern, high-praised AAA titles.

Also, it is said that, despite it's sheer size, there is a way to finish the game within like a few minutes. Can you find out how?

reviewText: A great game from start to finish. The Witcher will go down as a CRPG classic and will be enjoyed for many years to come. Despite its age, and various technical short-comings, this game feels like a complete package of storytelling and gameplay.\nThe voice acting is **alright** (boring and stale for most characters) and the presentation is so-so, but the story is interesting enough. Looking back on it, I enjoyed the charm and the great world building that this game was able to accomplish even without a high budget. This game definitely set a standard for western ARPGs. The Witcher's simplicity makes it feel even more intimate and I felt like I was reading a book at times.\n

reviewText:
This game is full of rich content, and is thriving with life. Most of the time.

Lets start with the good. It feels like an old timey RPG, with very simplistic, but addictive gameplay models. While the combat may not be supremely engaging, it can be very difficult at times, making preparation before a battle vital to surviving. All you need to do is master the almost, but not quite quicktime attack combat. The animations become more complex, and faster while requiring more timing and clicking with each improvement, making you feel like your moves are getting better and you feel all the more better.

Some potions are easy to make, some are not. Some are very helpful, some not so much. But each one can save your life in a dire situation. You can make a variety of bombs, potions, and oils/weapon enhancements. Some potions even make your character more powerful in general, giving him different abilities and ways to unlock special skills.

Time to talk about the negatives.

The negatives of this game are few, but can really screw with you. My system is very up-to-date and has been updated to keep with the times. However, I have experienced several blue screens through my playtime. I found this extremely odd and angering since no other game has done such a thing to me in the past. Glitches are slightly prevelant, but shouldn't cause too much trouble, and sometimes, the combat can be, at some times, meh. Sometimes, grinding is a factor you might have to use, going through a dangerous swamp to find a single herb for a swallow.

In conclusion, this is a great game, while rough around the edges, is very well made, and has fairly good graphics considering it was made in 2008. I strongly recommend this game, and remember, don't play the other witchers without starting from the beginning. Otherwise, nothing will make much sense in the long run.

reviewText: The Witcher is one of the greatest western RPGs. As you travel along as a Geralt you face many monsters, persons, fights, magic and problems. What is great about Witcher, is the possibility to choose from options how to make the plot go on. I wish I could stop the time and start it all over, just to see what other fates I could have faced. Talent-tree keeps playing interesting and let's players choose what kind of gameplay they prefer. Some problems still bug Witcher and one of them is limited amount of character models. It's not a big problem, but might get annoying for some if the same npc-face in different clothes isn't making sense. Another thing is that Mac version is quite bad port, so the game does crash from time to time and isn't working as it should. Still the game was playable and didn't stop me from enjoying this spectacular piece of pure art. Definitely one of my all-time-favorites.

reviewText: The Witcher's sequel's very first game is a really enjoyable adventure to try out even though the product was been released on 26 October, 2007 by CD Project Red.\nThis first game intoduces you to Temeria and to it's citizens by interacting with them while you're there and making progress on your storyline. Fighting system is pretty enjoyable if the person gets used to it and I also liked that Geralt, the main character, has is own opinions as well, even though the game offers you the chance of choices.\nThis game might be an old one, but if you woud like to to experience the history and the very first introduction to Geralt's world without jumping to the second game, I would recommend it to You.

reviewText: I got this in a Steam sale earlier in the year for around £1 then played for a couple of hours of just the prologue up till the begining of the first chapter. As the combat took some getting use too for me I didn't touch it again.  After a few months I'm back on it, having played further into the story it really has drawn me in. I've also got use to the combat now. The combat itself was for me the only major negative I could think of  that this game had but like I said now I have got use to it. Also some of the voice acting could have been done better. It's not an open world rpg such as Skyrim but has much more depth than that title. It deals with various shades of grey rather than just a moral outlook of black and white.\n\nI haven't any of the other Witcher games so I can't compare this one one to the others. I can say that this is a very immersive and good looking rpg. The artwork is very good. If you do see it on sale it is a no brainer to get it and at full price it is still worth it.

reviewText:
TL/DR- good but not great, must play to enjoy series.

I actually prefer the play style and mechanics of this game compared to its sequels. I've also heard that you don't need to play this Witcher the enjoy the others, I completely Disagree. There are so many details you would miss in the second game and so many questions you wouldn't even know to ask that to really get the effect of the whole series it's best to start at the beginning. That said the graphics are awful by today's standards, and the voice acting and placement of cut scenes even worse. What the game lacks in other areas it makes up for in story, The quest lines are so detailed and subtle gameplay mechanics leaveing amazing hints for those who look close enough.

game play     8/10
Story             11/10
voice acting  5/10

reviewText: Surprisingly beautiful for a game this old. The combat system is a bit wonky but you do get used to it after a while and it's fun to make a few mouse clicks and watch Geralt slice and dice like a maniac. I got a lot of good times out of this game. Probably the only irritating thing is how slow Geralt runs and how often quests will require you to traverse the same ground over and over.\nThe story is top notch and the choices you can make are interesting and matter quite a bit. Plus you can bring your save file over into the second game which can earn you some special armor and weapons if you've gotten them in this game. They're not the best stuff you can get in the second game, which is a bit lousy since they're given much adieu in this game to just be sold off for a pittance in the next one but I guess that's their way of balancing things.\nOverall, it's an experience that is worth having if you want to have an understanding of Geralt's backround before heading into the second and third game.

reviewText: After 44 hours, I must bid farewell to the first game in the Witcher series. Let’s get straight to point: I know that most people start playing and leave the game aside after playing for a few minutes. This is mainly because of the combat system which, at first, may seem complicated and hard to get used to. We've all been there, but trust me, a few hours later into the game and you'll be enjoying both the silver/steel and rock/paper/scissors mechanic, as well as the well-timed clicking" combat system. You'll get used to it in no time! The only complaints I have regarding the game is that it crashed about 6 o 7 times (in 44 hours

reviewText:
A fantastic RPG! A very story driven game with plenty of options to change your 'Destiny'. The game is full of lore to find a long the way with plenty of optional quests to do. The voice acting is great. Works fine on Win 7 with only a few minor issues, save regularly to avoid losing progress.

The talent system is nice with a good potion making system. I mainly stuck with mele combat through out the game. Combat is simple to be fair and not complicated in any way but don't let that stop you, this game for me was all about the story!

I really do recommend this game!

reviewText: The Witcher story is complex and many of the characters carry over in the sequels so if you're interested in playing the entire franchise I would suggest starting here. reviewText: After about 80 hours of gameplay, I finally finished this game, and man was it worth it. Its got 3 different endings depending on your choices. If you've never played the first witcher and decide to just play through the second or third game immediately your doing yourself a slight injustice by skipping out on the first game.\n\nThe game its self though, is quite old and outdated, and there are indeed some dull moments or points where you will find yourself confused as what to do next. The game does suffer from some bugs, and more then once, some events just don't make any sense. However, the story and choices you make, make up for that. It sets just the right tone and introduction to the Witcher 2.  7.5/10

reviewText:
Having played this game multiple times through, I can 100% recommend this game to anyone interested in the Witcher story.

It should be noted that anyone looking to purchase and play this game must understand that it differs immensely from its successors in many ways. The voice acting, character animations, and combat can be a little rough for some, but ultimately the game itself presents an excellent story and really pulls you in to assume the role of a witcher. You'll memorize what combat styles and Signs are useful for each monsters, learn the appearance and usage of herbs throughout the world, and you'll read and learn the lore of the Witcher.

The game presents choices throughout the game, some of which affect the story later. It is up to you decide whether Geralt will take sides or maintain his neutrality as a witcher.

Ultimately, if you intend to play the Witcher 2 or Witcher 3, I recommend you play the full trilogy for the full experience.

reviewText:
tl;dr 8/10

Good game, Very good story, Confusing mechanics but you will learn to love it.

Pro
+ awesome story
+ awesome quests
+ awesome world
+ awesome sex with hot babe

Con
- game mechanics
- combat gameplay
- lot of walking around

Full review  First game in The Witcher series from CD project red.
You will play as Garelt, an amnesia-return-from-the-dead-witcher. who try to regain his memory while on his quest to get the bad guy.

As a witcher you are a monster slayer, a human who train since a child with drug use until become a superhuman to slay monster (and laid girls). Too bad Geralt get amnesia and forget all his fighting skill, magic and knowledge.

The witcher is RPG game with lot of things to do and learn,

Story is so good it’s a pure sex, literally.
Every quest have story in it.
You will have to make a choice, take side, spare or kill which will impact the story later on.

There is also many interesting things to do. Play dice poker, Fist fight, Hunt monster, Help random people and collect romance cards AKA getting laid.

You want to have threesome with nurse? Orgy with vempires? Passionate love with sorcerer? This game have it all!!

Graphic is quite good, for old game. The atmosphere and graphic fit the wolrd of witcher nicely.
Music are very good too especially boss fight.

Gameplay is fun. Combat? Not so much.
When you attack Garelt will perform one set of sword move. When the move end cursor will change and you have to click attack again to make combo. If you click attack before or too late the move will stop. It's not that bad actually after you get used to and quite fun later in the game when you are strong but overall combat feel clunky, unresponsive and can be frustrated.

Gameplay is fun and addictive but you will found yourself walking around the map doing quest. Go there, do that kinda thing. No fast travel in this game too. While I find myself enjoy the world and love exploring it. Walking around across the map many times can be boring.

Game mechanics take awhile to get used to. Especially alchemy and crafting.
There is a steel sword for fight human and silver sword to fight monster. There is 3 different fighting style for different enemies. There is potions, blade oils, bombs with different effect which you can make and use if you get ingredients. You will have to buy books or find information about each monster and herb to be able to collect it. And many other little thing.
It will feel annoying at first but it will be a lot of fun after you get used to it. Too bad that I start to feel fun in the last chapters of the game.

The witcher may have boring start with it gameplay and story especially if you have play other witcher games before. Give it a try for a few hour first before you decide to uninstaling it.

Conclusion  The Witcher overall is a very fun RPG. Rich in story and charecter. Combat might not be the best and game mechanics might be confusing but worth to play and I'm sure you won't regret it.
If you interesting in the witcher series from CDPR DO NOT skip this one.

ps: sorry for my english.

reviewText:
I'm not a big fan of RPG Games, and i never play the Witcher series either. many reviews said that the Witcher series is a good and amazing RPG games, and with the new game (The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt) been released, i think it's time for me to play the game. bought the first 2 games in Summer sale, and now i've finished the first one (The Witcher Enhanced Edition) and here's my review:

First of all, i love the protagonist, Geralt of Rivia, a Witcher, he's one cold-tough-badass-guy, a perfect and efficient killing machine, but sometimes he can be funny too (Like when you meet random people and talk to them, and then you start an awkward conversation). Geralt is also an interesting character, from the beginning of the game, Geralt lost his memories. at first there's nothing special with Geralt, just a Legendary Monster slayer who lost his memories, but as you progress through the game, you'll understand why Geralt is an interesting character.

Next is the other Characters. in every chapters you'll meet new characters, friends and enemies that you'll hate or love. For example, in early game you'll be introduced to Siegfried, a Knight, and you can choose to befriend with him (help him) or just ignore him. I chose to befriend with him and it's worthy, he's one loyal friend. Yes, you can actually choose how to interact with other characters  and it's all about Decisions. Every decisions have impacts on the story, like if you decided to spare someone, he/she will later meet you again and they actually will help you or hate you, so you have to choose wisely.

For the Story. The story is a little bit cliche, but there are so many surprises in each chapter. All chapters are unique and once you play, you'll be eager to progress to the next chapter (There are 5 chapters in the game). The main quests are interesting but many of the quests are confusing (at least for me), like after you talk to someone the red marker on the map just dissapeared and i have to search on google to find the solution. and for the Side quests, well, some side quests or Contracts are repetitive like you must collect some loots from monsters and deliver them to the quest giver. Also in each chapter there's a trophy monsters that you can hunt, it's fun to hunt them, and the reward is good (Money, You need money in early game, so completing Side Quests/contracts and hunting the trophy monsters is a good idea).

For the Gameplay. The swordfight is simple, as you just click on the enemy, wait for the cursor to turn red and click again to do a combo attack, but sometimes in a group fight, you'll need to do more than just clicking on enemies, also there are 3 types of attack styles you can use depending on the enemy. you can use Signs (Magic) to help you in a fight, like you can use Aard to stun and allows you to move and plan another attack, or my favorite the Igni, a magic that bursts fire to the enemy and incinerate them.

Overall, i love the game! The story is good (and like i said, so many surprises), the characters are interesting, especially for the Protagonist Geralt, and the gameplay is simple yet challenging.
Well, my review is not that good compared to others, but i just want to share it here :D

reviewText:
This game is worth playing.  The combat system is very wonky but once you get the hang of it, it isn't so bad at all, and the story is very good.  Also the choices you make in this game carry over to 2nd game.

Act I, III and IV move along quite well.  Act II, V and Epilogue seem to drag on.

The alchemy system is a bit confusing but the game tells you what you can make so it isn't too bad.  Level up Igni a lot, it is very powerful, maybe a bit too powerful.

To answer the question:  Is it worth playing this game or should I just skip to the 2nd game?  The short answer: Yes, play this game!  The long answer: if you are a roleplaying enthusit you will enjoy the many nuances the game has to offer, also Geralt's sense of humor is amazing!  The game is a long one, I clocked over 50 hours on it.

reviewText:
TLDR: Fantastic game; Combat is not very good but story is absolutely amazing. Graphics great for 2007, obviously lackluster for 2015. Not open world. Play on hardest difficulty, because after chapter 1 game is a cakewalk. Although not needed, (really at all) the story in this game serves to clarify references in the later games and creates a bigger sense of immersion in the game world. 8.5/10 because of combat and lack of challenge.

This is my Witcher story. I bought Witcher 3 because I wanted a new RPG to play; it was absolutely amazing. I only got through the first chapter and realized that I didn't want the experience to end so quickly so I decided to buy the first one and work my way through that and once done with that play through the second and then eventually move on to finish the third. That's how good this series is, if you're a fan of action RPG's with good stories like me, get the trilogy pack instead of this because if you can bear the combat/graphics (both of which are not THAT bad) of Witcher 1 you will definitely want to play the second and third. You will also enjoy them moreso because you have the background info of the first one.

So I loaded up Witcher 1 for the low cost of $9.99. First thing I noticed when I started playing the Witcher was the graphics, although extraordinary for 2007, after overclocking my GPU to play the third I was a little disappointed, but you can't ask for much when you backtrack to a game that came out 8 years ago!

The next thing I noticed was that this game's story is awesome. Cheesily enough, you start off with amnesia. However Geralt's lack of memory serves to push the story forward; Alongside the main conflict in the story, you are trying to find out about Geralt's past through quests and former friends. The best part about the story is that you actually can't wait to find out what happens next. This is the only rpg where I actually read the extra books and lore things you find in the game world because they serve the story so well.  Where most RPG's push for progression by enticing you with new pieces of armor or weapons down the road, the Witcher puts you in a position where you actually want to find out what happens next and you don't really care about much else. However, at times, much of the story is told just by running back and forth and talking to various npcs - there gets to be a point when you want to just go out and smash some monster face. That leads me into one of the only two fair cons to find in this game (because you can't count the graphics of this game as a real con due to its age.)

My problems with this game are the combat and the lack of challenge. The fights remind me of Test Your Might" challenges from Mortal Kombat. You just wait until your sword turns yellow and then click
date: thats it. The whole combat system is click
hoursPlayed: click
voteText: repeat. there's no real challenge or engagement to it. If you can't kill a monster you just reload and drink more buff potions. When I say there is no challenge to this game

Other than the boring combat and lack of challenge I don't have anything else to really gripe about. I mean the inventory system could have been better and there could have been more applications for alchemy but all in all this is a fantastic game. Sorry for the long winded review."
